--- ## **üõ°Ô∏è Acquiring Adaptive (Acquired) Immunity**

Bio 3/4 frames acquired (adaptive) immunity using two independent classifications: whether immunity is active or passive, and whether it is natural or artificial.

This results in four combinations:

  • Natural active
  • Natural passive
  • Artificial active
  • Artificial passive

> üí° A useful exam rule is that **‚Äúnatural‚Äù means without medical intervention,** while **‚Äúartificial‚Äù involves medical intervention** (for example, a vaccine). ### **Active vs Passive Immunity** **Active immunity** always involves the person developing their **own antibodies** and their **own memory B cells** (and **memory T cells**), meaning **immunological memory** is formed. It must involve **clonal selection**. Because **memory cells persist**, active immunity can be maintained through **re-exposure** or **booster vaccinations**. **Passive immunity** occurs when **antibodies are received from an external source**. The recipient‚Äôs **immune system is not activated**, so **immunological memory does not develop**. ### 1. Natural active immunity **Natural active immunity** is produced when a person is **infected** or **naturally exposed to an antigen** and, as a result, produces their **own antibodies** via **plasma B cells** and develops **memory B and T cells**. This is why recovery from certain infections can **reduce the likelihood of reinfection**: **memory cells** enable a **faster, stronger response** upon later exposure. > üí° **Exam cue:** if the question stem includes **‚Äúactive‚Äù**, you should explicitly mention **immunological memory** and **memory lymphocytes**. ### 2. Natural passive immunity **Natural passive immunity** is the **transfer of antibodies** (not antigen exposure) in a **natural context**. A special case occurs in **babies/young children**, providing **temporary protection** during **immunological weakness**. It is acquired via **antibodies crossing the placenta** and via **breast milk**. **IgG crossing the placenta** can be referenced to explain this **natural passive protection**. ### 3. Artificial active immunity (vaccination) **Artificial active immunity** occurs when a person is **artificially exposed** to a pathogen (typically via a **vaccine**), stimulating an **immune response** so the recipient develops **antibodies** plus **memory B and T cells** (**immunological memory**). A **vaccine** is defined here as an **attenuated (weakened) form of a pathogen** that stimulates an immune response and creates **immunological memory**; therefore, **vaccination produces artificial active immunity**. ### 4. Artificial passive immunity (antiserum, monoclonal antibodies) **Artificial passive immunity** involves **antibodies produced in another organism** after exposure to a pathogen; these antibodies are **extracted and administered** as an **antiserum** to provide **temporary protection**. **Monoclonal antibodies** are an example of **artificial passive immunity**. ![Active vs Passive Immunity](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/DiseaseSummary1.1.webp) --- ## **üíâVaccines, Herd Immunity and Maintaining High Coverage** ### **Vaccines** A **vaccination** introduces **attenuated (weakened) pathogens or antigens**, stimulating the immune system to produce: - **Antibodies** - **Memory B cells** - **Memory T cells** This enables **faster and stronger responses** upon later exposure to the same pathogen, leading to significant reductions in **disease cases and deaths** at a population level. > **‚ùó Common exam misconception:** > > Vaccines do **not usually contain whole, live viruses**. They typically contain **attenuated pathogens or specific antigens**. ![Vaccines](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/DiseaseSummary1.2.webp) >### ‚ùì How vaccination produces immunity (exam-style) > >The **vaccine** introduces **antigens** (via an **attenuated virus**) that are taken up by **antigen-presenting cells**, activating a **specific T helper cell**. The **T helper cell** then activates a **selected B cell** and releases **cytokines**, driving differentiation into **plasma B cells** and **memory B cells**. **Plasma B cells** produce **antibodies** to clear the **attenuated pathogen/antigens**, while **memory cells persist**. Upon **later exposure**, **memory B cells** rapidly differentiate to generate a **faster, stronger response**. ![Vaccination producing Immunity](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/DiseaseSummary1.3.webp) ### **Herd Immunity** **Herd immunity** occurs when a **large proportion of the population** is immunised, reducing the number of susceptible hosts and making **transmission difficult**. Immunological memory is central: vaccinated individuals respond quickly, limiting infection and **onward spread**. Herd immunity is **important** because it **protects vulnerable people** who cannot be immunised, including: - **Newborn babies** - **Elderly individuals** - **Immunocompromised people** - **Pregnant women** It also reduces exposure risk for **unvaccinated individuals** by lowering overall disease circulation. ### Booster Vaccines and Long-term Protection **Booster vaccines** are important for maintaining **herd immunity**. Subsequent vaccinations matter because the **first vaccine establishes memory B and T cells** (and **antibodies**), enabling **faster and stronger responses** in later exposures. **Repeated immunisations** can also **restore and increase memory cell numbers** that decline over time if not stimulated. ### ‚ùì Why Vaccination Coverage Can Fall (and Lead to Re-emergence) **Immunological memory** can fade in a population if **booster vaccines are not given**, reducing **herd immunity**. This decline may be linked to **anti-vaccination beliefs** or **personal choice**. In addition, **antigenic drift or antigenic shift** can change **pathogen antigens** so that previously selected **lymphocyte receptors** are no longer complementary, meaning **memory responses are less effective** and **new clonal selection is required**. ### ‚úÖ Keeping Vaccination Coverage High

Two key strategies are identified:

  • Improving access to vaccines and vaccination programs
  • Addressing vaccine hesitancy through education about vaccine safety and benefits

--- ## **üß´ Pathogen Identification and Screening** **‚ùì Why identification and screening matter** Accurate **pathogen identification** allows **targeted public health responses** (e.g. **isolation** and **contact tracing**) and informs **appropriate treatment decisions**. **Screening** is particularly important for **rapidly detecting infected individuals** so they can be **isolated** to limit **transmission**. ### **Traditional (Phenotypic) Methods of Pathogen Identification** Traditional methods rely on **observable physical characteristics**. These can be grouped into **microscopy**, **Gram staining**, and **culturing pathogens on agar plates**. ### 1. Microscopy (physical observation) **Microscopy** uses **physical features** (including **surface features**) to differentiate and identify pathogens. An advantage is that it is **cheap and accessible**, but it can be **prone to error** because it relies on **human judgement** and may **miss fine details**. ### 2. Gram staining **Gram staining** is a **phenotypic test** used to classify **bacteria**: - **Gram-positive bacteria** have **thicker cell walls** and stain **purple** - **Gram-negative bacteria** have **thinner cell walls** and stain **pink** This method is useful early because it provides a **rapid preliminary classification**. ### 3. Culture on agar (in vitro culturing) Pathogens can be **cultured on agar plates**, and the resulting **colonies** can be used to help identify **what type of pathogen is present**. ![Methods of Pathogen Identification](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/DiseaseSummary1.5.webp) ### **Immunological Identification: ELISA (Best Framed as Screening)** **ELISA** is an **immunological technique** that detects the presence of **antibodies** to a pathogen in **blood**. Mechanistically: - **Antibodies complementary to the pathogen‚Äôs antigen** are attached to a plate - A **patient sample** is added - **Binding occurs** if the relevant antigen/target is present - The plate is **washed** - **Conjugated antibodies** are added, producing a **coloured signal** - The signal can be **quantified using a spectrophotometer** A key limitation is **timing**: if the **adaptive immune response** has not yet produced detectable antibodies, ELISA can produce a **false negative**. For this reason, ELISA is best emphasised as a **screening test**, rather than a definitive **virus vs bacteria** identifier. ![ELISA](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/DiseaseSummary1.6.webp) --- ## **Modern (Molecular) Methods** ### **PCR** **PCR testing** detects **pathogen DNA** by **amplification using specific primers**. If amplification occurs, it indicates the presence of **specific DNA**. PCR is often followed by **gel electrophoresis**. - **Main advantage:** **early diagnosis**, as very small quantities of DNA can be amplified - **Key disadvantage:** **cost** and **limited accessibility** in lower-resource settings ### **DNA sequencing** **DNA sequencing** is considered the **most detailed identification method** because it determines the **exact nucleotide sequence** of a pathogen‚Äôs DNA and allows tracking of **genetic changes over time**. It is particularly valuable when: - **Strains are evolving** - **Precise identification** is required **DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation** is also a molecular identification method, using **complementary DNA** to test for the presence of pathogen DNA. >### üß† Screening Nuance: Antigen vs Antibody > >If the question asks **‚ÄúDoes the person currently have the illness?‚Äù**, testing for **antigen** is preferred. **Antibodies alone** are **not a reliable indicator of current infection**, as they may persist after recovery. > >This distinction is commonly tested in **VCAA-style data interpretation questions**.
--- ## Conclusion for Dealing With Disease In this topic, we examined how diseases arise, spread, and are controlled at both the **individual** and **population** level. A disease is any condition that disrupts normal body function, and understanding whether it is **infectious or non-infectious** is essential for correctly classifying outbreaks, epidemics, and pandemics. - **Patterns of disease spread:** Diseases may exist as **endemic**, **outbreak**, **epidemic**, or **pandemic** conditions, depending on how widely and rapidly they spread. Importantly, only **infectious diseases** can cause pandemics, while epidemics may be either infectious or non-infectious. - **Emerging and re-emerging diseases:** Diseases may emerge due to **zoonotic spillover**, **mutation**, or movement into **new populations**, while re-emerging diseases occur when previously controlled pathogens increase again due to **waning immunity**, **pathogen evolution**, or **drug resistance**. - **Adaptive immunity and vaccination:** Adaptive immunity may be **active or passive**, and **natural or artificial**, producing four possible combinations. **Vaccination** generates **artificial active immunity** by stimulating antibody production and the formation of **memory B and T cells**, enabling faster and stronger immune responses upon re-exposure. - **Herd immunity and population protection:** High vaccination coverage reduces the number of susceptible individuals, limiting transmission and protecting vulnerable groups who cannot be immunised. **Booster vaccinations** are essential for maintaining long-term herd immunity as immunological memory declines over time. - **Pathogen identification and screening:** Accurate identification supports effective public health responses. Traditional methods rely on **phenotypic characteristics**, while modern molecular techniques such as **PCR** and **DNA sequencing** enable early detection and detailed genetic analysis. **Screening tests** prioritise speed, while **confirmatory tests** prioritise accuracy. Overall, effective disease control relies on understanding **pathogen biology**, **immune responses**, and **population-level strategies**, allowing informed decisions that reduce transmission, prevent re-emergence, and protect public health.

Always refer to your school resources for complete and accurate coverage of the syllabus. # **üõ°Ô∏è Immunity** ## **Pathogens, disease, and transmission** **Pathogens:** organisms or causative agents that cause disease in a host. **Disease:** any condition that interferes with how an organism (or any part of it) functions, and it is usually caused by a pathogen. **Host:** the organism that has the disease, meaning it is harmed or affected by the pathogen. **Transmission** is often described using **vectors**. A **vector** is an organism that carries a pathogen from one host to another with **no harm done to the vector**. If the ‚Äúvector‚Äù is harmed while transmitting the disease, it is actually functioning as a **host**. **Examples of vectors** include: - mosquitoes - sandflies - rats/mice - houseflies ![Pathogen Transmission](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.0.webp) The **key pathogen groups** to recognise are: - viruses - prions - fungi - helminths (worms) - protozoa (protists) - bacteria (with **‚Äúvirion‚Äù** sometimes used as a related term for viruses). In this topic, **viruses and prions** are emphasised as **non-living / non-cellular**. A useful way to organise this is to separate pathogens into: - **non-cellular agents:** viruses and prions - **cellular organisms:** bacteria, fungi, protozoa/protists, helminths
### ü¶† Viruses and virions

Viruses are considered non-living because they:

  • do not carry out normal cellular processes
  • do not maintain internal temperature
  • require a host for reproduction
  • do not carry out metabolism by themselves

The term **virion** refers to the virus particle when it is **outside the cell** (for example, after completing its cycle inside the host and causing lysis). >**üß† Virus structure** is a common exam question. > >A virus consists of: > >- genetic material (**DNA or RNA**) >- a protein coat called a **capsid** >- in some viruses, an outer **lipid envelope**
### Prions **Prions** are described as highly infectious because a **single prion** can trigger a **cascading reaction**, leading to more and more non-functional prions. They are not easy to ‚Äúkill‚Äù using typical approaches like high temperature, because they are already **misfolded proteins**; further denaturation does not solve the underlying issue. **Examples of prion diseases** include: - mad cow disease - kuru ![Prions](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.1.webp) ### **Cellular pathogens (bacteria, fungi, protists)** ### Bacteria Bacteria are **prokaryotes** that replicate via **binary fission**, and while most are not pathogenic, some are. Bacterial damage is described in two main ways: - release of **toxins** (metabolic waste) - **direct damage** to host cells ### Fungi Fungi are distinguished by a **chitin cell wall** (compared with **peptidoglycan** in many bacteria), and are noted as commonly affecting **skin**. ### Protists (protozoa) Protists are described as **unicellular eukaryotes** that are generally **parasitic**. A key example is **malaria**. Their spread is explicitly linked to **vectors** (for example, a mosquito), which introduce them into new hosts, where they then **replicate rapidly**.
--- ## **1Ô∏è‚É£ The first line of defence** The **first line of defence** is **non-specific**, meaning it provides the same general protection regardless of which pathogen attempts to enter. It is also referred to as **innate immunity** because it does not require prior exposure to develop; it is present from birth. A key advantage is **speed**: the non-specific defences (**first and second lines**) are always acting, giving an **almost instant response** to pathogen entry and providing **quick protection** while the slower, pathogen-specific **third line** activates. Importantly, the **non-specific defence does not produce immunological memory**. The first line can be organised into **three barrier types**: - **physical** - **chemical** - **microbiological** ![First line of defence](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.3C.webp) ### **Physical barriers** A **physical barrier** is a physical defence that blocks pathogens from entering the host. Key examples include **intact skin**, **mucus membranes and mucus secretions**, **nasal hairs**, and **cilia**. - **Intact skin** acts as a physical outer layer that prevents entry of pathogens and foreign substances, functioning as a barrier between the internal environment and the outside. - **Mucus membranes** line the respiratory tract (and also urinary and gastrointestinal tracts). Their secretions trap pathogens and dirt to prevent them entering body tissues. - **Nasal hairs** filter and trap microorganisms in nasal passages. - **Cilia** are hair-like structures lining the respiratory tract that move mucus and trapped materials away from the airways toward the gastrointestinal tract, where swallowed pathogens can be destroyed. ![Airway physical defence](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.4.webp) ### **Chemical barriers** A **chemical barrier** includes enzymes, toxins, acids, or other chemicals that protect the host from pathogens. Examples include **stomach acid**, **sweat and oil on the skin**, and **tears and saliva containing lysozymes**. - The **stomach** contains hydrochloric acid at low pH, which kills many microorganisms. - **Sweat and oil** secreted on the skin inhibit bacterial growth. - **Tears and saliva** contain **lysozymes** (enzymes) that break down pathogens. ### **Microbiological barriers** The **microbiological barrier** refers to non-pathogenic bacteria living on the skin and lining the intestinal tract. These non-pathogenic microbes take up space and compete for resources, inhibiting the growth of pathogenic bacteria. **Examples** include: - *Lactobacillus* - *E. coli* >### üéØ Example: preventing respiratory infection >In the respiratory tract, **mucus traps inhaled bacteria** and **cilia move the trapped material toward the throat** to be swallowed; the gastrointestinal tract then destroys many pathogens, supported by the **stomach‚Äôs very low pH**. ![Preventing Respiratory Infection](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.5.webp) --- ## **2Ô∏è‚É£ Second line of defence** The **second line of defence** is part of **innate immunity** and acts rapidly once a pathogen has breached the **first-line barriers**. It relies on **immune cells (leukocytes)** and **coordinated signalling** to contain infection, remove pathogens and debris, and begin **tissue repair**. ### **Innate immune cells involved** **Leukocytes** are produced in **bone marrow**. Relevant cell types are: - granulocytes - histamine-releasing cells - phagocytes - antigen-presenting cells (APCs) - natural killer (NK) cells >### üß† Key roles to know > >- **Neutrophils (granulocytes):** typically first major phagocytes to arrive at the infection site; they engulf pathogens and contribute to **pus formation** when they die. >- **Macrophages:** large phagocytes that engulf pathogens and debris; they also release **signalling molecules (cytokines)** that help coordinate inflammation. >- **Dendritic cells (APCs):** phagocytic cells that can present antigens, forming an important **bridge into the third line of defence**. >- **Mast cells / basophils:** histamine-releasing cells that drive key **blood vessel changes** in inflammation. >- **NK cells:** innate lymphocytes that can destroy infected host cells (often recruited via signalling such as **interferons**), supporting early control of viral infection. ### üìç Inflammatory response sequence (what happens at a wound/infection) 1. **Cytokines** released at the infection site act as chemical signals. 2. **Mast cells** degranulate and release **histamine**. 3. **Histamine** causes **vasodilation** (widening of nearby blood vessels) and increases **capillary permeability** (vessels become ‚Äúleakier‚Äù). 4. **Leukocytes** move out of the blood and into tissues at the site (often neutrophils early, followed by macrophages and dendritic cells). 5. **Phagocytosis** removes pathogens and debris; if skin is broken, **clotting** can help seal the entry point. ![Inflammatory response sequence](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.6.webp) ### Signs and outcomes of inflammation Typical inflammatory signs include: - **redness and heat** (from increased blood flow) - **swelling** (fluid and immune cells moving into tissues) - **pain** (pressure and local chemical signals) **Pus** is commonly seen when many neutrophils and pathogens have died and accumulated in the area. The overall aim is to **limit spread**, **clear the cause**, and **support repair**.
### **Innate non-cellular processes** ### ‚ùì What does ‚Äúnon-cellular‚Äù mean in the second line? The second line of defence includes several **non-cellular processes** that help control pathogens quickly once the first line is breached. **Four key non-cellular processes**: - **fever and pain** - **complement proteins** - **interferons** - **the inflammatory response** ***(Inflammation is covered in the previous section; this section focuses on the remaining three.)*** ### Fever and pain ***System-level innate response*** Fever and pain commonly occur as part of an infection response. **Fever** is linked to temperature regulation by the **hypothalamus** (a specialised region of the brain responsible for temperature regulation). In response to a pathogen, signalling molecules released by **macrophages** stimulate the hypothalamus to **increase body temperature**. This rise in temperature is detrimental to pathogens because higher temperatures: - inhibit pathogen function by moving conditions above the **optimal temperature for pathogenic enzymes** - reduce enzyme catalytic ability - inhibit reproduction Fever can also push temperature beyond a pathogen‚Äôs **tolerance range**, contributing to **enzyme denaturation** and slowing pathogen cellular processes (around **39¬∞C** in severe cases). ![Fever and Pain](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.7.webp) ### Complement proteins ***Used for marking, recruiting, and lysing pathogens*** **Complement proteins** are described as a special type of **non-specific defence** that can bind to a pathogen‚Äôs outer layer. Once bound, they support three linked outcomes: - **opsonisation** - **chemotaxis** - **formation of membrane attack complexes (MACs)** **Opsonisation** is when complement proteins coat the exterior of a pathogen (notably bacteria), marking it for **phagocytosis** and making it easier for phagocytic cells to recognise and engulf it. **Chemotaxis** refers to attracting phagocytic cells to the infection site, increasing the likelihood the labelled pathogen will be destroyed. Complement proteins can also **lyse pathogens** via **MAC formation**. MACs create pores in the pathogen membrane, allowing water movement into the cell and killing it through **lysis / osmotic pressure**.
### Interferons ***Antiviral warning signals*** **Cytokines** are immune signalling molecules used by immune cells (such as leukocytes) to communicate; examples include **interferons** and **interleukins**. **Interferons** are described as a signalling molecule (a cytokine subtype) released by **virally infected host cells**. Their roles are: - alert nearby healthy cells to produce **antiviral proteins** in preparation for an upcoming attack - attract **natural killer (NK) cells** to release **granzymes and perforin** Interferons are also noted as an **innate defence** against **virally infected host cells** and **cancer / tumour cells**. ![Inteferons](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.8.webp) --- ## **3Ô∏è‚É£ Third line of defence (adaptive immunity: specificity, antibodies, and pathways)** The **third line of defence** is **adaptive immunity**: it is **specific** (targets particular antigens) and involves **clonal selection and expansion** of lymphocytes that have receptors complementary to an antigen. It is typically **slower to activate** than the innate lines because the correct lymphocyte must be **selected and activated** and, in many cases, antigen must be **transported and presented in lymphoid tissue**. #### Antigens and lymphocyte specificity An **antigen** is a molecule that induces an immune response; it is usually a **protein**, but may be a **polysaccharide**. Each lymphocyte has **identical receptors** on its surface, and each lymphocyte is **specific to one antigen** that is complementary in shape and chemical properties. Only the lymphocyte whose receptor matches the antigen is selected (**clonal selection**). ![Antigen and Lymphocytes](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary1.9.webp) ### **Clonal expansion and differentiation** After selection, the activated lymphocyte rapidly divides to produce a population (**clone**) of genetically identical lymphocytes (**clonal expansion**). These then differentiate into: - **effector cells** (immediate action) - **memory cells** (long-term readiness) For **B cells**, differentiation produces: - plasma B cells - memory B cells For **T cells**, **memory T cells** are also produced as part of the adaptive response. >### ‚ùì What are antibodies? >**Antibodies** are proteins produced as part of the **humoral response**. > >They are **Y-shaped molecules** with **variable regions at the tips** that determine antigen specificity. One antibody is specific to **one antigen**, and each antibody can bind **two identical antigens** (one on each arm). > >There are **five functional outcomes** of antibody binding: > >- precipitation >- immobilisation >- agglutination >- neutralisation >- opsonisation > >Antibodies can also **activate complement**, contributing to **membrane attack complex (MAC) formation**. ### **Humoral immunity (B cell pathway)** In the **humoral response**, **helper T cells** play a central activation role by releasing **cytokines**. A **B cell** with the complementary receptor is activated (often after antigen interaction and signalling), then differentiates into: - **plasma B cells** - **memory B cells** Plasma B cells produce and release **large quantities of antibodies** that bind to the antigen and support pathogen removal. ### **Cell-mediated immunity (T cell pathway)** In the **cell-mediated response**, **helper T cells** release cytokines that activate **cytotoxic T cells**. Cytotoxic T cells: - recognise foreign antigen presented on **MHC I** of infected or abnormal cells - kill these cells by releasing **perforin and granzymes**, triggering **apoptosis** **Memory T cells** are also formed, improving responsiveness on re-exposure. ![Cell-mediated immunity](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary2.0.webp) --- ## **üß¨ Lymphatic system and lymphoid tissues** #### ‚ùì What does the lymphatic system actually do? The **lymphatic system** is a network that supports **immunity and fluid balance**. Key functions include: - returning excess **interstitial fluid** to the bloodstream (once inside lymphatic vessels, this fluid is called **lymph**) - producing lymphocytes in **primary lymphoid tissues** - housing immune cells in **lymph nodes** - transporting **fatty acids** - helping transport **antigen-presenting cells (APCs)** to secondary lymphoid tissues >#### ‚ùì Why it is essential for the third line of defence >A major reason the third line of defence is delayed is that **lymph (and/or APCs carrying antigen)** must travel to **lymph nodes**, where clonal selection and activation occur. > >Adaptive immunity is **specific**, so the correct lymphocyte must be found, selected, and expanded. This makes lymph nodes a critical **‚Äúmeeting point‚Äù** where innate detection connects to adaptive activation. ![Lymphatic System](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/ImmunitySummary2.1.webp) ### **Lymph formation and movement** At the capillaries, fluid leaks out into surrounding tissues, forming **interstitial fluid**. This fluid can contain: - water - proteins - leukocytes - sometimes pathogens When interstitial fluid enters **lymphatic capillaries** it becomes **lymph**. Lymphatic capillaries begin as tiny **blind-ended vessels** in the interstitial spaces and widen into larger lymph vessels. Lymph vessels contain **valves** that ensure **one-way movement**, preventing backflow. ### **Lymph nodes: screening, presentation, and activation** **Lymph nodes** are small structures positioned along lymph vessels. Their role is to: - **screen lymph** for pathogens - coordinate immune responses They are described as a major site for: - **antigen presentation** - **clonal selection** - **clonal expansion** of lymphocytes Lymph nodes contain **phagocytes**, **antigen-presenting cells**, **B cells**, and **T cells**, enabling innate cells to present antigen to lymphocytes and trigger adaptive responses. ### **Primary vs secondary lymphoid tissues** ### Primary lymphoid tissues Primary lymphoid tissues are where lymphocytes are **produced and mature**. - All leukocytes are produced in **bone marrow** - **T cells** mature in the **thymus** - **B cells** mature in **bone marrow** A defective thymus weakens the third line of defence due to **impaired T cell maturation**. ### Secondary lymphoid tissues Secondary lymphoid tissues include: - lymph nodes - spleen - tonsils - appendix The **spleen filters blood**, whereas **lymph nodes filter lymph**. --- ## üõ°Ô∏è Summary for Immunity Disease occurs when **pathogens** disrupt normal body function. Pathogens may be **cellular** (bacteria, fungi, protists, helminths) or **non-cellular** (viruses and prions). Transmission can occur directly or via **vectors**, which carry pathogens between hosts without being harmed. The immune system protects the body using **three coordinated lines of defence**: ### 1Ô∏è‚É£ First line of defence (innate, non-specific) The first line prevents pathogens from entering the body and provides the same protection against all pathogens. It includes: - **Physical barriers** such as intact skin, mucus membranes, cilia, and nasal hairs - **Chemical barriers** such as stomach acid, sweat, oils, and lysozymes in tears and saliva - **Microbiological barriers** where non-pathogenic microbes compete with pathogens for space and resources These defences act immediately and do **not** produce immunological memory. ### 2Ô∏è‚É£ Second line of defence (innate, non-specific) The second line responds rapidly once pathogens breach first-line barriers. It involves immune cells (**leukocytes**) and coordinated signalling. Key features include: - **Inflammation**, driven by cytokines and histamine, causing vasodilation, increased capillary permeability, and movement of leukocytes into tissues - **Phagocytosis** by neutrophils and macrophages to remove pathogens and debris - **Fever and pain**, which inhibit pathogen enzyme activity and reproduction - **Complement proteins**, which promote opsonisation, chemotaxis, and pathogen lysis via membrane attack complexes (MACs) - **Interferons**, which warn nearby cells of viral infection and recruit natural killer (NK) cells These responses limit pathogen spread and support tissue repair but do not create long-term memory. ### 3Ô∏è‚É£ Third line of defence (adaptive, specific) The third line provides **pathogen-specific immunity** and involves lymphocytes that recognise particular **antigens**. Key processes include: - **Clonal selection**, where only lymphocytes with receptors complementary to the antigen are activated - **Clonal expansion**, producing genetically identical cells - **Differentiation** into effector cells and long-lived memory cells Two adaptive pathways operate: - **Humoral immunity**, where B cells differentiate into plasma cells that produce antibodies and memory B cells - **Cell-mediated immunity**, where cytotoxic T cells destroy infected or abnormal cells, forming memory T cells Antibodies bind antigens to cause neutralisation, agglutination, precipitation, immobilisation, and opsonisation, and can activate complement. ### üß¨ Lymphatic system and immunity The lymphatic system supports immunity by returning interstitial fluid to the bloodstream, transporting antigens and antigen-presenting cells, and providing sites for immune activation. - **Primary lymphoid tissues** (bone marrow and thymus) produce and mature lymphocytes - **Secondary lymphoid tissues** (lymph nodes, spleen, tonsils) filter lymph or blood and are key sites of antigen presentation, clonal selection, and clonal expansion Overall, effective immunity relies on the integration of **barrier defences**, **rapid innate responses**, and **specific adaptive immunity with memory**, allowing the body to control disease and respond more efficiently to future infections.

> ‚ö†Ô∏è **Note:** This explanation is meant to support your understanding, but it is **not a substitute for your official textbook or prescribed course materials**. Always refer to your school resources for complete and accurate coverage of the syllabus. # **Mechanisms of Evolution** This topic explains **how populations evolve over time** by examining the processes that **change allele frequencies** in gene pools, including mutation, natural selection, genetic drift, gene flow and reproductive isolation. ## **üß¨ Gene pools, allele frequency, and genetic diversity** >### **‚úçÔ∏è Core definitions** > >***You must be able to state the following:*** >- **A population:** all members of a species at a given location or time. >- **A gene pool:** the complete set of alleles present within that population. >- In exam language, **evolution at the population level** is often described as **changes in allele frequencies within the gene pool over time**. ### **Allele frequency** - **Allele frequency** is the number of times an allele of interest occurs in the gene pool compared to the total number of alleles in the gene pool (**allele of interest √∑ total alleles**). - A quick way to avoid mistakes is to **translate genotype counts into allele counts first**. - For example: - Convert each **homozygote** into **two copies of its allele**. - Convert each **heterozygote** into **one copy of each allele**. - Then **sum the allele counts**. ### **Genetic diversity** - **Genetic diversity** refers to the variety of alleles present in a population‚Äôs gene pool. - A **larger, more diverse gene pool** contains a greater variety of alleles and therefore has **greater genetic diversity and greater adaptive potential**. - **Adaptive potential** is the population‚Äôs capacity to respond to selection pressures, because a wider range of alleles increases the likelihood that some individuals already carry an allele that becomes favourable when the environment changes. - Conversely, **low genetic diversity increases extinction risk** because the population may lack alleles that allow survival and reproduction under new pressures. ### ‚ùì How genetic diversity increases ***Linking back to the gene pool*** - Genetic diversity can be increased by **mutations** and **gene flow (interbreeding / immigration between populations)**. - **Mutations** introduce **new alleles** into a population‚Äôs gene pool. - They arise from **random changes in DNA sequences**. - Mutations may be **induced by mutagens** such as radiation or chemicals, or **occur spontaneously**. - **Gene flow** transfers alleles **between populations**. - It increases genetic diversity in the **recipient population** by introducing alleles that were **previously absent** from that gene pool. ![Genetic Diversity](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.0.webp) >### üí° Exam cues to use in written responses > >When explaining why diversity matters, explicitly connect: > **greater variety of alleles** ‚Üí **higher chance of favourable allele** ‚Üí **better response to selection pressures** ‚Üí **higher adaptive potential**
--- ## **üß™ Sources of new variation: mutations (and what counts as heritable)** ### ‚ùì Why mutations matter ***The ‚Äúnew allele‚Äù mechanism*** **Mutations** are a primary source of **new genetic variation** because they introduce **new alleles** into a population‚Äôs gene pool, expanding the range of alleles available for **selection pressures** to act on over time. Not all mutations are beneficial; depending on the **environment** and the **gene or protein affected**, a mutation may be **advantageous**, **disadvantageous**, or **neutral**. ### ‚ùì How mutations arise ***Spontaneous vs induced*** Mutations arise from **random changes in DNA sequences**. They may occur **spontaneously** or be **induced by mutagens**, which increase the probability of DNA changes occurring. Common **mutagens** include: - **Radiation** - **Chemicals** ![Spontaneous vs Induced Mutation](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.2.webp) ### ‚ùì What counts as heritable A mutation is **only heritable** if it occurs in a **gamete or germline cell**, allowing it to be passed to offspring. Mutations in **somatic (body) cells** are not inherited, even if they affect the individual, and therefore **do not contribute directly to allele frequency change across generations**. >**üí° Exam discriminator (always state explicitly):** > >- Only **germline mutations** can affect evolution >- **Somatic mutations** do **not** affect allele frequencies across generations
### **Categories of mutations** Mutations are grouped into **three main categories**: - **Point mutations** (affect a single gene; often single-nucleotide changes) - **Block (chromosomal-level) mutations**, including: - deletion - duplication - inversion - translocation - **Chromosome-number changes**: - polyploidy - aneuploidy ### Point mutations ***Substitution trio + frameshift (and typical consequences)*** **Substitution mutations** include the **substitution trio**: - **Silent mutation**: a single nucleotide substitution that does not change the amino acid coded, highlighting **redundancy of the genetic code** and typically producing no change to the polypeptide. - **Missense mutation**: a single nucleotide substitution that changes one amino acid, altering **primary structure** and potentially protein function. - **Nonsense mutation**: a single nucleotide substitution that creates a **stop codon**, causing premature termination and a **truncated polypeptide**. A nonsense mutation near the **end of the mRNA** is often less impactful than one in the **middle**. **Frameshift mutations** are also considered point mutations but involve: - **Insertion or deletion of a single nucleotide** - A **shift in the reading frame** - Disruption of subsequent codons, often causing **major disruption to protein function** ### Block (chromosomal) mutations and chromosome number changes **Block mutations** operate at the **chromosomal level** and include: - **Deletion**: loss of a large DNA segment - **Duplication**: replication of a segment producing extra copies and elongating the chromosome - **Inversion**: segment order reversed without size change - **Translocation**: segment breaks off and attaches to a **non-homologous chromosome** These larger-scale changes are often associated with errors during **meiosis**. Separately: - **Polyploidy** refers to possessing **more than two complete sets of chromosomes** - **Aneuploidy** refers to an **abnormal number of chromosomes** (extra or missing)
--- ## **Selection pressures and natural selection** ***How allele frequencies shift***

A selection pressure is a sudden environmental change that influences an organism‚Äôs ability to survive and reproduce. Examples include food scarcity, exposure to antibiotics, changes in environmental colour/background, the appearance of a new predator, disease, and climate change.

> üí° In exam answers, the **selection pressure must be explicitly stated**, as it is the driver that determines which phenotypes are considered **fit** in that specific context. ### **Natural selection** **Natural selection** is the selection of the most advantageous phenotype suited to overcome an environmental selection pressure. It is a **population-level process**, because its long-term outcome is a **change in allele frequencies in the gene pool over generations**. >### üß† How natural selection shifts allele frequencies (Causal template) > >A high-scoring response follows this causal chain: >- **Variation:** there is pre-existing genetic variation in the population, meaning at least two phenotype or allele groups exist. >- **Selection pressure:** an environmental selection pressure becomes present (state and name it). >- **Advantage vs disadvantage:** one phenotype/allele is advantageous while another is disadvantageous under that pressure. >- **Differential survival and reproduction:** individuals with the advantageous allele are more likely to survive and reproduce, producing viable, fertile offspring. >- **Inheritance and frequency change:** the advantageous allele is passed to offspring, so its **allele frequency increases over generations**.
> ‚ö†Ô∏è **Note: natural selection does not create new alleles**; it **increases the frequency of existing favourable alleles** because their carriers leave more offspring. ### Fitness and heritability The **environment determines fitness**, meaning which phenotypes or alleles are more likely to survive and reproduce. However, a trait must be **heritable** for its frequency to increase over time. This is why natural selection is described in terms of **inherited alleles**, rather than acquired characteristics. ### Effect on genetic diversity Natural selection generally **reduces genetic diversity**, as alleles linked to higher fitness are favoured while alternative alleles decrease in frequency. Over time, the population‚Äôs phenotype distribution becomes **driven toward the fit allele** under that selection pressure. --- ## **Non-selection mechanisms of allele frequency change** #### **What ‚Äúnon-selection‚Äù means** Not all allele frequency change is driven by natural selection. Allele frequencies can shift **without any allele being better adapted**, through: - **Genetic drift** (random chance events), - **Gene flow** (movement of alleles between populations), - **Inbreeding** (breeding within a limited population). Genetic drift and gene flow both change allele frequencies, but they have **opposite effects on genetic diversity**. ### üé≤ Genetic drift ***Random chance changes*** **Genetic drift** is a change in allele frequencies due to **random chance events**, and its effects are strongest in **small populations**. Small populations are more susceptible because the gain or loss of a few individuals can cause large shifts in allele frequencies. Because small populations often already have **low genetic diversity**, genetic drift can worsen extinction risk. ![Genetic Drift](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.1.webp) ### Founder effect The **founder effect** is a type of genetic drift where a new population is established by a **small, unrepresentative group** from a larger population. The resulting gene pool differs from the original and has **lower genetic diversity**, reducing adaptive potential and increasing vulnerability to environmental change. ![Founder Effect](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.4.webp) ### Bottleneck effect A **population bottleneck** occurs when a random disaster (e.g. flood, drought, earthquake, bushfire) reduces a population to small numbers. This removes alleles from the gene pool, leaving a surviving population that is **unrepresentative** and **low in genetic diversity**. Even if population size later recovers through inbreeding, **lost alleles are not restored**, and allele frequencies remain altered. Advantageous alleles may be lost purely by chance, reducing adaptive potential. ### Gene flow **Gene flow** is the transfer of alleles between populations, often through interbreeding. It **introduces new alleles** into the recipient population and **increases genetic diversity**, while potentially reducing diversity in the population experiencing emigration. Compared to drift: both change allele frequencies, but **genetic drift decreases genetic diversity**, whereas **gene flow increases it**. Gene flow can also help populations recover after drift events. ### Inbreeding **Inbreeding** is continued breeding within the same population among genetically similar individuals. Excessive inbreeding increases the frequency of **recessive alleles**, raising the risk of genetic disorders, and **does not increase genetic diversity**. Following founder or bottleneck events, inbreeding may restore population numbers, but **cannot restore lost genetic diversity**. --- ## üß¨ **Reproductive isolation and speciation (allopatric vs sympatric)** >### **‚úçÔ∏è Core definitions** > >***You are expected to know the following:*** >A **species** is a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce **viable, fertile offspring**. **Speciation** is the process by which populations genetically diverge until they become **genetically distinct** and can no longer interbreed to produce viable, fertile offspring. >> In Bio 3/4 terms, speciation is driven by **reproductive isolation**: something prevents **gene flow and interbreeding** between two groups for long enough that genetic differences accumulate. ### üöß The key role of barriers ***Reproductive isolation*** **Barriers** prevent **gene flow and interbreeding**, keeping populations separate. Once isolated, populations experience **different selection pressures**, and over time **genetic differences accumulate** through: - **Mutations** - **Genetic drift** - **Natural selection** As **allele frequencies shift differently** in each population, they evolve independently until they become **distinct species** that can no longer interbreed to produce viable, fertile offspring. ### Types of barriers: pre-zygotic vs post-zygotic

Pre-zygotic barriers prevent reproduction before a zygote forms and are especially relevant to sympatric speciation:

  • Temporal: different breeding seasons or times
  • Behavioural: different mating calls or courtship behaviours
  • Habitat / ecological: different habitats within the same location
  • Mechanical: incompatible reproductive structures

Post-zygotic barriers occur after zygote formation and include:

  • Inviability (offspring does not survive)
  • Infertility (offspring cannot reproduce)

### **Allopatric vs sympatric speciation** - **Allopatric speciation** must involve a **geographic barrier** (e.g. rivers, mountains, highways, sea). - **Sympatric speciation** occurs **without a geographic barrier**, relying on **non-geographic barriers** such as temporal, behavioural, habitat/ecological, or mechanical isolation. >### üß† Allopatric speciation > >- An existing species is split into two by a **specific geographic barrier**. >- The barrier **prevents gene flow and interbreeding**. >- The isolated populations experience different **selection pressures**, **mutations**, and **genetic drift**. >- **Genetic differences accumulate** over time. >- Eventually, the populations can no longer produce **viable, fertile offspring**.
>### üß† Sympatric speciation template > >- An existing species is split by a **non-geographic barrier** (temporal, behavioural, mechanical, or ecological). >- **Gene flow is prevented** despite populations living in the same area. >- Different selection pressures lead to **accumulation of genetic differences**. >- Over time, two species form that **cannot interbreed** to produce viable, fertile offspring. ***‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Speciation may not occur if gene flow is still permitted, if the populations have not been separated for long enough, or if they experience similar selection pressures.*** **e.g 1. Distinguish allopatric speciation from sympatric speciation. (3 marks)** - ***Allopatric speciation: a geographic barrier separates populations and stops gene flow/interbreeding.*** - ***Sympatric speciation: no geographic barrier; gene flow is prevented by non- geographic (pre-zygotic) barriers such as temporal/behavioural/ecological/mechanical.*** - ***In both cases, reproductive isolation allows genetic differences to accumulate until populations can no longer produce viable, fertile offspring.*** --- ## **Human-driven change and fast-evolving pathogens** ### **üß¨ Selective breeding (artificial selection): humans as the selection pressure** Selective breeding differs from natural selection because the selective agent (selection pressure) is **human choice**, rather than the environment. Like natural selection, selective breeding increases the **frequency of a favoured allele**, but it also tends to **reduce genetic diversity** because certain phenotypes are heavily favoured while others are neglected. We can highlight two major biological risks: - **Inbreeding of selected organisms**, which increases the abundance/expression of **recessive or deleterious (harmful) alleles** - **Overall reduction of genetic diversity** A further disadvantage is that humans may select traits that are **aesthetically pleasing or desired**, rather than actually advantageous for survival in the environment. ![Selective Breeding](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.5.webp) Selective breeding is described as **faster and more efficient than natural selection** because humans strongly and deliberately select the wanted trait, ensuring the chosen alleles are passed down. >### üß† Human-driven selection template: > >- pre-existing **genetic variation** exists >- **humans act as the selection pressure** favouring one phenotype >- humans breed that phenotype, **allowing favourable alleles to be passed to the next generation** >- over time, the **frequency of the selected allele increases** ***‚ö†Ô∏è Like natural selection, it only works if the favourable allele is heritable***. A key extension is the **human-induced bottleneck effect**: excessive selective breeding can overly favour one allele, driving the population strongly towards that allele and neglecting the rest, resulting in a major reduction in genetic diversity. ### ü¶† **Antibiotic resistance: natural selection in bacteria** **Antibiotic resistance** arises through **natural selection**. Bacterial populations show **pre-existing genetic variation**, meaning some bacteria carry resistance alleles while others do not. The process follows a standard selection pathway: - Exposure to **antibiotics** acts as the **selection pressure** - **Resistant bacteria** have a survival advantage - **Non-resistant bacteria** are more likely to die - Resistant bacteria survive, reproduce, and **pass resistance alleles to offspring** - Over time, the **frequency of resistant bacteria increases** Pre-existing variation can be explicitly linked to **mutations** (and also interbreeding), which contribute to genetic diversity and different phenotypes. ![Antibiotic Selection](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.7.webp) Resistance becomes a practical problem because: - Older antibiotics become **less effective** - Higher dosages or new treatments are required (with increased **side effects**) - **Unnecessary antibiotic use** (e.g. treating viral infections) strengthens the selection pressure - Widespread antibiotic use **accelerates natural selection for resistance** **e.g 2. Explain how antibiotic resistance increases in a bacterial population through natural selection. (3 marks)** - ***Pre-existing variation: some bacteria already carry a resistance allele (e.g., from mutation).*** - ***Antibiotic exposure acts as the selection pressure, so resistant bacteria survive/reproduce more than non-resistant bacteria.*** - ***Resistant bacteria pass the resistance allele to offspring, increasing its frequency over generations.*** ### üß™ **Viral evolution: antigenic drift vs antigenic shift** Viruses evolve rapidly to gain a **selective advantage**, often reducing the effectiveness of existing vaccinations. This occurs through changes to **surface antigens**, primarily driven by mutations. ![Antigenic Drift vs Shift](https://vceproblems.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/question_media/EvolutionSummary1.8.webp) **Antigenic drift**: - Involves **small, gradual changes** in viral surface antigens over time - Each change is minor, but changes **accumulate** - Immunological memory becomes less effective - Contributes to **reduced vaccine effectiveness** over time **Antigenic shift**: - A **sudden, rapid change** in viral surface antigens - Often occurs when **two or more viral strains combine** - Involves **viral recombination** - Produces large antigenic changes - Natural immunity is often **absent**, increasing outbreak risk
--- ## Conclusion for Mechanisms of Evolution In this chapter, we explored how **evolution operates at the population level** through changes in **allele frequencies** over generations. Evolutionary change depends on the interaction between **genetic variation** and **environmental or human-driven pressures**, shaping which alleles are passed on. - **Genetic variation and gene pools:** Populations contain a pool of alleles, and **genetic diversity** within this pool determines a population‚Äôs **adaptive potential** and ability to respond to changing conditions. - **Sources of variation:** **Mutations** introduce new alleles, while **gene flow** redistributes alleles between populations. Only **heritable (germline) mutations** contribute to evolutionary change. - **Natural selection and selection pressures:** **Selection pressures** favour certain phenotypes, leading to **differential survival and reproduction**. Over time, this increases the frequency of **favourable alleles**, without creating new ones. - **Non-selection mechanisms:** **Genetic drift**, **founder effects**, **bottlenecks**, and **inbreeding** can change allele frequencies by chance, often reducing genetic diversity, while **gene flow** can increase diversity. - **Speciation and isolation:** **Reproductive isolation** prevents gene flow, allowing populations to diverge genetically through **allopatric** or **sympatric speciation** until they form distinct species. - **Human-driven change and pathogens:** **Selective breeding**, **antibiotic resistance**, and **viral evolution** demonstrate how strong selection pressures can drive **rapid evolutionary change**, often with important consequences for genetic diversity and public health. Together, these mechanisms explain how populations evolve, diversify, and sometimes speciate in response to both natural processes and human influence.
