\\(\\text{Only substrates with the correct starting shape can trigger the proper induced shift, so the enzyme becomes}\\)
\\(\\text{more selective.}\\)

questions.question_text: A plant produces a compound that binds to the first enzyme in a long pathway that normally makes bitter defensive chemicals. These chemicals help protect the plant from insects. Field studies show that when insects are absent, the plant produces far less of these compounds to save energy. To do this, the plant releases a small molecule that binds to the first enzyme in the pathway and slows it down. The compound blocks the enzyme whenever too much final product builds up.

orders.text_content: a) Identify this form of pathway control. (1 mark)
b) Explain the benefits of this pathway control. (2 marks)
c) Explain why this control must target the first enzyme, not the last. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Feedback inhibition}\\)

\\(\\text{Regulating the first step prevents the cell from using energy to make unneeded intermediates, hence energy conservation}\\)
\\(\\text{for efficient survival. Blocking early steps prevents build‚Äëup of products that could disrupt cell balance.}\\)

\\(\\text{Blocking the first enzyme stops the entire pathway before resources are used, while blocking the last step would}\\)
\\(\\text{still allow wasteful intermediate formation.}\\)

questions.question_text: A rare metal binds tightly to the active site of an enzyme that breaks down nerve toxins. Once bound, the metal never detaches.

orders.text_content: a) Name this type of inhibition. (1 mark)
b) Explain how this metal affects the active site. (2 marks)
c) Explain why enzyme levels fall even though the metal does not destroy enzymes. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Irreversible competitive inhibition.}\\)

\\(\\text{The metal permanently occupies the active site.}\\)
\\(\\text{This prevents the substrate from entering, blocking all catalytic activity.}\\)

\\(\\text{Once an enzyme is permanently blocked, it becomes non‚Äëfunctional, so the number of active enzymes decreases}\\)
\\(\\text{over time, meaning fewer active sites available for substrates to bind to.}\\)

questions.question_text: A key enzyme in a plant, responsible for an intermediate step in a metabolic pathway, needs Mg¬≤‚Å∫ as a cofactor to stabilize charges in the active site. A plant grown in Mg¬≤‚Å∫ poor soil shows slow growth because this enzyme does not function well.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the enzyme fails without Mg¬≤‚Å∫. (1 mark)
b) Explain how missing cofactors alter active site shape. (2 marks)
c) Explain why the whole pathway stops even if only one enzyme needs Mg¬≤‚Å∫. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Mg¬≤‚Å∫ is needed to stabilize charged groups in the active site, allowing the enzyme to bind substrate properly.}\\)
\\(\\text{It improves enzyme, substrate affinity.}\\)

\\(\\text{Cofactors help the enzyme fold into the correct tertiary structure.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without Mg¬≤‚Å∫, the active site loses its correct 3D shape and cannot bind to substrate, as the active site lacks the}\\)
\\(\\text{complementary fit.}\\)

\\(\\text{Metabolic pathways rely on each step occurring. If one enzyme stops, downstream products cannot form, so the}\\)
\\(\\text{whole pathway shuts down.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Three tubes are tested with equal substrate:
Tube A: enzyme only
Tube B: enzyme + substrate
Tube C: enzyme + substrate + non‚Äëcompetitive inhibitor

orders.text_content: a) Rank the tubes from fastest to slowest reaction. (1 mark)
b) Explain why Tube C stays slow even at high substrate. (2 marks)
c) Explain how the inhibitor alters tertiary structure. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Allosteric binding shifts the enzyme‚Äôs tertiary structure, distorting the active site and reducing catalytic function.}\\)
\\(\\text{Tube B fastest, Tube C slowest, Tube A has no reaction.}\\)

\\(\\text{Non‚Äëcompetitive inhibitor binds to an allosteric site rather than the active site this binding changes the active}\\)
\\(\\text{site shape so extra substrate cannot restore activity.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Many ‚Äúbiological‚Äù laundry powders contain enzymes that help break down food, blood and sweat stains. One common group are proteases, which cut long protein chains into smaller, washable pieces. Many of these proteases come from heat-tolerant bacteria such as Bacillus licheniformis.

A customer washes clothes at 20¬∞C and finds many stains remain.
Another customer washes at 80¬∞C and also gets poor results.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the enzyme works slowly at 20¬∞C and hence why the customer receives poor results? (3 marks)
b) Explain why washing at 80¬∞C also gives poor stain removal. (3 marks)
c) Explain why the detergent is designed to work best at 40‚Äì50¬∞C rather than at 25¬∞C. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{At 20¬∞C, enzyme and substrate molecules have low kinetic energy.}\\)
\\(\\text{There are fewer effective collisions between enzyme active sites and substrate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fewer enzyme‚Äìsubstrate complexes form per second, so stain breakdown is slow.}\\)

\\(\\text{High temperature disrupts bonds that hold the enzyme‚Äôs specific 3D shape.}\\)
\\(\\text{The active site changes shape so it is no longer complementary to the substrate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Substrate can no longer bind properly, so the enzyme becomes denatured and inactive. }\\)

\\(\\text{At 40‚Äì50¬∞C, particles move faster, so there are more successful collisions per second.}\\)
\\(\\text{This higher collision rate increases enzyme activity and stain breakdown, while still avoiding rapid denaturation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
During COVID PCR testing, viral RNA from SARS-CoV-2 is first converted to DNA using reverse transcriptase, then amplified using PCR with fluorescent probes that bind to viral sequences. A student designs a test where the probe binds to a human gene instead of a viral gene, but all other steps are correct.

What is the most likely outcome?

orders.text_content:
A. No fluorescence in any sample, because PCR can only amplify viral DNA
B. Fluorescence in all samples, because the probe binds to human DNA in every person
C. Fluorescence only in samples with a very high viral load
D. No fluorescence in positive cases, because reverse transcriptase only copies viral RNA

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. PCR can amplify ANY sequency of DNA, given specific primers.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{The thinking trap is thinking PCR ‚Äúonly works on virus‚Äù or that reverse transcriptase is selective for viral RNA. This}\\)
\\(\\text{question is worded in a complex manner, so reading it slowly is key.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In PCR, detectives amplify a single-exon gene from a crime scene sample. The teacher claims both primers bind to 3‚Äô ends of the same strand of DNA to let Taq polymerase copy in opposite directions.
Why is this statement wrong?

orders.text_content:
A. Primers bind to 5‚Äô ends of both strands, not 3‚Äô ends
B. One primer must bind RNA, not DNA
C. Primers must bind to opposite strands, each at a 3‚Äô end, so polymerase can extend towards each other
D. Primers must bind within introns, not exons

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{C. Both primers bind 3‚Äô ends, but on opposite strands, allowing extension inwards.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A forensics lab receives a 15-year-old bloodstain. Some DNA is degraded into many small fragments. They perform PCR on several STR loci and then run a gel.
Which issue is most likely if degradation is severe but not complete?

orders.text_content:
A. STR bands appear thicker than normal because small fragments run more slowly
B. Some STR loci fail to amplify, leading to missing bands and ambiguous matches
C. All bands shift upward because degraded DNA carries less negative charge
D. Extra random bands appear because degraded fragments re-anneal into new STRs

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Degraded DNA often lacks intact target regions, so some STRs do not amplify, giving partial profiles. The trap is A,}\\)
\\(\\text{which wrongly links degradation with thicker bands.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student runs three DNA samples and a standard ladder on an agarose gel. The ladder bands are 100, 200, 300, 400, 500 bp. One sample shows a single band slightly between the 300 and 400 bp bands but closer to 400.

orders.text_content:
Which conclusion is most accurate?

A. The fragment is exactly 350 bp, so the measuring equipment is wrong
B. The fragment size is estimated, not exact, and is probably around 360‚Äì380 bp
C. The fragment must be 400 bp because bands cannot sit between ladder bands
D. The gel has run incorrectly and must be repeated

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Gel size estimates are approximate; band position between ladder bands suggests an estimated size, not an}\\)
\\(\\text{exact number.}\\)
\\(\\text{Option C is a deliberate trap. This question requires a deeper understanding of gel electrophoresis.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A lab wants to separate DNA fragments of 100 bp, 120 bp, and 130 bp that are very similar in size.
Which conditions is most likely to improve separation between these bands?

orders.text_content:
A. Use a higher agarose concentration and run for longer at moderate voltage
B. Use a lower agarose concentration and very high voltage
C. Use a higher agarose concentration but run only for a short time
D. Use a lower agarose concentration and very low voltage

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Higher agarose concentration creates smaller pores, improving resolution of similar sizes and creating clear differences}\\)
\\(\\text{between two small fragments of similar length. Note that high voltages increase risk of smearing.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A plant is engineered to produce more vitamin A. Researchers insert a gene into a plasmid and transform bacteria that later infect the plant cells.

What type of organism is created?

orders.text_content:
A. Clone
B. Transgenic organism
C. Polyploid
D. Haploid

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. A plant with an inserted foreign gene is transgenic.}\\)

questions.question_text: A class compares heat-shock transformation and electroporation for the same plasmid. Heat shock uses rapid temperature changes; electroporation uses short electrical pulses to open membrane pores. They find electroporation gives many more transformed colonies, but some show signs of cell damage.

orders.text_content:
A. Heat shock never works, so all colonies must be contaminants
B. Electroporation allows more plasmids in but can damage membranes if pulses are strong
C. Heat shock destroys plasmids but not cells
D. Electroporation only works if plasmids carry antibiotic resistance

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. Electroporation can be more efficient but harsher.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A recombinant plasmid carries a tetracycline-resistance gene and the gene of interest. Only transformed bacteria survive when grown on tetracycline. A student claims the only evidence a surviving colony is transformed is that it is resistant to tetracycline.

Why is this claim incorrect?

orders.text_content:
A. Some bacteria are naturally tetracycline-resistant or may have non-recombinant plasmids
B. Tetracycline breaks down quickly and never kills bacteria
C. Tetracycline resistance genes do not exist on plasmids
D. Transformation never happens with tetracycline selection

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Resistance alone does not prove the plasmid carries the gene of interest; there may be non-recombinant plasmids}\\)
\\(\\text{or natural resistance. Consider hypotheticals.}\\)

\\(\\text{A. Resistance alone does not prove the plasmid carries the gene of interest; there may be non-recombinant plasmids}\\)
\\(\\text{or natural resistance. Consider hypotheticals.}\\)

questions.question_text: In another experiment, the plasmid has both tetracycline resistance and a color-producing gene. The gene of interest is inserted into the color gene‚Äôs restriction site. Transformed bacteria grow on tetracycline plates; some colonies are colored, others are colorless.

orders.text_content:
Which colonies most likely contain the recombinant plasmid with the gene of interest?

A. Colored colonies, because the color gene is intact
B. Colorless colonies, because insertion disrupts the color gene
C. All colonies, because growth on tetracycline proves recombination
D. No colonies, because insertion into any gene kills the bacteria

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. Insertion in the color gene disrupts its expression, so colorless colonies carry the inserted gene. A is the classic trap.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In recombinant insulin production, two different plasmids are created: one carries the gene for the A subunit, the other for the B subunit. Both use ampR and tetR markers, and the insulin gene is inserted into the tetR region. 

Bacteria are first plated on ampicillin, then replica-plated onto tetracycline.

Which pattern identifies bacteria with recombinant insulin plasmids?

orders.text_content:
A. Grow on both ampicillin and tetracycline
B. Grow on ampicillin, die on tetracycline
C. Die on ampicillin, grow on tetracycline
D. Die on both antibiotics

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Recombinant plasmids still carry ampR but have tetR disrupted by the insulin gene, so they are sensitive to tetracycline.}\\)
\\(\\text{Visualization of disruption is key for selecting right answer.}\\)

\\(\\text{B. Recombinant plasmids still carry ampR but have tetR disrupted by the insulin gene, so they are sensitive to tetracycline.}\\)
\\(\\text{Visualization of disruption is key for selecting right answer.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Insulin subunits expressed in bacteria are fused to a large Œ≤-galactosidase protein before being cleaved later.

Why is this fusion step useful?

orders.text_content:
A. It increases transcription of the insulin gene
B. It protects the small insulin peptide from being degraded inside bacteria
C. It makes insulin toxic to bacteria
D. It ensures insulin contains introns

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The large fusion partner shields the small peptide from proteases. A is the trap, fusion affects stability more than}\\)
\\(\\text{transcription.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In bacteria, Cas1‚ÄìCas2 cut a protospacer from viral DNA and insert it into the CRISPR locus as a new spacer. Later infections trigger expression of guide RNAs that match these spacers and direct Cas9 to cut the viral DNA.

Why can this be considered as an ‚Äòadaptive‚Äô immune system?

orders.text_content:
A. It only defends against one virus type
B. It gains new spacers after each new infection, improving future protection
C. It uses antibodies to recognize viruses
D. It works only at high temperature

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. New spacers store a ‚Äúmemory‚Äù of previous infections.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A clinic uses CRISPR-Cas9 to silence a mutant gene in liver cells. Later testing finds changes in another gene that was not meant to be edited.

What is the best explanation?

orders.text_content:
A. Cas9 randomly cuts DNA whenever ATP is present
B. The guide RNA located a complementary sequence adjacent to PAM site, elsewhere
C. Liver cells cannot repair double strand breaks
D. CRISPR always deletes entire chromosomes

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. Off-target effects occur when similar sequences plus a PAM are present elsewhere.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher wants to disable a gene to study its function in mice using CRISPR-Cas9.
Which approach is most appropriate?

orders.text_content:
A. Create a cut and provide no repair template, allowing error-prone repair to disrupt the gene.
B. Provide a template carrying a corrected version of the gene
C. Insert a strong promoter upstream of the gene
D. Insert extra copies of the gene into a plasmid

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{A. Gene knockout relies on error-prone repair introducing frameshifts or early stop codons.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A company offers CRISPR editing on embryos to remove a disease gene.
Concerns are raised about consent and fairness.
Which ethical principles are most directly involved?

orders.text_content:
A. Autonomy and justice
B. Beneficence only
C. non-maleficence only
D. Confidentiality only

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{A. Embryos cannot give informed consent (autonomy), Access may favor the wealthy (justice).}\\)

questions.question_text:
A wheat plant has been edited using CRISPR to increase drought tolerance by manipulating DNA using genes from the same wheat species. No DNA from other species was added.

How should this plant be classified?

orders.text_content:
A. Transgenic GMO
B. Cisgenic GMO
C. non-GMO organism
D. Bacterial clone

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The genome has been modified using engineering but only with DNA from the same species. The trap is C, assuming}\\)
\\(\\text{‚Äúno foreign DNA = not GMO‚Äù.}\\)

questions.question_text: A DNA profile shows, at one STR locus, a single thick band for person X and two thinner bands for person Y at different positions on the gel.

orders.text_content:
Which statement is most accurate?

A. X and Y have the same genotype
B. X is homozygous at this STR, Y is heterozygous
C. Y is homozygous, X is heterozygous
D. Both are heterozygous

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. One band = homozygous; two bands = heterozygous.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student runs gels at very high voltage in a warm room with low-concentration agarose. The bands appear smeared and some DNA has migrated off the gel.
Which combination of issues best explains this result?

orders.text_content:
A. High voltage and low agarose concentration reduce movement of DNA
B. High voltage, high temperature and low agarose concentration make DNA run too fast and denature
C. Low voltage and high agarose concentration make bands too sharp
D. High agarose concentration and cold temperature cause smearing

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Too much voltage + heat + large pores = very rapid movement, smearing, possible denaturation, and bands}\\)
\\(\\text{leaving the gel. These factors are often not used as favorable conditions for gel electrophoresis due to smearing.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A scientist wants to know whether a patient carries a specific allele that differs by only a few base pairs from the normal allele. They have limited DNA.

Which sequence of techniques is most suitable?

orders.text_content:
A. Gel electrophoresis alone
B. PCR to amplify the region, then gel electrophoresis to separate alleles by size
C. PCR alone, without any size separation
D. CRISPR editing followed by PCR

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. PCR provides enough copies; gel electrophoresis resolves small size differences. A is a trap because there may}\\)
\\(\\text{be too little DNA to see.}\\)

questions.question_text: A teacher claims that each PCR cycle adds one extra copy of the target gene, so 30 cycles create ‚Äú30 copies‚Äù. Students know Taq polymerase copies both strands each cycle.

orders.text_content:
A. PCR is linear; 30 cycles make 60 copies
B. PCR is exponential; ideally, the number of copies roughly doubles each cycle
C. PCR is random; copy number cannot be predicted
D. PCR stops after three cycles due to Taq denaturation

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. Ideal PCR roughly doubles target DNA each cycle (2‚Åø pattern), not linear addition.}\\)

questions.question_text: A forensic lab receives a degraded DNA sample from a 15-year-old cold case. The team decides to run PCR using standard denaturation, annealing and extension temperatures. The primers target a 120 bp STR region known to survive degradation.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the 95¬∞C step is necessary for this sample. (2 marks)
b) Explain why primers must bind to the 3‚Ä≤ ends of opposite strands. (2 marks)
c) Explain why Taq polymerase is essential in this investigation. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Heating to 95¬∞C breaks hydrogen bonds and separates the DNA strands.}\\)
\\(\\text{So, primers can access and bind to exposed, complementary sections of target DNA.}\\)

\\(\\text{Primers must bind to opposite strands, so polymerase extends toward the target region from both sides.}\\)
\\(\\text{Binding at the 3‚Ä≤ ends ensure the STR region between primers is amplified, not DNA outside the target.}\\)

\\(\\text{Taq polymerase does not denature at 95¬∞C, so it remains active through repeated heating cycles.}\\)
\\(\\text{A heat‚Äëstable polymerase is required to copy DNA during each extension step after denaturation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A scientist wants to clone a drought-tolerance gene from a plant into a plasmid.
The gene contains two internal EcoRI sites. The plasmid has one EcoRI site inside a screening gene. 
The scientist instead uses HindIII and XbaI, which do not cut inside the gene.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why EcoRI cannot be used to isolate this gene. (2 marks)
b) Explain why using two different restriction enzymes helps orient the gene correctly. (3 marks)
c) Explain why DNA ligase is necessary after cutting with HindIII and XbaI. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Using EcoRI would cut the gene into multiple fragments.}\\)
\\(\\text{This prevents the entire coding region from being inserted into the plasmid.}\\)

\\(\\text{HindIII and XbaI create non-matching sticky ends.}\\)
\\(\\text{This forces the gene to insert in only one direction.}\\)
\\(\\text{Correct orientation ensures the promoter transcribes the entire coding sequence, ensuring the correct protein is}\\)
\\(\\text{expressed.}\\)

\\(\\text{Sticky ends only form temporary hydrogen bonds.}\\)
\\(\\text{Ligase seals sugar-phosphate bonds permanently, forms ‚Äòphosphodiester‚Äô bonds.}\\)
\\(\\text{This stabilizes the recombinant plasmid so bacteria can replicate it.}\\)

questions.question_text: A lab edits a tomato gene to delay ripening. Cas9 makes a cut next to a PAM sequence. Sequencing after editing shows three types of outcomes: normal sequence, a 3-bp deletion, and a 17-bp insertion.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why Cas9 requires a PAM sequence to cut DNA. (2 marks)
b) Explain why some edited cells show a short deletion while others show a longer insertion. (3 marks)
c) State one reason only some cells show the desired delayed-ripening trait. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Cas9 binds only when a PAM sequence sits beside the target.}\\)
\\(\\text{PAM prevents Cas9 from cutting similar sequences lacking PAM.}\\)

\\(\\text{The cell repairs cuts using error-prone NHEJ.}\\)
\\(\\text{NHEJ may remove bases or add random bases.}\\)
\\(\\text{These changes often disrupt gene function.}\\)

\\(\\text{Not all cells receive the same mutation or frameshift.}\\)
\\(\\text{Only cells with a disruptive change express the new phenotype.}\\)

questions.question_text: A lab attempts to separate three fragments: 120 bp, 300 bp, and 305 bp. The gel shows the 120 bp band clearly, but the 300 and 305 bp bands appear as one blurred band.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the 300 bp and 305 bp fragments did not separate. (3 marks)
b) Suggest three changes to improve separation in the next trial. (3 marks)
c) Explain why increasing voltage too much worsens separation. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 3 marks:}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Their sizes are extremely similar.}\\)
\\(\\text{The gel pores were potentially too large to create enough resistance.}\\)
\\(\\text{Insufficient voltage}\\)
\\(\\text{Insufficient run time}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 3 marks:}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Increase agarose concentration to create smaller pores.}\\)
\\(\\text{Reduce voltage to slow fragment migration.}\\)
\\(\\text{Run the gel longer to allow clearer spacing.}\\)
\\(\\text{Use polyacrylamide gel for finer separation.}\\)

\\(\\text{High voltage causes bands to migrate too quickly.}\\)
\\(\\text{Rapid movement leads to smearing and poor resolution.}\\)

questions.question_text: Engineers redesign bacteria to produce human insulin for medical use. Modern insulin production is based on a process first developed by Genentech in 1978, when scientists created the world's first genetically engineered drug. To do this, the insulin A-chain and B-chain genes are inserted into separate plasmids, because bacteria cannot assemble the final hormone on their own. Each insulin gene is inserted inside the tetR gene, disrupting tetracycline resistance. The plasmid retains its ampicillin-resistance gene (ampR) and an origin of replication (ori) so it can multiply inside the bacterial cell. After transformation, bacteria are first grown on ampicillin plates, then replica-plated onto tetracycline plates to identify true recombinants.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why recombinant colonies grow on ampicillin plates but die on tetracycline plates. (3 marks)
b) Explain why insulin is produced as two separate chains in bacteria. (3 marks)
c) State one reason the insulin gene is fused to Œ≤-galactosidase before purification. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Insulin must fold into two polypeptide chains.}\\)
\\(\\text{Bacteria cannot form the correct human disulfide bridges naturally.}\\)
\\(\\text{Chains are purified and later combined in-vitro.}\\)

\\(\\text{ampR remains intact, so all plasmid-bearing bacteria survive ampicillin.}\\)
\\(\\text{The insulin gene disrupts tetR.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without tetR, bacteria become tetracycline sensitive and will die.}\\)

\\(\\text{Fusion protects insulin from being degraded.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fusion allows easier purification through affinity methods.}\\)

questions.question_text: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is one of the most common inherited disorders in Australia, caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. One of the best-known mutations is F508, where three DNA bases are deleted, removing a phenylalanine from the CFTR protein. Around 70% of CF patients worldwide carry this mutation. A diagnostic lab designs a fluorescent DNA probe that binds only to the F508 mutant sequence. The probe cannot bind if DNA remains double-stranded, because the bases are not exposed for pairing. To make the DNA single-stranded, the sample is first heated. After cooling, the probe is added, and fluorescence indicates the presence of the mutation.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why DNA must be heated before probe addition. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the probe binds only the mutated allele. (1 mark)
c) Explain why probe-based testing is useful in newborn screening. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Heating separates the strands.}\\)
\\(\\text{Exposed bases allow the probe to bind its complementary sequence.}\\)
\\(\\text{The probe sequence matches the mutant allele exactly, by complementary base pairing.}\\)

\\(\\text{It detects mutations quickly using fluorescence.}\\)
\\(\\text{Only small DNA samples are needed.}\\)
\\(\\text{Early detection allows rapid treatment decisions.}\\)

questions.question_text: Drought is one of the biggest threats to global crop production. In Australia alone, dry years can reduce wheat yields by up to 40%. Researchers recently discovered that a gene called DREB2A helps plants respond to drought stress. When activated, this gene triggers protective pathways that reduce water loss. A research team uses CRISPR-Cas9 to edit a wheat variety so its own DREB2A gene is up-regulated, improving drought tolerance.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the crop is not transgenic. (2 marks)
b) Explain why some regulators still classify it as a GMO. (3 marks)
c) State two environmental benefits and one environmental risk of this modification. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{No foreign DNA is inserted.}\\)
\\(\\text{The plant‚Äôs own genome is modified, meaning it is a genetically modified organism}\\)

\\(\\text{CRISPR techniques count as genetic engineering.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some definitions focus on the method, not the outcome.}\\)
\\(\\text{Edited organisms may still pose ecological risks.}\\)

\\(\\text{Benefit: Less water use improves sustainability.}\\)
\\(\\text{Benefit: Higher drought tolerance increases yield stability.}\\)
\\(\\text{Risk: Gene flow may spread altered traits to wild relatives.}\\)

questions.question_text: Researchers studying a hereditary blood disorder caused by a single faulty gene decide to use CRISPR-Cas9 to investigate how different mutations affect the gene‚Äôs function. The disorder is like Œ≤-thalassemia, a real condition caused by mutations in the Œ≤-globin gene, which reduces oxygen-carrying capacity in red blood cells. When Cas9 and the guide RNA are delivered into the cells, the gRNA binds perfectly to the faulty gene, directing Cas9 to the correct location. Once Cas9 cuts both DNA strands, the cell attempts to repair the break, often creating small insertions or deletions that disrupt the gene further. This allows scientists to study how the loss of gene function affects cell behaviour.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the PAM site is needed for Cas9 to cut. (2 marks)
b) Explain how guide RNA directs Cas9 to the target gene. (3 marks)
c) State one outcome after the DNA is cut. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Cas9 only binds to DNA when a PAM sequence is present.}\\)
\\(\\text{PAM helps Cas9 recognise the correct cutting location.}\\)

\\(\\text{Guide RNA has bases complementary to the target DNA.}\\) 
\\(\\text{Complementary binding pulls Cas9 to the exact location.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cas9 then cuts both strands.}\\)

\\(\\text{The cell may repair using NHEJ.}\\)
\\(\\text{NHEJ can create small insertions or deletions.}\\)

questions.question_text: Farmers worldwide lose large portions of their crops to insect pests every year. Before genetic engineering, farms relied heavily on chemical pesticides, which can harm ecosystems and require repeated spraying. Researchers use a bacterial gene from B. thuringiensis that codes for a Bt toxin. When insects eat plant tissue, the toxin becomes activated in their gut and kills them, protecting the crop.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why this plant is transgenic. (2 marks)
b) Explain one potential benefit of this GMO. (2 marks)
c) Explain one potential risk. (2 marks)
d) Explain why GMOs must be regulated. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The plant now contains a bacterial Bt gene that was not originally part of the plant genome.}\\)
\\(\\text{This foreign gene allows the plant to produce the Bt toxin protein, giving it a trait that plants cannot make naturally.}\\)

\\(\\text{The Bt gene allows the plant to kill insect larvae internally, reducing crop loss without needing repeated pesticide sprays.}\\)
\\(\\text{Reduced chemical spraying leads to lower environmental contamination, including less harm to waterways and non-}\\)
\\(\\text{target organisms.}\\)

\\(\\text{Insects exposed to the Bt toxin year after year may evolve resistance through natural selection, making the trait}\\)
\\(\\text{less effective.}\\)
\\(\\text{Resistant insect populations can spread to nearby farms or wild habitats, reducing long-term pest control and altering}\\)
\\(\\text{ecological balance.}\\)

\\(\\text{Gene transfer into wild species (gene flow) could change ecological interactions, such as creating more competitive or}\\)
\\(\\text{invasive plant varieties.}\\)
\\(\\text{Regulators must ensure GMOs are safe for consumers and do not introduce harmful allergens or unintended genetic}\\)
\\(\\text{effects.}\\)

questions.question_text: Scientists often use CRISPR-Cas9 to study how genes work by ‚Äúknocking out‚Äù (disabling) a gene and observing how cells behave without it. A research team is investigating a gene in mouse cells that helps the cells respond to stress. Similar genes have been studied in real biomedical labs, such as p53, a tumour-suppressor gene that protects cells from DNA damage. When p53 is knocked out in mice, cells divide more quickly and become more prone to forming tumours.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how CRISPR causes a gene knockout. (3 marks)
b) Explain why not all cells in the sample show the knockout. (3 marks)
c) State one method to confirm which cells are successfully edited. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Cas9 cuts both DNA strands.}\\)
\\(\\text{The cell repairs the cut using NHEJ.}\\)
\\(\\text{NHEJ introduces insertions or deletions that disrupt the reading frame.}\\)

\\(\\text{Not all cells receive the CRISPR components.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some cuts are repaired without disruptive mutations.}\\)
\\(\\text{Mosaic outcomes occur when edits differ between cells.}\\)

\\(\\text{Sequence the target region.}\\)
\\(\\text{Look for insertions or deletions at the cut site.}\\)

questions.question_text: Insects destroy billions of dollars‚Äô worth of crops each year, and in some regions, farmers rely heavily on chemical sprays to protect yields. To create a similar pest-resistant crop, researchers use Agrobacterium tumefaciens, a natural plant-infecting bacterium. Agrobacterium transfers part of its Ti plasmid into plant cells, and scientists exploit this system to deliver a Bt toxin gene into the crop‚Äôs genome. Plants that successfully integrate the Bt gene can make the toxin inside their leaves, giving them strong resistance to pests.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why only the first modification creates a transgenic GMO. (2 marks)
b) Explain two environmental benefits and two environmental risks of the insect-resistant GMO. (4 marks)
c) Explain why some countries regulate both modifications equally. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{It inserts DNA from another species.}\\)
\\(\\text{The drought edit modifies an existing gene, not adding foreign DNA.}\\)

\\(\\text{Benefit: Lower pesticide use reduces chemical pollution.}\\)
\\(\\text{Benefit: Plants show higher yield under insect pressure.}\\)
\\(\\text{Risk: Insects may evolve resistance.}\\)
\\(\\text{Risk: Resistance traits may spread to wild relatives.}\\)

\\(\\text{Both involve genetic engineering tools.}\\)
\\(\\text{Regulation is based on method, not final gene content.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Climate models predict more frequent heatwaves with low humidity. A farmer grows two grasses: one C3, one C4. After a week of 38¬∞C days and dry winds, the C3 grass shows severe wilting and reduced growth, while the C4 grass remains relatively healthy. Stomatal conductance measurements show that both species close stomata for long periods.

Which statement best explains the different outcomes?

orders.text_content:
A. C4 plants avoid stomatal closure, so they keep taking in CO‚ÇÇ
B. C4 plants use PEP carboxylase and malate to keep CO‚ÇÇ high near Rubisco
C. C3 plants lack Rubisco and rely only on PEP carboxylase
D. C3 plants perform the light-dependent reactions only at night

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. C4 plants make malate using PEP carboxylase, then deliver CO‚ÇÇ to bundle sheath Rubisco, so photorespiration stays}\\)
\\(\\text{low even when stomata close.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A scientist grows a C3 and a CAM plant in identical, mild conditions: 25¬∞C, high humidity, plenty of water and CO‚ÇÇ. Both receive the same light. After several weeks, the C3 plant has much greater biomass than the CAM plant, even though both fix similar total amounts of CO‚ÇÇ each day.

Which option best explains this difference?

orders.text_content:
A. CAM plants lack Rubisco, so they cannot run the Calvin cycle
B. CAM plants waste ATP on creating, storing and moving malate in vacuoles
C. C3 plants do not perform cellular respiration, so they save ATP
D. C3 plants keep stomata closed at night, so they lose less water

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. CAM plants spend extra ATP making malate, storing it in vacuoles and regenerating PEP; this high energy cost}\\)
\\(\\text{leaves less energy for growth.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A CAM plant line is engineered so that malate can no longer be stored in vacuoles, but carbon fixation at night still occurs. The plant is placed in a hot, dry greenhouse and survives only a few days.

Which is the best reason for this rapid failure?

orders.text_content:
A. Malate in the cytosol lowers pH and disrupts cell processes
B. Malate in the cytosol raises pH and activates photorespiration
C. Malate replaces ATP and stops the light-dependent reactions
D. Malate blocks stomata from closing during the day

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{A. Malate must be stored in vacuoles; otherwise, it would change cytosolic pH and disrupt normal metabolism.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A biotech company tests two experimental molecules on C3 leaves: 

Molecule X binds at Rubisco‚Äôs active site, competing with CO‚ÇÇ.
Molecule Y binds to an allosteric site, changing Rubisco‚Äôs shape.

Leaves are then supplied with very high CO‚ÇÇ concentrations.

orders.text_content:
Which result pattern is most likely?

A. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by X and by Y
B. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by X, but not by Y
C. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by Y, but not by X
D. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses neither X nor Y

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. X is a competitive inhibitor, so extra CO‚ÇÇ can outcompete it; Y is non-competitive, so extra substrate does not}\\)
\\(\\text{restore maximum rate.}\\)

\\(\\text{B. X is a competitive inhibitor, so extra CO‚ÇÇ can outcompete it; Y is non-competitive, so extra substrate does not}\\)
\\(\\text{restore maximum rate.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Two plants are tested at low light: a C3 herb and a C4 grass. The light intensity is slowly increased from very dim to moderate. Net gas exchange is measured. The C3 plant reaches its compensation point at a higher light intensity than the C4 plant; it shows net CO‚ÇÇ gain only at brighter light.

Which interpretation best fits these data?

orders.text_content:
A. C3 plants have lower respiration rates than C4 plants
B. C3 plants suffer more from photorespiration at low light and CO‚ÇÇ
C. C4 plants cannot respire in the dark
D. C4 plants have less chlorophyll, so they need more light

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. C3 plants lose carbon to photorespiration and need more photosynthetic output to balance respiration; C4 plants}\\)
\\(\\text{avoid photorespiration and reach net gain earlier.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A farmer applies nitrogen fertiliser to two fields: one planted with C3 wheat and the other with C4 maize. After fertiliser, both crops show darker green leaves, but only the C3 wheat shows a large increase in photosynthetic rate at the same CO‚ÇÇ and light levels.

Which is the most accurate explanation?

orders.text_content:
A. Nitrogen only enters C3 leaves, not C4 leaves
B. More nitrogen increases chlorophyll, boosting light capture; C3 plants benefit more because CO‚ÇÇ was limiting their Rubisco, not already concentrated like in C4
C. C4 plants already use PEP carboxylase and are not limited by chlorophyll
D. Nitrogen stops photorespiration only in C3 plants

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Nitrogen increases chlorophyll and photosynthetic machinery in both, but C4 plants already operate near their}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ-limited maximum; C3 gains more because CO‚ÇÇ and Rubisco activity were stronger limits.}\\)

questions.question_text: A researcher compares leaf cross-sections of a C3 and a C4 grass. The C4 leaf shows Kranz anatomy: tightly packed bundle sheath cells surrounded by rings of mesophyll. Transpiration per unit CO‚ÇÇ fixed is lower in the C4 grass under hot, dry conditions.

orders.text_content:
Which option best explains why Kranz anatomy helps reduce water loss?

A. It allows stomata to stay open longer because more chloroplasts form in epidermal cells
B. It lets C4 plants store water in bundle sheath cells
C. It concentrates CO‚ÇÇ near Rubisco, so stomata do not need to open as often to maintain high internal CO‚ÇÇ
D. It blocks O‚ÇÇ from entering the leaf, preventing transpiration entirely

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Malate delivers CO‚ÇÇ to bundle sheath Rubisco; efficient CO‚ÇÇ capture means stomata can open less often yet}\\)
\\(\\text{maintain photosynthesis.}\\)

questions.question_text: Why do CAM plants convert CO‚ÇÇ into malate at night?

orders.text_content:
A. Malate stores reducing power for PSI
B. Malate releases CO‚ÇÇ for Rubisco during the day when stomata close
C. Malate buffers stromal pH
D. Malate transports ATP between cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. CAM plants convert CO‚ÇÇ into malate at night so it can be stored and later broken down in the day to release CO‚ÇÇ}\\)
\\(\\text{next to Rubisco, allowing photosynthesis while stomata remain closed.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student measures photosynthesis in a C3 plant while steadily increasing light intensity. At low light, the rate rises almost proportionally with light. After a certain point, the curve flattens even though light keeps increasing. CO‚ÇÇ concentration and temperature are recorded as constant, but an exam question asks which
other factor could reasonably be limiting at the plateau.

Which answer is the most correct?

orders.text_content:
A. pH of the soil, because soil pH always limits photosynthesis
B. Light intensity, because it continues to increase
C. Rubisco concentration, because active sites may be saturated by substrate
D. Water availability, because water has no effect on stomata

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{C. ‚ÄúEnzyme active sites saturated by substrate‚Äù is a classic explanation once light has stopped being limiting.}\\)

questions.question_text:
C3 and CAM plants are given identical, constantly high-water supply in a growth chamber, with moderate temperature (25¬∞C) and equal light. Stomatal behaviour is unchanged: C3 opens in the day; CAM opens at night. Both species run through several months.

Which outcome is most likely?

orders.text_content:
A. CAM now outgrows C3, because stomata can be open longer at night
B. C3 outgrows CAM, because CAM still wastes ATP on malate storage and PEP regeneration
C. CAM and C3 show equal growth, because water is no longer limiting
D. CAM stops using malate, so its energy cost disappears

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. CAM keeps its high-cost pathway even when water is plentiful, so it spends more ATP on malate handling}\\)
\\(\\text{and grows less than an energy-efficient C3 in favourable conditions.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A long dry spell reduces soil moisture. CO‚ÇÇ, light and temperature stay similar. Internal measurements show that, in one species, stomatal closure causes a sharp rise in internal O‚ÇÇ and a large drop in CO‚ÇÇ; this plant‚Äôs photosynthetic rate collapses. In another species, internal CO‚ÇÇ near Rubisco remains fairly stable because malate breakdown continues.

Which pair identification fits best?

orders.text_content:
A. First plant = C4, second = C3
B. First plant = CAM, second = C3
C. First plant = C3, second = C4 or CAM
D. First plant = C4, second = CAM

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. C3 is most affected by low water, with stomatal closure causing high O‚ÇÇ and severe photorespiration; C4}\\)
\\(\\text{and CAM maintain CO‚ÇÇ near Rubisco using malate.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Two plants have been genetically modified so that, per day, they produce the same amount of glucose. One uses C3 photosynthesis, the other CAM. Over several months in a perfectly mild, moist greenhouse with no water stress, one plant has clearly more biomass than the other.

Which is the best explanation?

orders.text_content:
A. CAM outgrows C3 because its malate store gives extra carbon at night
B. CAM outgrows C3 because it avoids photorespiration completely
C. C3 outgrows CAM because CAM wastes more ATP on malate creation, storage and transport
D. They must grow equally if glucose production per day is equal

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. CAM has the highest energy expenditure (malate storage, PEP regeneration), so even with equal glucose}\\)
\\(\\text{fixation, less energy is left for growth.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A week-long heatwave with low humidity causes significant wilting in a C3 grass, while a C4 grass growing beside it remains relatively healthy. Measurements show that stomata in both species remain largely closed during the hottest periods.

Which statement best explains the difference in performance?

orders.text_content:
A. C4 plants keep stomata open and maintain continuous CO‚ÇÇ uptake
B. C4 plants use PEP carboxylase to maintain high CO‚ÇÇ concentrations aroundRubisco
C. C3 plants lack Rubisco and rely solely on PEP carboxylase
D. C3 plants conduct the light-dependent reactions only at night

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. C4 plants use PEP carboxylase to fix CO‚ÇÇ into 4-carbon compounds and deliver high CO‚ÇÇ to Rubisco, so they keep}\\)
\\(\\text{photosynthesis high and photorespiration low during heatwaves when stomata are mostly closed.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A C3 plant and a CAM plant are grown under mild, well-watered conditions with identical light levels. After several weeks, the C3 plant has accumulated much more biomass, even though both fixed similar amounts of CO‚ÇÇ per day.

Which option best explains this outcome?

orders.text_content:
A. CAM plants do not contain Rubisco
B. CAM plants invest additional ATP into producing, storing, and converting malate
C. C3 plants do not undergo cellular respiration
D. C3 plants reduce water loss by closing stomata at night

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. CAM plants still need extra ATP to fix CO‚ÇÇ into malate at night, store it and reconvert it by day; under mild, well-}\\)
\\(\\text{watered conditions that extra energy cost makes them grow more slowly than C3 plants.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A genetically modified CAM plant is unable to store malate in vacuoles, although CO‚ÇÇ fixation at night still occurs. When placed in a hot, dry environment, the plant dies within days.

What is the most likely reason?

orders.text_content:
A. Malate accumulates in the cytosol and disrupts cellular pH
B. Malate accumulation activates photorespiration
C. Malate accumulation replaces ATP and prevents ATP synthesis
D. Malate prevents stomata from closing during the day

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. If malate cannot be sequestered in vacuoles, it builds up in the cytosol, disturbing pH and normal enzyme function,}\\)
\\(\\text{which is especially damaging in hot, dry conditions where the CAM pathway is vital for survival.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher applies two experimental molecules to C3 leaves:

Molecule X competes with CO‚ÇÇ for Rubisco‚Äôs active site
Molecule Y binds to an allosteric site on Rubisco and alters its shape

The leaves are then exposed to a very high CO‚ÇÇ concentration.

orders.text_content:
Which result is most likely?

A. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by both X and Y
B. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by X but not Y
C. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses inhibition by Y but not X
D. High CO‚ÇÇ reverses neither X nor Y

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. High CO‚ÇÇ can displace a competitive inhibitor (X) from Rubisco‚Äôs active site, restoring activity, but cannot remove}\\)
\\(\\text{a non-competitive inhibitor (Y) bound at an allosteric site, so inhibition by Y persists.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A C3 herb and a C4 grass are tested at low light intensities. The C3 plant reaches its compensation point at a much higher light intensity.

Which explanation best accounts for this difference?

orders.text_content:
A. C3 plants have lower rates of respiration
B. C3 plants lose more carbon to photorespiration at low CO‚ÇÇ levels
C. C4 plants are unable to respire in the dark
D. C4 plants contain less chlorophyll

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. At low CO‚ÇÇ, C3 plants lose more carbon through photorespiration, so they need higher light (more photosynthesis) to}\\)
\\(\\text{balance respiration, whereas C4 plants avoid most photorespiration and reach net gain at lower light.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A farmer applies nitrogen fertilizer to C3 wheat and C4 maize. Both develop darker leaves, but only wheat shows a substantial increase in photosynthetic rate under the same conditions.

Which explanation is most accurate?

orders.text_content:
A. Nitrogen assimilates only in C3 leaves
B. Wheat benefits more because its photosynthesis is limited by Rubisco activity, whereas maize already concentrates CO‚ÇÇ around Rubisco
C. Maize does not require chlorophyll for carbon fixation
D. Nitrogen fertilizer eliminates photorespiration only in wheat

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Nitrogen improves the photosynthetic machinery in both, but C3 wheat gains more because its Rubisco activity and}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ availability were stronger limits; C4 maize already concentrates CO‚ÇÇ around Rubisco and is less boosted by extra}\\)
\\(\\text{nitrogen.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher compares leaf cross-sections of a C3 and a C4 grass. The C4 grass shows Kranz anatomy and a lower transpiration rate per unit CO‚ÇÇ fixed under hot, dry conditions.

Which explanation best accounts for this?

orders.text_content:
A. C4 plants keep stomata open for longer
B. C4 plants store water inside bundle sheath cells
C. C4 plants maintain high CO‚ÇÇ concentrations around Rubisco, allowing stomata to open less frequently
D. C4 leaves prevent O‚ÇÇ from entering mesophyll tissue

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. In C4 leaves, CO‚ÇÇ is concentrated around Rubisco in bundle sheath cells, so stomata can open less frequently to maintain}\\)
\\(\\text{adequate internal CO‚ÇÇ, which lowers water loss per CO‚ÇÇ fixed compared with C3 leaves.}\\)

questions.question_text: Photosynthetic rate in a C3 leaf increases with rising light intensity until it reaches a plateau, despite further increases in light. Temperature and CO‚ÇÇ concentration remain constant.

orders.text_content:
Which factor is most likely limiting at the plateau?

A. Soil pH
B. Light intensity
C. Rubisco concentration or turnover rate
D. Water availability has no influence on this pattern

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. At the plateau, light, CO‚ÇÇ and temperature are adequate, but the amount or turnover rate of Calvin cycle enzymes,}\\)
\\(\\text{especially Rubisco, limits how fast carbon can be fixed, so more light alone cannot increase the rate.}\\)

questions.question_text: A wheat crop (C3) and a maize crop (C4) are grown side by side during a hot, dry fortnight. Midday measurements show that both species close their stomata for long periods, but wheat shows a much larger drop-in photosynthetic rate and growth.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why stomatal closure causes a strong drop in photosynthesis in the C3 wheat. (3 marks)
b) Explain why the C4 maize maintains a higher photosynthetic rate under the same conditions. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Stomata close to conserve water, so external CO‚ÇÇ cannot enter the leaf.}\\)
\\(\\text{Internal CO‚ÇÇ levels fall while O‚ÇÇ from photosynthesis builds up around Rubisco.}\\)
\\(\\text{Rubisco now binds more O‚ÇÇ, increasing photorespiration and wasting carbon and ATP.}\\)

\\(\\text{Initial carbon fixation occurs in mesophyll cells using PEP carboxylase, not Rubisco.}\\)
\\(\\text{PEP carboxylase has no affinity for oxygen and continues to fix CO‚ÇÇ when stomata are partly closed.}\\)
\\(\\text{Malate delivers concentrated CO‚ÇÇ to bundle sheath cells, so Rubisco sees high CO‚ÇÇ and low O‚ÇÇ.}\\)

questions.question_text: A researcher compares a CAM succulent and a nearby C3 shrub in a semi- desert. Both receive the same light and temperature. The CAM plant grows more slowly, even though it survives drought far better.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the CAM plant is better at surviving prolonged water stress. (3 marks)
b) Explain why the CAM plant usually has poorer growth than the C3 shrub in mild, moist conditions. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{CAM stomata open at night when it is cooler, so less water is lost.}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ is fixed at night into malate and stored in vacuoles, keeping water loss minimal.}\\)
\\(\\text{During the day stomata are closed, but malate supplies CO‚ÇÇ for the Calvin cycle.}\\)

\\(\\text{CAM carries extra energy costs: making malate, storing it in vacuoles and transporting it back out.}\\)
\\(\\text{Breaking down malate and regenerating PEP, both use ATP that could have gone to growth.}\\)
\\(\\text{Stomata only take in CO‚ÇÇ at night, so total daily carbon gain is often lower than in C3.}\\)

questions.question_text: In a controlled experiment, three plants (C3, C4, CAM) are grown under their own optimal temperatures. All receive equal light and water. A student measures Rubisco activity and notes that each plant type has a different temperature optimum.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why Rubisco from C3, C4 and CAM plants has different optimal temperatures. (2 marks)
b) Explain how these different optima help each plant type in its native environment. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Each plant evolved Rubisco suited to its usual climate, with different bond strengths in the enzyme.}\\)
\\(\\text{These structural differences change how quickly Rubisco denatures or loses shape at higher temperatures.}\\)

\\(\\text{C3 Rubisco suits cooler, moist habitats, so high activity occurs at lower temperatures.}\\)
\\(\\text{C4 Rubisco tolerates warmer conditions, working well when mesophyll and bundle sheath cells heat up.}\\)
\\(\\text{CAM Rubisco remains functional at very high daytime temperatures inside succulent tissues.}\\)

questions.question_text: A lab measures the rate of the light-independent reactions in C3 chloroplasts while changing ATP and NADPH supply. CO‚ÇÇ levels are kept constant and optimal.

orders.text_content: a) Describe the roles of ATP and NADPH in the Calvin cycle. (3 marks)
b) Explain what happens to Calvin cycle rate if ATP and NADPH production falls while CO‚ÇÇ stays high. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{ATP provides energy to drive the conversion of PGA into higher-energy intermediates like G3P.}\\)
\\(\\text{NADPH donates hydrogen ions and electrons to reduce carbon compounds in the cycle.}\\)
\\(\\text{Both are unloaded in the stroma, then recycled back as ADP + Pi and NADP‚Å∫ to the thylakoids.}\\)

\\(\\text{The cycle slows because there is not enough energy and reducing power to convert PGA into G3P.}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ may enter, but it cannot be efficiently fixed into glucose, so overall sugar output drops.}\\)

questions.question_text: A C3 plant is grown under rising light intensity. At first, photosynthesis rate rises. Later, the rate plateaus even though light continues to increase and water and CO‚ÇÇ are still adequate.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why photosynthesis increases at low to moderate light intensities. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the rate plateaus at higher light intensities even though light keeps increasing. (2 marks)
c) Explain one risk to the chloroplast if light continues to increase well beyond this plateau. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{More light increases the rate of the light-dependent reactions in thylakoid membranes.}\\)
\\(\\text{This produces more ATP and NADPH, which fuels faster Calvin cycle activity.}\\)

\\(\\text{Enzymes in the Calvin cycle, such as Rubisco, reach their maximum working rate.}\\)
\\(\\text{At that point, further light cannot raise ATP and NADPH use any faster, so sugar output is capped.}\\)

\\(\\text{Excess light can overload chlorophyll and cause photodamage to photosystems.}\\)
\\(\\text{Secondary pigments must dissipate extra energy as heat; if they fail, membranes and proteins may be damaged.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Two C3 plants of the same species are studied:
- one grows in a dense forest under low light
- the other grows in open plains with intense light nearly all day.
Chloroplast counts per cell and pigment levels are measured.

orders.text_content: a) Predict how chloroplast number and pigment levels differ between the forest plant and the plains plant. (3 marks)
b) Explain one advantage and one disadvantage for the plains plant of having fewer chloroplasts. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Advantage: less risk of photodamage, because less light is absorbed by each cell.}\\)
\\(\\text{Disadvantage: in cloudy or low-light periods, it may capture less light and fix less CO‚ÇÇ.}\\)

\\(\\text{The forest plant usually has more chloroplasts and higher total pigment to capture scarce light.}\\)
\\(\\text{The plains plant often has fewer chloroplasts and less pigment per cell to avoid light overload.}\\)
\\(\\text{These differences change how much light each plant absorbs, matching their light environment.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student compares three potted plants (C3, C4, CAM) under gradually decreasing water supply. Stomatal behaviour, internal gas levels and growth are recorded.

orders.text_content: a) Explain, in terms of stomata and internal gases, why C3 plants are the most affected by low water. (3 marks)
b) Explain why C4 and CAM plants can maintain more stable photosynthesis when stomata are closed. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Water stress causes stomata to close, stopping new CO‚ÇÇ from entering the leaf.}\\)
\\(\\text{Existing CO‚ÇÇ is used up while O‚ÇÇ from photosynthesis and respiration builds up around Rubisco.}\\)
\\(\\text{High O‚ÇÇ and low CO‚ÇÇ trigger photorespiration, which wastes carbon and lowers sugar production.}\\)

\\(\\text{Both store carbon as malate, which keeps high CO‚ÇÇ near Rubisco even when stomata shut.}\\)
\\(\\text{C4 moves malate from mesophyll to bundle sheath cells, while CAM stores malate in vacuoles overnight.}\\)
\\(\\text{These mechanisms reduce Rubisco‚Äôs exposure to high O‚ÇÇ, preventing photorespiration for longer.}\\)

questions.question_text: A researcher investigates how pH affects photosynthesis in C3 leaf discs. At the optimal pH, photosynthesis rate is highest. When pH is moved well above this optimum, rate declines even though light and CO‚ÇÇ are unchanged.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why photosynthesis rate is highest near the optimal pH. (2 marks)
b) Explain what happens to these enzymes when pH is raised too far above the optimum. (2 marks)
c) Explain how this change in enzyme activity affects the overall carbon balance of the leaf. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Enzymes of the light-independent reactions have their correct charge and shape at that pH.}\\)
\\(\\text{Rubisco and other enzymes work fastest, so carbon fixation and sugar formation proceed efficiently.}\\)

\\(\\text{Changes in hydrogen ion concentration alter ionic and hydrogen bonds holding the enzyme shape.}\\)
\\(\\text{Enzymes partly unfold or denature, causing active sites to lose their precise shape and activity.}\\)

\\(\\text{Slower Calvin cycle means less CO‚ÇÇ is fixed into sugars per unit time.}\\)
\\(\\text{Respiration may continue at a higher relative rate, so net carbon gain and biomass formation decline.}\\)

questions.question_text: A C3 leaf is supplied with high CO‚ÇÇ and normal O‚ÇÇ. Then the CO‚ÇÇ supply is reduced while O‚ÇÇ remains the same. Rubisco activity is measured in both conditions.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how high CO‚ÇÇ reduces the risk of photorespiration in a C3 leaf. (2 marks)
b) Explain what happens to Rubisco activity and sugar output when CO‚ÇÇ falls and O‚ÇÇ stays high. (3 marks)
c) Explain how increasing CO‚ÇÇ concentration can overcome competitive inhibition of Rubisco by O‚ÇÇ. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{When CO‚ÇÇ concentration around Rubisco is high, Rubisco is more likely to bind CO‚ÇÇ than O‚ÇÇ.}\\)
\\(\\text{This favours the normal Calvin cycle over the oxygenation reaction that starts photorespiration.}\\)

\\(\\text{With less CO‚ÇÇ, Rubisco more often binds O‚ÇÇ at its active site.}\\)
\\(\\text{This starts photorespiration, which uses O‚ÇÇ and releases CO‚ÇÇ instead of making sugar.}\\)
\\(\\text{Overall glucose production falls because more ATP and carbon are wasted in this side pathway.}\\)

\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ and O‚ÇÇ compete for the same active site, so raising CO‚ÇÇ increases the chance CO‚ÇÇ binds first.}\\)
\\(\\text{At very high CO‚ÇÇ, Rubisco approaches its maximum carboxylation rate and photorespiration is greatly reduced.}\\)

questions.question_text: A new molecule Z binds to an allosteric site on Rubisco in C3 plants. When Z is present, photosynthesis rate falls and cannot be restored even by very high CO‚ÇÇ levels.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why molecule Z is described as a non-competitive inhibitor of Rubisco. (2 marks)
b) Explain why increasing CO‚ÇÇ concentration does not restore the original photosynthetic rate. (2 marks)
c) Suggest one possible effect of long-term exposure to molecule Z on plant growth. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Z binds to a site away from the active site where CO‚ÇÇ normally binds.}\\)
\\(\\text{Binding of Z changes Rubisco‚Äôs shape so the active site no longer functions properly.}\\)

\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ and Z are not competing for the same active site, so more CO‚ÇÇ cannot displace Z.}\\)
\\(\\text{Even at high CO‚ÇÇ, many Rubisco molecules remain distorted and cannot reach maximum activity.}\\)

\\(\\text{Chronic inhibition of Rubisco reduces carbon fixation and lowers glucose production.}\\)
\\(\\text{With less sugar for respiration and biosynthesis, the plant shows reduced growth and yield over time.}\\)

questions.question_text: A leaf cell is placed in bright light with plenty of water and CO‚ÇÇ. After a while, a chemical is added that blocks ATP synthase in the thylakoid membrane.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how the light-dependent reactions normally support the Calvin cycle. (3 marks)
b) Explain what happens to the Calvin cycle once ATP synthase is blocked. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Light-dependent reactions generate ATP in the thylakoid membranes.}\\)
\\(\\text{They also reduce NADP‚Å∫ to NADPH using excited electrons.}\\)
\\(\\text{ATP and NADPH then move into the stroma to power the Calvin cycle reactions.}\\)

\\(\\text{ATP production in the light-dependent stage drops sharply.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without enough ATP, the Calvin cycle cannot convert PGA into higher-energy sugars.}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ may still enter, but sugar output falls because the cycle slows or stalls.}\\)

questions.question_text: A C3 wheat crop and a C4 maize crop grow in the same hot, dry paddock. Around midday, both close stomata to reduce water loss. Later, gas exchange measurements show a stronger fall in net photosynthesis in wheat than in maize.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why C3 photosynthesis drops more when stomata close. (3 marks)
b) Explain how C4 maize maintains higher photosynthesis under the same conditions. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{When stomata close, CO‚ÇÇ inside C3 leaves falls and O‚ÇÇ builds up.}\\)
\\(\\text{Rubisco then binds more O‚ÇÇ instead of CO‚ÇÇ.}\\)
\\(\\text{Photorespiration increases, wasting ATP and fixed carbon and lowering net photosynthesis.}\\)

\\(\\text{Maize first fixes CO‚ÇÇ into a 4-carbon compound using PEP carboxylase in mesophyll cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{PEP carboxylase does not bind O‚ÇÇ, so it still captures CO‚ÇÇ when stomata are partly closed.}\\)
\\(\\text{4-carbon compounds deliver concentrated CO‚ÇÇ to bundle sheath cells, keeping Rubisco carboxylation high.}\\)

questions.question_text: A CAM plant is studied in a desert greenhouse. Gas probes show net CO‚ÇÇ uptake at night and net CO‚ÇÇ release during the day, even though photosynthesis is happening in the light.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the CAM plant takes up CO‚ÇÇ mainly at night. (3 marks)
b) Explain why CO‚ÇÇ may be released from the plant during the day even while photosynthesis is active. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Night air is cooler and more humid, so opening stomata loses less water.}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ enters and is fixed into an organic acid such as malate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Malate is stored in vacuoles, holding carbon until daytime.}\\)

\\(\\text{During the day, malate is moved from vacuoles and broken down in the cytosol or chloroplast.}\\)
\\(\\text{This breakdown releases CO‚ÇÇ inside the leaf near Rubisco.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some of this CO‚ÇÇ diffuses out again, so gas probes detect net CO‚ÇÇ release while the Calvin cycle is also fixing CO‚ÇÇ.}\\)

questions.question_text: A C3 plant is grown in a lab chamber. At first, light intensity is very low and CO‚ÇÇ is moderate. Later, light is increased to a high level, and finally CO‚ÇÇ is raised while light stays high. Temperature is kept constant.

orders.text_content: a) Identify the main limiting factor at very low light and explain your answer. (2 marks)
b) Once light is high but CO‚ÇÇ is still moderate, explain why photosynthesis rate plateaus. (3 marks)
c) Explain why raising CO‚ÇÇ can increase photosynthesis again after the plateau. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Light intensity is limiting at low light.}\\)
\\(\\text{Low light means few photons reach chlorophyll, so little ATP and NADPH are made for the Calvin cycle.}\\)

\\(\\text{At high light, the light-dependent stage supplies plenty of ATP and NADPH.}\\)
\\(\\text{Enzymes in the Calvin cycle, such as Rubisco, are working at or near maximum rate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Further increases in light cannot raise the rate because CO‚ÇÇ supply and enzyme capacity now limit photosynthesis.}\\)

\\(\\text{Extra CO‚ÇÇ increases the chance that Rubisco binds CO‚ÇÇ instead of O‚ÇÇ.}\\)
\\(\\text{More carboxylation events occur, so the Calvin cycle fixes more carbon per unit time.}\\)

questions.question_text: A leaf cell is examined with an electron microscope. The chloroplasts show many stacked grana connected by lamellae, and a large volume of stroma surrounding them.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how the grana structure supports the light-dependent reactions. (3 marks)
b) Explain how the stroma supports the light-independent reactions. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Grana provides a large surface area of thylakoid membrane.}\\)
\\(\\text{This allows many photosystems and electron transport chains to be packed into the chloroplast.}\\)
\\(\\text{More membrane means more ATP and NADPH can be produced per unit time under strong light.}\\)

\\(\\text{The stroma contains Rubisco and other enzymes of the Calvin cycle.}\\)
\\(\\text{ATP and NADPH from the thylakoids diffuse into the stroma to drive carbon fixation.}\\)
\\(\\text{CO‚ÇÇ dissolves in the stroma fluid, where it is attached to RuBP and converted into sugars.}\\)

questions.question_text:
For many years, science and associated textbooks reported that one glucose molecule yields 36‚Äì38 ATP via aerobic respiration. Newer data from human cells show that the real yield is closer to 30‚Äì32 ATP.
Which statement best explains why the updated value is lower?

orders.text_content:
A. Glycolysis no longer produces ATP in human cells
B. Krebs cycle does not produce NADH in human cells
C. Some energy is lost when electrons are transferred into mitochondria and when ATP is moved to the cytosol
D. Oxygen is no longer the final electron acceptor, so less ATP forms

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Real cells lose some energy moving electrons from cytosolic NADH into mitochondria and exporting ATP to}\\)
\\(\\text{the cytosol. Proton leak across the inner membrane also wastes some of the gradient, so fewer ATP are formed}\\)
\\(\\text{than the ideal 36‚Äì38.}\\)

questions.question_text: Most ATP made during aerobic respiration in a eukaryotic cell is produced in which location?

orders.text_content:
A. Cytosol during glycolysis
B. Mitochondrial matrix during the Krebs cycle
C. Inner mitochondrial membrane during oxidative phosphorylation
D. Nucleus during DNA replication

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Although glycolysis and the Krebs cycle make a small amount of ATP, the majority comes from oxidative phosphorylation}\\)
\\(\\text{when ATP synthase uses the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This membrane (with its cristae)}\\)
\\(\\text{is where the electron transport chain and ATP synthase are located.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A toxin prevents pyruvate from entering the mitochondria but does not affect reactions in the cytosol. Glucose availability and oxygen remain high. Glycolysis still occurs in the cytosol and produces its normal outputs. 

Which outcome is most likely in these cells?

orders.text_content:
A. Glycolysis stops because pyruvate must enter the matrix for ATP to form
B. Glycolysis continues, but Krebs cycle and electron transport chain both stop
C. Krebs cycle continues normally, but electron transport stops
D. Glycolysis, Krebs cycle and electron transport all continues at normal rates

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The toxin blocks pyruvate entry into mitochondria, so acetyl CoA cannot form. Glycolysis in the cytosol continues, but the}\\)
\\(\\text{Krebs cycle and electron transport chain both stop.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher bubbles nitrogen gas through a muscle cell suspension to remove most dissolved oxygen. Mitochondria are intact and their protein complexes are functional. Glucose is present. After a short time, Krebs cycle and electron transport stop completely, though glycolysis continues.

Which statement best explains why the mitochondrial stages stop?

orders.text_content:
A. Without oxygen, ATP synthase is blocked by extra H‚Å∫ ions in the matrix
B. Without oxygen, NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ cannot unload electrons, so coenzymes are no longer regenerated
C. Without oxygen, pyruvate cannot be made in the cytosol
D. Without oxygen, acetyl CoA cannot be formed from pyruvate

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Without oxygen, the electron transport chain cannot accept electrons from NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ. These coenzymes stay}\\)
\\(\\text{reduced, NAD‚Å∫ and FAD run out, and the Krebs cycle and ETC stop while glycolysis can still run.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In a patient, several protein complexes in the mitochondrial cristae are damaged, so electrons cannot pass along the electron transport chain. Oxygen levels in the blood are normal, and Krebs cycle enzymes are still active.

Which pattern of events is most likely in the patient‚Äôs mitochondria?

orders.text_content:
A. Krebs cycle and electron transport both stop immediately because oxygen is absent
B. Krebs cycle continues for a time, but NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ accumulate in the matrix
C. Electron transport continues, but ATP production stops
D. All stages of aerobic respiration speed up to compensate for the damage

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Damaged complexes prevent normal electron flow, so NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ made by the Krebs cycle cannot unload}\\)
\\(\\text{electrons. They accumulate in the matrix and the supply of NAD‚Å∫ and FAD falls, slowing and then stopping the Krebs}\\)
\\(\\text{cycle.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student investigates glycolysis in isolated cytosol. They provide abundant glucose and NAD‚Å∫ but remove mitochondria from the preparation. No oxygen is added. Glycolysis proceeds to completion for several minutes.

Which result is most consistent with this setup?

orders.text_content:
A. 2 ATP and 2 NADH are produced per glucose, and no further ATP is obtained from mitochondria
B. 30‚Äì32 ATP are produced per glucose, because oxygen is not required
C. No ATP is formed because mitochondria are essential for glycolysis
D. Only NADH forms; ATP production requires electron transport

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Glycolysis does not need mitochondria or oxygen, so it still converts glucose to pyruvate, giving 2 ATP and 2 NADH}\\)
\\(\\text{per glucose. With no mitochondria, there is no Krebs cycle or ETC, so no extra ATP is produced.}\\)

questions.question_text: A graph shows rate of aerobic respiration against oxygen concentration. The curve rises then levels off at a plateau.

orders.text_content:
Which explanation best describes the plateau?

A. Oxygen becomes toxic and stops all enzyme activity
B. All enzymes involved are working at maximum rate, so oxygen is no longer limiting
C. Glucose supply increases and slows respiration
D. Anaerobic respiration completely replaces aerobic respiration

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. As oxygen concentration increases, aerobic respiration speeds up until the enzymes of the pathway, including the}\\)
\\(\\text{electron transport chain, are saturated and working at their maximum rate. Beyond this point, adding more oxygen}\\)
\\(\\text{cannot raise the rate further, so the graph plateaus.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A yeast culture is grown in a sealed bioreactor. Researchers can adjust glucose and oxygen levels independently. They want to increase both aerobic respiration and anaerobic fermentation rates at the same time.

Which change will reliably increase energy production from both pathways?

orders.text_content:
A. Increase glucose concentration in the medium
B. Increase oxygen concentration, keep glucose constant
C. Decrease glucose, increase oxygen
D. Decrease both glucose and oxygen

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Both aerobic respiration and fermentation start with glycolysis. Raising glucose concentration increases glycolytic rate,}\\)
\\(\\text{feeding more substrate into both pathways at once.}\\)

questions.question_text: The graph below shows ATP production in a plant cell under rising oxygen concentration, while glucose and temperature are kept constant. At very low oxygen, anaerobic respiration dominates. As oxygen increases, aerobic respiration progressively replaces anaerobic respiration. Eventually, total ATP production plateaus.

orders.text_content:
A. Oxygen becomes toxic and blocks all enzymes
B. Enzymes involved in aerobic respiration become saturated, so more oxygen cannot increase rate
C. Glucose concentration rises and becomes inhibitory
D. ATP synthase stops rotating when oxygen is high

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. As oxygen rises, aerobic respiration replaces anaerobic pathways and ATP output increases. Once the mitochondrial}\\)
\\(\\text{enzymes are working at maximum rate, they become saturated, so extra oxygen cannot raise ATP production further and}\\)
\\(\\text{the curve plateaus.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Three bacterial strains are grown at different oxygen concentrations:
Strain X shows high, constant growth at all oxygen levels
Strain Y grows only at high oxygen levels, with little or no growth in anoxic conditions
Strain Z grows best at very low oxygen, but growth falls sharply as oxygen increases

orders.text_content:
Which assignment is most appropriate?

A. X = obligate aerobe, Y = facultative anaerobe, Z = obligate anaerobe
B. X = facultative anaerobe, Y = obligate aerobe, Z = obligate anaerobe
C. X = obligate anaerobe, Y = obligate aerobe, Z = facultative anaerobe
D. X = facultative anaerobe, Y = obligate anaerobe, Z = obligate aerobe

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Strain X grows well with or without oxygen, so it is a facultative anaerobe. Strain Y needs high oxygen, so it is an}\\)
\\(\\text{obligate aerobe, and strain Z is harmed by oxygen and grows best when oxygen is very low, so it is an obligate anaerobe.}\\)

questions.question_text:
During anaerobic respiration in human muscle cells, pyruvate is converted to lactate.
Why must this step occur?

orders.text_content:
A. To increase the number of ATP produced per glucose
B. To regenerate NAD‚Å∫ so glycolysis can continue
C. To move pyruvate into the mitochondria
D. To produce carbon dioxide for photosynthesis

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. When oxygen is low, the electron transport chain cannot accept electrons from NADH. Converting pyruvate}\\)
\\(\\text{to lactate transfers electrons back to pyruvate, regenerating NAD‚Å∫. This allows glycolysis to keep running and produce}\\)
\\(\\text{a small but vital supply of ATP.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Red blood cells transport oxygen through the bloodstream but do not contain mitochondria. They rely solely on anaerobic respiration in the cytosol for ATP.
What is the main advantage of this arrangement?

orders.text_content:
A. red blood cells maximise ATP yield by using only fermentation
B. Red blood cells avoid using the oxygen they are meant to deliver to body tissues
C. Red blood cells can generate more ethanol for energy
D. Red blood cells avoid producing any waste products

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Red blood cells lack mitochondria and rely on glycolysis and lactic fermentation for ATP. Because they do not}\\)
\\(\\text{use oxidative phosphorylation, they do not consume the oxygen they carry and can deliver it to other tissues.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Note: This niche knowledge was once tested, several years ago in a VCE exam, catching MANY students off-guard.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A culture of muscle cells is deprived of oxygen, but glucose is supplied. Glycolysis continues, generating pyruvate, ATP and NADH. No mitochondria are active. After some time, the ATP yield suddenly falls to almost zero, and the cells die.
Which statement best explains this sudden failure?

orders.text_content:
A. All available ADP has been used up
B. NAD‚Å∫ becomes depleted because fermentation does not regenerate it
C. Pyruvate cannot be formed without oxygen
D. Glycolysis stops because glucose is no longer needed

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. With no oxygen and no active mitochondria, NADH cannot pass electrons to the electron transport chain. If}\\)
\\(\\text{fermentation does not regenerate NAD‚Å∫ fast enough, NAD‚Å∫ is depleted, glycolysis stops, and ATP production collapses.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A sprinter completes a 400 m race at maximum effort. During the last 100 m, their leg muscles switch heavily to anaerobic respiration. After the race, the athlete experiences burning and fatigue in those muscles.

Which process best accounts for these symptoms?

orders.text_content:
A. Ethanol accumulation in muscle cells lowers pH and denatures enzymes
B. Lactic acid accumulation changes pH and slows enzyme-controlled reactions
C. Excess oxygen in muscles damages mitochondrial cristae
D. ATP production rises too high and inhibits glycolytic enzymes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. During the final part of the race, muscles rely heavily on anaerobic glycolysis, converting pyruvate to lactate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Lactate and H‚Å∫ lower pH in the muscle, slowing enzymes and causing the burning and fatigue.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In aerobic respiration, oxygen is essential for the electron transport chain to keep running.
What is the main role of oxygen here?

orders.text_content:
A. It donates electrons to NAD‚Å∫ and FAD
B. It acts as the final electron and proton acceptor to form water
