C. It pumps hydrogen ions into the intermembrane space
D. It breaks glucose into pyruvate

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. At the end of the electron transport chain, oxygen accepts electrons and combines with hydrogen ions to}\\)
\\(\\text{form water. This removal of electrons keeps the chain flowing and allows NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ to unload and be recycled.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Both plant and animal cells are placed in sealed containers with no oxygen. After some time, gas and metabolite analysis is performed. In both containers, glycolysis continues and 2 ATP per glucose are produced. However, the end products differ.

Which pair of end products is most likely?

orders.text_content:
A. Plants: lactic acid; animals: ethanol + CO‚ÇÇ
B. Plants: ethanol + CO‚ÇÇ; animals: lactic acid
C. Plants: only CO‚ÇÇ; animals: oxygen + lactic acid
D. Plants: ethanol only; animals: CO‚ÇÇ only

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In anaerobic conditions, plants (and yeast) carry out alcohol fermentation, producing ethanol and CO‚ÇÇ. Animal muscle}\\)
\\(\\text{cells perform lactic acid fermentation, producing lactate without extra CO‚ÇÇ.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A teacher demonstrates the effect of temperature on cellular respiration using yeast. At low temperature, CO‚ÇÇ production is very slow. As temperature rises, CO‚ÇÇ production increases until it reaches a clear maximum. If temperature is raised further, CO‚ÇÇ production drops sharply and does not recover.

Which explanation best describes what happens at temperatures beyond the optimum?

orders.text_content:
A. Enzymes gain kinetic energy and collide more, so respiration rate stays high
B. Enzymes denature, so their active sites change and substrates can no longer bind effectively
C. Oxygen is produced instead of CO‚ÇÇ, which is harder to detect
D. Glucose molecules freeze and cannot be used

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Above the optimum temperature, respiratory enzymes lose their precise shape as bonds in the protein break. The active}\\)
\\(\\text{sites no longer fit the substrates, so respiration rate falls sharply and does not recover.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Cellular respiration in a human liver cell converts glucose and oxygen into carbon dioxide, water and ATP.
Which balanced equation best represents this process?

orders.text_content:
A. C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ ‚Üí 2C‚ÇÉH‚ÇÜO‚ÇÉ + 2 ATP
B. C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ + 6O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 6CO‚ÇÇ + 6H‚ÇÇO + 30‚Äì32 ATP
C. 6CO‚ÇÇ + 6H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ + 6O‚ÇÇ
D. C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí CO‚ÇÇ + H‚ÇÇO + 2 ATP

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{B. Note that the ATP values are sometimes not included in the overall equation. Always select the most appropriate answer.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A biofuel company ferments plant biomass to produce ethanol. Crops are ground, treated with enzymes to release glucose, then fed to yeast in low-oxygen tanks. The yeast convert glucose into ethanol and carbon dioxide in their cytosol.
Which statement correctly links this industrial process to cellular respiration?

orders.text_content:
A. Yeast is performing the Krebs cycle to convert glucose into ethanol
B. Yeast are carrying out anaerobic respiration, using glycolysis followed by alcohol fermentation
C. Yeast are using aerobic respiration, because CO‚ÇÇ is released
D. Ethanol is produced in mitochondria during the electron transport chain

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In the low-oxygen tanks, yeast use glycolysis in the cytosol followed by alcohol fermentation. Pyruvate is converted to}\\)
\\(\\text{ethanol and CO‚ÇÇ, regenerating NAD‚Å∫ so glycolysis and ATP production can continue anaerobically.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student compares energy yields from different pathways using one glucose molecule:

Aerobic respiration: glycolysis ‚Üí Krebs cycle ‚Üí electron transport chain
Anaerobic respiration: glycolysis ‚Üí fermentation

They want to explain why aerobic respiration is considered more efficient.

Which explanation is most accurate?

orders.text_content:
A. Aerobic respiration is faster because it has more steps
B. Aerobic respiration produces about 30‚Äì32 ATP, while anaerobic pathways produce only 2 ATP per glucose
C. Anaerobic respiration makes more ATP, but it is all lost as heat
D. Anaerobic respiration uses no enzymes, so it cannot be regulated

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Aerobic respiration fully oxidises glucose through glycolysis, the Krebs cycle and the ETC, giving about 30‚Äì32 ATP per}\\)
\\(\\text{molecule. Anaerobic pathways stop after glycolysis, so each glucose yields only 2 ATP, making them much less efficient.}\\)

questions.question_text: During a 200 m sprint, a sprinter‚Äôs leg muscles quickly use oxygen faster than it can be delivered. The cells shift from mainly aerobic respiration to a high rate of anaerobic respiration, then return to aerobic pathways during recovery.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why anaerobic respiration produces far less ATP per glucose than aerobic respiration. (3 marks)
b) Explain why lactic acid forms in these muscle cells during intense exercise. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Anaerobic respiration uses only glycolysis to make ATP.}\\)
\\(\\text{Electrons carried by NADH are not passed through the electron transport chain.}\\)
\\(\\text{No oxidative step occurs, with no involvement of ATP synthase so only 2 ATP per glucose are made instead of}\\)
\\(\\text{about 30‚Äì32.}\\)

\\(\\text{Glycolysis converts NAD‚Å∫ to NADH while making ATP and pyruvate.}\\)
\\(\\text{When oxygen is low, NADH cannot pass electrons to the electron transport chain.}\\)
\\(\\text{Pyruvate accepts electrons from NADH to form lactate, regenerating NAD‚Å∫ so glycolysis can continue.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Two groups of cells are examined under an electron microscope.
Group A has mitochondria with many long, densely folded cristae.
Group B has mitochondria with few, short cristae.
Both groups receive equal glucose and oxygen.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why Group A is likely to produce more ATP per unit time than Group B. (3 marks)
b) Explain how damage that reduces cristae surface area would affect electron transport and oxidative phosphorylation. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Cristae increase the inner membrane surface area.}\\)
\\(\\text{More surface area allows more electron transport chain proteins and ATP synthase complexes to be present.}\\)
\\(\\text{This supports a higher rate of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP production.}\\)

\\(\\text{Fewer electron transport chain complexes reduce the rate at which electrons can flow from NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ to oxygen.}\\)
\\(\\text{The proton gradient across the inner membrane becomes weaker.}\\)
\\(\\text{ATP synthase produces less ATP because less proton flow is available to drive its rotation.}\\)

questions.question_text: Cyanide, a highly toxic compound, binds strongly to ‚ÄòComplex IV‚Äô (cytochrome coxidase) in the mitochondrial inner membrane. This prevents oxygen from accepting electrons at the end of the electron transport chain. This proceed often leads to death as the body cannot keep up with ATP demands.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how cyanide affects the electron transport chain. (3 marks)
b) Explain why Krebs cycle activity falls soon after cyanide exposure, even if glucose and oxygen are present. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Complex IV can no longer pass electrons to oxygen.}\\)
\\(\\text{Electron flow through the chain stops because carriers before Complex IV remain reduced.}\\)
\\(\\text{The proton pumping that depends on electron flow is greatly reduced or stops.}\\)

\\(\\text{NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ cannot unload electrons to the blocked electron transport chain.}\\)
\\(\\text{These reduced coenzymes accumulate in the matrix, and the pool of NAD‚Å∫ and FAD becomes limited.}\\)
\\(\\text{Krebs cycle reactions slow or stop because they require NAD‚Å∫ and FAD as oxidised coenzymes.}\\)

questions.question_text: Brown adipose tissue (category of fat tissue) in infants and some mammals contains specialised mitochondria. These mitochondria have ‚Äúuncoupling proteins‚Äù in the inner membrane that allow protons to leak back into the matrix without passing through ATP synthase.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how these uncoupling proteins change the effect of the proton gradient. (3 marks)
b) Explain why this adaptation is useful in newborn mammals or hibernating animals. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Protons pumped into the intermembrane space can move back into the matrix through uncoupling channels.}\\)
\\(\\text{This bypasses ATP synthase, so less proton flow passes through ATP synthase to make ATP.}\\)
\\(\\text{The energy from the gradient is released as heat instead of being captured in ATP.}\\)

\\(\\text{Extra heat production helps maintain body temperature when shivering is limited or risky.}\\)
\\(\\text{It provides non-shivering thermogenesis to keep vital organs at a safe temperature in cold environments.}\\)

questions.question_text: A researcher studies a cell line with a mutation that blocks the enzyme converting pyruvate to acetyl CoA in the mitochondrial matrix. Glycolysis is normal and oxygen is available.

orders.text_content: a) Explain what happens to pyruvate and ATP production in these cells. (3 marks)
b) Explain how cells might temporarily survive this mutation by switching to an alternative pathway. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Pyruvate accumulates because it cannot be converted into acetyl CoA.}\\)
\\(\\text{Krebs cycle cannot proceed, so no further ATP is made through substrate-level phosphorylation in the matrix.}\\)
\\(\\text{Total ATP yield per glucose is limited to the 2 ATP produced by glycolysis.}\\)

\\(\\text{Cells can convert pyruvate into lactate or another fermentation product.}\\)
\\(\\text{This process regenerates NAD‚Å∫ from NADH so glycolysis can continue.}\\)
\\(\\text{Glycolysis then supplies small amounts of ATP even without a functional link reaction or Krebs cycle.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Note: Understand the importance of co-enzyme cycling for cellular respiration to continue as an ongoing process.}\\)

questions.question_text: Endurance training (e.g. long-distance running) causes changes in skeletal muscle cells. After several months, muscle fibres show more mitochondria and increased levels of enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how mitochondria having more improves aerobic capacity in these muscle cells. (3 marks)
b) Explain how these changes affect lactic acid production during prolonged exercise. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{More mitochondria mean a greater total inner membrane surface area.}\\)
\\(\\text{This allows higher rates of Krebs cycle activity and electron transport for any given glucose supply.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cells can produce more ATP aerobically, delaying the need to rely on anaerobic respiration.}\\)

\\(\\text{With increased aerobic ATP production, cells can meet energy demands without switching early to anaerobic pathways.}\\)
\\(\\text{Less reliance on anaerobic respiration reduces lactate production and delays muscle fatigue.}\\)

questions.question_text: Yeast cells are used to investigate how temperature affects respiration. At low temperatures, CO‚ÇÇ production is slow; at an intermediate temperature it is much higher; at very high temperatures, CO‚ÇÇ production quickly drops and cannot recover.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why respiration rate is low at very low temperatures. (2 marks)
b) Explain why respiration rate falls sharply at very high temperatures. (2 marks)
c) Explain why the yeast do not recover their original respiration rate when cooled back to the optimum after being held at very high temperature. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Enzymes and substrates have low kinetic energy at low temperatures.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fewer effective collisions occur between enzymes and substrates, so reaction rates are slow.}\\)

\\(\\text{High temperatures disrupt bonds that maintain enzyme structure.}\\)
\\(\\text{Enzymes denature, changing the active site so substrates no longer bind properly.}\\)

\\(\\text{Denaturation is often irreversible once key bonds and structures are lost.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cooling does not restore the original active site shape, so catalytic activity remains low.}\\)

questions.question_text: Two students argue about ATP yield from one glucose molecule. Student 1 says, ‚ÄúAerobic respiration always gives exactly 38 ATP per glucose.‚Äù Student 2 says, ‚ÄúActual yield is often lower in real cells.‚Äù

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the theoretical yield is sometimes given as 36‚Äì38 ATP per glucose. (2 marks)
b) Explain two reasons why actual ATP yield in a cell is often lower than this theoretical value. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Adding ATP from glycolysis, Krebs cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation gives a theoretical maximum.}\\)
\\(\\text{Ideal calculations assume no losses in transferring electrons and ATP within the cell.}\\)

\\(\\text{Some energy is used to transport ADP, ATP and phosphate across mitochondrial membranes.}\\)
\\(\\text{Electrons from cytosolic NADH may enter the electron transport chain at different points, altering ATP yield.}\\)
\\(\\text{Proton leaks across the inner membrane reduce the efficiency of the proton gradient in driving ATP synthase.}\\)

questions.question_text: A medical student is asked to summarise aerobic cellular respiration in a human muscle cell at rest. They know that one glucose molecule is fully broken down to carbon dioxide and water, and that about 30‚Äì32 ATP molecules are produced.

orders.text_content: a) Write the overall balanced equation for aerobic cellular respiration in a human cell, including ATP. (2 marks)
b) Explain why oxygen is essential for the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain to keep running. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ + 6O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí 6CO‚ÇÇ + 6H‚ÇÇO + 30‚Äì32 ATP}\\)

\\(\\text{Oxygen acts as the final electron and proton acceptor in the electron transport chain, forming water.}\\)
\\(\\text{This allows NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ to unload electrons and be recycled back to NAD‚Å∫ and FAD.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without oxygen, NADH and FADH‚ÇÇ build up, so the supply of oxidised coenzymes falls and both the Krebs cycle and}\\)
\\(\\text{electron transport chain stop.}\\)

questions.question_text: During a flood, plant roots become waterlogged and soil oxygen drops almost to zero. At the same time, a sprinter finishes a 400 m race, and their leg muscles also experience low oxygen. Both plant roots and muscle cells continue making small amounts of ATP.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why fermentation must occur in both plant root cells and human muscle cells when oxygen is very low. (2 marks)
b) Describe the different end products in waterlogged plant roots and in human muscle cells and explain why each is a problem if it accumulates. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Glycolysis converts NAD‚Å∫ to NADH while producing ATP and pyruvate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fermentation reactions regenerate NAD‚Å∫ from NADH so glycolysis can continue to produce ATP.}\\)

\\(\\text{In plant roots, pyruvate is converted to ethanol and carbon dioxide in the cytosol.}\\)
\\(\\text{Ethanol is toxic to plant cells at high concentrations and can kill the tissue if anaerobic respiration continues for long.}\\)
\\(\\text{In human muscle cells, pyruvate is converted to lactic acid, which lowers pH and can begin to denature enzymes or}\\)
\\(\\text{slow cellular processes if it builds up.}\\)

questions.question_text: A class measures carbon dioxide production by yeast at different temperatures. At 10¬∞C, CO‚ÇÇ production is low. It rises and reaches a maximum at 35¬∞C. At 60¬∞C, CO‚ÇÇ production drops to near zero and does not recover when the yeast is cooled.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why respiration rate is low at 10¬∞C. (2 marks)
b) Explain why respiration rate drops at 60¬∞C and does not return to normal when cooled. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{At 10¬∞C, enzymes and substrates have low kinetic energy.}\\)
\\(\\text{There are fewer effective collisions between respiratory enzymes and their substrates, so reaction rate is low.}\\)

\\(\\text{High temperature breaks bonds that maintain the enzymes‚Äô specific three-dimensional shape.}\\)
\\(\\text{The active sites change shape, so substrates no longer fit and reaction rate falls sharply.}\\)
\\(\\text{This denaturation is often irreversible, so cooling does not restore the original shape and respiration stays low.}\\)

questions.question_text: A potted plant is placed in a sealed container that contains glucose solution in the soil but no oxygen in the air. After several hours, sensors in the container detect that carbon dioxide has built up, even though aerobic respiration cannot occur.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how the plant cells can still produce carbon dioxide when no oxygen is present. (2 marks)
b) State how many ATP molecules are produced per glucose under these anaerobic conditions, and where this ATP is made. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{In the absence of oxygen, plant cells switch to anaerobic respiration using alcohol fermentation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Glucose is converted to ethanol and carbon dioxide in the cytosol, so CO‚ÇÇ is still released.}\\)

\\(\\text{Only 2 ATP are produced per glucose molecule during anaerobic respiration.}\\)
\\(\\text{This ATP is made during glycolysis in the cytosol, before pyruvate is fermented to ethanol.}\\)

questions.question_text: A biofuel company produces ethanol from maize. The maize plants are grown and harvested, then processed in a factory. Large tanks containing yeast are kept at low oxygen levels so that the yeast can convert the sugars into ethanol, which is later blended with petrol.

orders.text_content: a) Outline the main steps that turn the maize crop into ethanol using yeast. (4 marks)
b) Explain why this ethanol is often described as ‚Äúcarbon neutral‚Äù. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Maize crops are grown and harvested to provide biomass containing complex carbohydrates.}\\)
\\(\\text{The biomass is physically and chemically broken down, and enzymes are used to release glucose subunits.}\\)
\\(\\text{Glucose is supplied to yeast cells kept in low oxygen so they carry out anaerobic fermentation in the cytosol.}\\)
\\(\\text{Yeast convert glucose to ethanol and carbon dioxide, and the ethanol is then extracted and purified.}\\)

\\(\\text{During growth, the maize plants absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by photosynthesis.}\\)
\\(\\text{When ethanol is produced and later burned as fuel, a similar amount of CO‚ÇÇ is released, so overall there is little or no}\\)
\\(\\text{net increase in atmospheric CO‚ÇÇ.}\\)

questions.question_text: Yeast cells are grown in a bioreactor where the technician can change glucose concentration and oxygen concentration independently. She first increases glucose concentration while keeping oxygen low, then later increases oxygen while keeping glucose constant.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why increasing glucose concentration increases both aerobic and anaerobic cellular respiration. (2 marks)
b) Explain how increasing oxygen concentration changes the balance between aerobic and anaerobic respiration, and why total rate may eventually plateau. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Glucose is the substrate for glycolysis, which is the first stage of both aerobic and
anaerobic respiration.}\\)
\\(\\text{Providing more glucose increases the rate of glycolysis, feeding more substrate into both pathways and increasing}\\)
\\(\\text{ATP production in each.}\\)

\\(\\text{As oxygen concentration rises, more yeast cells use aerobic respiration and rely less on anaerobic fermentation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Aerobic respiration yields far more ATP per glucose, so the proportion of ATP made aerobically increases.}\\)
\\(\\text{At high oxygen concentration, enzymes in aerobic pathways reach maximum rate, so total ATP production plateaus}\\)
\\(\\text{even if oxygen continues to increase.}\\)

questions.question_text: Plant root cells in waterlogged soil and animal muscle cells during sprinting both experience low oxygen, but they use different anaerobic pathways.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why both plant root cells and animal muscle cells must regenerate NAD‚Å∫ during anaerobic conditions. (2 marks)
b) Describe the main difference in end products between anaerobic respiration in waterlogged plant roots and in animal muscle cells. (2 marks)
c) Explain one disadvantage of prolonged anaerobic respiration in plant roots. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Glycolysis converts NAD‚Å∫ to NADH when splitting glucose.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without regeneration of NAD‚Å∫, glycolysis would stop and no ATP could be produced anaerobically.}\\)

\\(\\text{Plant roots typically convert pyruvate to ethanol and carbon dioxide.}\\)
\\(\\text{Animal muscle cells convert pyruvate to lactate with no additional CO‚ÇÇ release.}\\)

\\(\\text{Ethanol can accumulate and become toxic to plant cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{If waterlogging persists, root cells may die due to toxin build-up and lack of ATP.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A new drug partly destroys a person‚Äôs bone marrow. Months later, tests show very low numbers of neutrophils, macrophages and mast cells. B and T lymphocyte numbers are normal.
Which part of immunity is most weakened?

orders.text_content:
A. First line of defence
B. Innate cellular second line of defence
C. Humoral immune response
D. Cell-mediated immune response

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The bone marrow damage lowers key innate cells like neutrophils, macrophages and mast cells. Adaptive B and T}\\)
\\(\\text{lymphocytes are still present, so the non-specific second line is most affected.}\\)

questions.question_text:
During the 1990s, some people developed a rare brain disease after eating beef from cattle with ‚Äúmad cow disease‚Äù (BSE). Their brain tissue later showed many abnormal, misfolded proteins that triggered a chain reaction, forcing normal versions of the protein into the same faulty shape. Standard sterilisation and high heat did not destroy the agent, unlike most bacteria and viruses.
What is the causative pathogen?

orders.text_content:
A. Virus
B. Prion
C. Protozoan
D. Bacterium

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Prions are infectious misfolded proteins that convert normal forms into the same abnormal shape. They resist}\\)
\\(\\text{high heat and standard sterilisation, and they cause slow, fatal brain degeneration.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Mosquitoes carrying malaria pick up Plasmodium from one human, then inject it into another. The mosquitoes show no signs of illness, but the humans become very sick.
In immunology terms, what is the mosquito?

orders.text_content:
A. Host
B. Pathogen
C. Vector
D. Antigen

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. A vector carries a pathogen from one host to another without being harmed itself. Here the mosquito transfers}\\)
\\(\\text{Plasmodium between human hosts.}\\)

questions.question_text: A child inhales airborne bacteria while playing. Most of these microbes are trapped and then swallowed, later dying in the stomach.

orders.text_content:
Which combination best explains these defences?

A. Mucus and cilia, then stomach acid
B. Nasal hairs, then neutrophils
C. Earwax, then complement proteins
D. Skin, then antibodies

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Cilia move mucus up the airway, trapping pathogens that are swallowed. Strong stomach acid then kills most of}\\)
\\(\\text{the swallowed microbes.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A patient is given a broad-spectrum antibiotic for a chest infection. The drug wipes out many species of bacteria in her gut as well as the target pathogen. Two weeks later she develops severe diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Tests show very high numbers of Clostridioides difficile, a bacterium that was previously present only at low levels and can form hardy spores.

Which statement best explains this outcome?

orders.text_content:
A. Antibiotics killed only viruses, leaving C. difficile to grow
B. Antibiotics removed normal gut flora that usually compete with C. difficile
C. Antibiotics turned C. difficile into a non-pathogenic strain
D. Antibiotics weakened the first line of defence in the lungs

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Normal gut flora competes for space and nutrients, limiting C. difficile growth. The antibiotic kills many of these}\\)
\\(\\text{helpful species, so C. difficile can expand and cause disease.}\\)

questions.question_text: A plant pathologist compares two leaves. One has a thick waxy cuticle and many trichomes. The other has a thin cuticle and no hairs. Both leaves lack obvious chemical toxins. Why is the first leaf better protected from fungal spores landing on its surface?

orders.text_content:
A. Trichomes and thick cuticle form strong physical barriers to entry
B. Trichomes secrete antibodies that bind fungal antigens
C. Thick cuticle produces lysozyme enzymes that digest spores
D. Thin cuticle prevents stomata from closing during infection

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. The thick waxy cuticle and leaf hairs act as physical barriers. They block or slow fungal spores from reaching and}\\)
\\(\\text{penetrating the epidermis.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A teenager with a long history of hay fever walks through a field of rye grass in spring. Within minutes, her airways feel tight and itchy. In her bronchi, blood vessels dilate, become leaky and produce a lot of mucus. Blood tests show high histamine levels and many granules have vanished from certain immune cells sitting in her airway tissues rather than in blood.

Which cell type is most responsible for releasing this histamine at the site?

orders.text_content:
A. Basophils in the bloodstream
B. Mast cells in connective tissue
C. Neutrophils in pus
D. Cytotoxic T cells in lymph nodes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Mast cells lie in connective tissue near blood vessels and airways. When activated by allergens, they degranulate and}\\)
\\(\\text{release histamine, driving local inflammation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A bacterial infection spreads into tissue fluid. Complement proteins bind to the bacterial surface. Soon after, pores form in the membrane and water rushes in, killing the cells. Phagocytes also arrive in large numbers.

Which term best describes this complement action on bacteria?

orders.text_content:
A. Neutralisation of toxins
B. Agglutination of antigens
C. Membrane attack complex formation and chemotaxis
D. Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Complement can assemble into a membrane attack complex that punches holes in pathogen membranes. It also}\\)
\\(\\text{attracts phagocytes to the site by chemotaxis.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A virus infects liver cells and forces them to produce new virions. As infection spreads, nearby uninfected cells begin expressing antiviral proteins and become harder to infect. Natural killer cells also move into the area.

Which innate signal most likely started this local antiviral state?

orders.text_content:
A. Histamine from mast cells
B. Interferons from infected cells
C. Complement proteins from plasma
D. Antibodies from plasma cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Infected cells release interferons that warn neighbouring cells to enter an antiviral state. Interferons also}\\)
\\(\\text{recruit natural killer cells to destroy infected hosts.}\\)

questions.question_text: A chef cuts his finger with a dirty knife at work. Within a few hours, the skin around the wound becomes red, hot, swollen and sore. A yellowish fluid rich in dead neutrophils and bacteria builds up under the bandage. He has not yet made a measurable antibody response to the bacteria.

orders.text_content:
Which description best matches this response?

A. First line barrier using intact skin
B. Adaptive humoral response
C. Inflammatory response of the second line
D. Cell-mediated killing by cytotoxic T cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Redness, heat, swelling, pain and pus are classic signs of inflammation. This is a rapid, non-specific second line}\\)
\\(\\text{response driven by histamine and recruited phagocytes.}\\)

questions.question_text: In healthy mice, the interaction shown in the diagram occurs in lymph nodes soon after infection with a new pathogen. A mutant mouse strain completely lacks dendritic cells but still has neutrophils, macrophages, B cells and T cells. After infection with a new virus, the mutant mouse clears some virus early but fails to make strong antibody or cytotoxic T cell responses.

orders.text_content:
Which role of dendritic cells best explains this failure?

A. Degranulation and histamine release at wounds
B. Long-term antibody production in blood
C. Antigen presentation to T helper cells in lymph nodes
D. Production of complement proteins in plasma

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Antigen presentation to T helper cells in lymph nodes. Dendritic cells capture antigens in tissues, then move to}\\)
\\(\\text{lymph nodes and present them on MHC II to naive T helper cells. This interaction, plus cytokine release, is essential to}\\)
\\(\\text{fully activate T helpers, which in turn drive B-cell antibody production and cytotoxic T-cell activation. Without}\\)
\\(\\text{dendritic cells, these adaptive responses stay weak.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A patient‚Äôs B cells can bind antigens and engulf them, but their T helper cells cannot make cytokines. After infection with a bacterium, antigen-presenting cells still activate these T helpers, yet almost no antibodies appear in blood.

What step is blocked?

orders.text_content:
A. Clonal expansion and differentiation of selected B cells
B. Phagocytosis of bacteria by neutrophils
C. MHC I presentation on infected cells
D. Release of perforin and granzymes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Cytokines from T helper cells drive clonal expansion and differentiation of B cells. Without these signals, few}\\)
\\(\\text{plasma cells form and antibody levels remain very low.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A person is infected with an extracellular bacterium. Weeks later, many circulating proteins bind to the bacterial surface, clump them, neutralise toxins and flag them for phagocytosis.

Which cells were most responsible for making these proteins?

orders.text_content:
A. Neutrophils
B. Plasma B cells
C. Cytotoxic T cells
D. Natural killer cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Plasma B cells secrete large amounts of antibodies into blood and lymph. These antibodies bind, neutralise and}\\)
\\(\\text{opsonise extracellular bacteria.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A teacher asks students to match antibody actions with outcomes:

- Action W: antibodies bind bacterial flagella
- Action X: antibodies cause clumps of several bacteria
- Action Y: antibodies coat bacteria for easier engulfment

orders.text_content:
Which labels fit W, X and Y?

A. W neutralisation, X agglutination, Y precipitation
B. W immobilisation, X agglutination, Y opsonisation
C. W opsonisation, X neutralisation, Y immobilisation
D. W agglutination, X immobilisation, Y neutralisation

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Binding flagella stops movement, which is immobilisation. Clumping whole cells is agglutination, and}\\)
\\(\\text{coating to aid phagocytosis is opsonisation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A patient develops a small skin tumour. Biopsy shows abnormal proteins produced by mutated genes. These proteins are displayed on MHC I molecules on the tumour cells. Nearby lymphocytes recognise these markers, bind to the tumour, then release perforin and granzymes that trigger apoptosis. Doctors later detect memory cells specific to the same tumour antigens.

Which adaptive cell type is acting here?

orders.text_content:
A. Helper T cell
B. Cytotoxic T cell
C. Natural killer cell
D. Plasma B cell

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Cytotoxic T cells recognise non-self-antigens on MHC I on abnormal cells. They kill these cells by releasing perforin}\\)
\\(\\text{and granzymes, and they form memory cells for future responses.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Surgeons remove lymph nodes from a person‚Äôs armpit during cancer treatment. After recovery, the arm on that side occasionally swells and infections in that arm persist longer.

Which combined role of the lymphatic system best explains these problems?

orders.text_content:
A. Making stomach acid and sweat
B. Draining tissue fluid and providing sites for adaptive activation
C. Producing red blood cells and platelets
D. Making complement proteins and interferons

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Lymphatic vessels drain excess fluid into lymph nodes. Lymph nodes also house many immune cells and are key}\\)
\\(\\text{sites where adaptive responses begin.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A newborn baby has intact skin and normal first line barriers, but a genetic defect prevents the production of complement proteins and interferons.

Which statement best describes this baby‚Äôs immune function?

orders.text_content:
A. First line, second line and third line are all normal
B. First line is normal, second line partly impaired, third line still possible
C. First line fails, second line and third line stay normal
D. Only third line is impaired

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Physical and chemical barriers of the first line still work. However, important non-cellular parts of the innate second}\\)
\\(\\text{line (complement, interferons) are missing, while adaptive immunity can still be triggered.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Staphylococcus aureus usually lives harmlessly on skin as part of normal flora. After deep surgery, the same bacterium enters the bloodstream and causes a serious infection.

Which sequence best describes the order of defences it overcomes?

orders.text_content:
A. Third line, second line, first line
B. First line, second line, third line
C. Second line, first line, third line
D. First line then third line only

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The bacterium first passes the skin barrier (first line). Innate defences respond next, and if they fail, adaptive third}\\)
\\(\\text{line responses develop.}\\)

questions.question_text: A lab screens compounds that damage cell walls. One candidate drug dissolves peptidoglycan but has no effect on nucleic acids or proteins. Which pathogen group would most likely be killed directly by this drug?

orders.text_content:
A. Prions
B. Viruses
C. Bacteria
D. Protozoa

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Bacterial cell walls are mainly peptidoglycan, so dissolving this layer causes lysis. Viruses, prions and protozoa do not}\\)
\\(\\text{have peptidoglycan walls.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A child catches measles at age six. They have fever and a widespread rash but recover after two weeks. Years later, they are exposed to measles again in a school outbreak. This time they have no rash and only mild cold-like symptoms. Blood tests show a rapid, high spike of measles-specific antibodies produced within days.

Which explanation best fits this response?

orders.text_content:
A. First line barriers became stronger after the first infection
B. Memory B and T cells from the earlier adaptive response remained in the body
C. Complement proteins permanently increased after the first infection
D. Viruses cannot infect a host twice

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The first infection created long-lived memory B and T cells. On re-exposure, these cells respond quickly, producing large}\\)
\\(\\text{amounts of antibody and clearing the virus before major symptoms develop.}\\)

questions.question_text: Doctors treat an older patient for a serious gut infection using a broad-spectrum antibiotic course. Within a month the patient develops severe diarrhoea caused by Clostridium difficile. Doctors then perform a faecal microbiota transplant (FMT) from a healthy donor to restore the patient‚Äôs gut flora.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how normal gut flora act as a microbiological barrier before the first antibiotic course. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the first antibiotic course made the patient more likely to develop C. difficile infection. (3 marks)
c) Explain how a faecal microbiota transplant helps restore the first line of defence in the gut. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Normal florae occupy space on the gut lining and use available nutrients, leaving little room and food for invading}\\)
\\(\\text{pathogens.}\\)
\\(\\text{Many normal flora release substances that inhibit or outcompete harmful bacteria, stopping them from establishing}\\)
\\(\\text{infection.}\\)

\\(\\text{Broad spectrum antibiotics kill many non-pathogenic gut bacteria as well as the target pathogen, reducing the diversity}\\)
\\(\\text{of normal flora.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer normal flora, C. difficile faces less competition for space and nutrients in the intestine.}\\)
\\(\\text{This loss of competition allows C. difficile numbers to rise quickly, turning it into an opportunistic pathogen that now}\\)
\\(\\text{causes disease.}\\)

\\(\\text{FMT introduces a community of healthy bacteria from the donor into the patient‚Äôs large intestine.}\\)
\\(\\text{These bacteria repopulate the gut, rebuilding the microbiological barrier so that C. difficile can no longer dominate.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student falls on gravel and cuts their knee. Dirt and bacteria enter the wound. Over the next day the skin around the cut becomes red, hot and swollen, and the student notices a tender, enlarged lymph node behind the knee.

orders.text_content: a) Name two first line barriers that were breached when the gravel cut the knee and explain how each normally protects against pathogens. (2 marks)
b) Describe four key steps of the inflammatory response that occur at the cut site. (4 marks)
c) Explain why the lymph node behind the knee becomes swollen during this response. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Intact skin, which normally forms a continuous physical barrier that blocks pathogen entry into body tissues.}\\)
\\(\\text{Normal skin flora, which usually compete with incoming microbes for space and nutrients on the skin surface, limiting}\\)
\\(\\text{colonisation by pathogens.}\\)

\\(\\text{Damaged cells and resident immune cells release cytokines and other signals that attract leukocytes.}\\)
\\(\\text{Local blood vessels dilate and become more permeable, bringing extra blood and allowing plasma and proteins}\\)
\\(\\text{to leak into the tissue.}\\)
\\(\\text{Neutrophils and other phagocytes leave the blood, move into the tissue and engulf bacteria and debris.}\\)
\\(\\text{Clotting factors help form a clot and scab, sealing the wound and limiting the spread of pathogens from the }\\)
\\(\\text{injury site.}\\)

\\(\\text{Extra tissue fluid, containing pathogens and antigen-presenting cells, drains from the injured area into nearby lymphatic}\\)
\\(\\text{capillaries and vessels.}\\)
\\(\\text{This lymph is carried to the regional lymph node, where it passes through dense clusters of B cells and T cells for}\\)
\\(\\text{antigen surveillance.}\\)
\\(\\text{Clonal selection and proliferation of matching lymphocytes in the node increase cell numbers, which causes the}\\)
\\(\\text{node to swell and become tender.}\\)

questions.question_text: A neurologist studies a patient with a slow, fatal brain disease like Creutzfeldt‚ÄìJakob disease. Brain samples show abnormal, misfolded proteins that can convert normal forms of the same protein into the misfolded shape. No nucleic acids are detected in the infectious material.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the agent causing this disease is classed as a non-cellular pathogen. (2 marks)
b) Describe how this misfolded protein causes progressive damage to brain tissue. (2 marks)
c) Suggest two reasons why the immune system may struggle to clear this type of pathogen. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The infectious agent is made only of misfolded protein and lacks cellular structures such as a membrane, cytoplasm}\\)
\\(\\text{or organelles.}\\) 
\\(\\text{It does not contain DNA or RNA, so it cannot carry out normal cellular processes on its own and is not considered a}\\)
\\(\\text{living cell.}\\)

\\(\\text{The misfolded protein converts normal versions of the same protein into the abnormal shape, causing them to}\\)
\\(\\text{aggregate.}\\)
\\(\\text{These protein aggregates disrupt normal neuron function and lead to cell death, which produces holes and loss of}\\)
\\(\\text{brain tissue.}\\)

\\(\\text{Because the prion is made from a host protein, its antigens are very similar to self, so it may not trigger a strong}\\)
\\(\\text{adaptive immune response.}\\)
\\(\\text{Prion aggregates are highly resistant to normal proteases and degradation, so they are difficult for phagocytes to}\\)
\\(\\text{break down and remove.}\\)

questions.question_text: A person is infected with a new strain of influenza virus. Antibody levels in their blood rise slowly over two weeks, then fall once the infection clears. Three years later they encounter the same strain again. Antibody levels now rise within a few days and reach a much higher peak than the first time.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why there is a delay before antibodies appear after the first infection. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the second exposure produces a faster and stronger antibody response. (2 marks)
c) Describe the roles of T helper cells and cytotoxic T cells in clearing this influenza infection. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Viral antigens must first be taken up by antigen-presenting cells and carried to a lymph node.}\\)
\\(\\text{In the lymph node, matching T helper cells and B cells undergo clonal selection and expansion before enough plasma}\\)
\\(\\text{cells exist to secrete detectable antibody.}\\)

\\(\\text{Memory B cells created after the first infection remain in the body and recognise the same viral antigen quickly.}\\)
\\(\\text{These memory cells divide rapidly into many plasma cells, so antibodies are produced sooner and in larger amounts than}\\)
\\(\\text{in the primary response.}\\)

\\(\\text{T helper cells recognise antigen presented on MHC II, then release cytokines that activate selected B cells}\\)
\\(\\text{and cytotoxic T cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{Activated B cells become plasma cells that secrete antibodies, which neutralise free virus and tag it for phagocytosis.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cytotoxic T cells recognise infected host cells displaying viral peptides on MHC I and induce apoptosis in those}\\)
\\(\\text{cells, removing sites of viral replication.}\\)

questions.question_text: Elephantiasis is caused by the parasitic worm Wuchereria bancrofti, which lives in lymphatic vessels and can block them. The worms also release chemicals that reduce the activity of parts of the immune system. Patients often show extreme swelling in their legs and frequent infections.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why blocking lymphatic vessels in the legs leads to severe swelling. (2 marks)
b) Explain how blocked lymphatic vessels can weaken the adaptive immune response to other pathogens. (3 marks)
c) Explain why elephantiasis is described as causing a form of immunodeficiency and identify whether it is primary or secondary. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Tissue fluid that normally leaks from blood capillaries into the leg cannot enter blocked lymphatic capillaries.}\\)
\\(\\text{This fluid builds up in the surrounding tissues instead of being returned to the blood, causing persistent swelling}\\)
\\(\\text{and enlargement of the limbs.}\\)

\\(\\text{Less lymph flows from tissues to lymph nodes, so fewer pathogens and antigen-presenting cells reach lymphoid tissue.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer antigens arriving, there is reduced clonal selection and activation of specific B and T lymphocytes.}\\)
\\(\\text{This means fewer antibodies and cytotoxic T cells are produced, making it harder to clear new infections.}\\)

\\(\\text{The worm and its secreted chemicals reduce the effectiveness of the host immune system, increasing susceptibility}\\)
\\(\\text{to opportunistic infections.}\\)
\\(\\text{The problem arises from an external infectious agent rather than a defect inside the immune cells themselves.}\\)
\\(\\text{It is therefore classed as a secondary immunodeficiency, since an acquired factor has impaired normal immune function.}\\)

questions.question_text: A teenager develops a severe peanut allergy. On first exposure, they only have mild itching. One year later, after eating a small amount of peanut, they quickly develop swelling of the lips, wheezing and a drop in blood pressure.

orders.text_content: a) Define an allergen and explain why peanuts can trigger an allergic reaction even though they are not pathogens. (2 marks)
b) Outline the key events that occur during the sensitisation stage after the teenager‚Äôs first exposure to peanut. (3 marks)
c) Explain what happens in the body when the teenager is re-exposed to peanut and why this can lead to anaphylaxis. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{An allergen is a harmless substance that the immune system wrongly treats as a threat.}\\)
\\(\\text{Peanut proteins act as antigens that trigger an inappropriate immune response, even though they do not cause infection.}\\)

\\(\\text{B cells incorrectly recognise peanut antigen as dangerous and undergo clonal selection and differentiation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Plasma cells produce IgE antibodies that bind to receptors on mast cells in tissues such as the skin and airways.}\\)
\\(\\text{Mast cells become ‚Äúsensitised‚Äù, ready to respond strongly if they encounter the same allergen again.}\\)

\\(\\text{Peanut allergen cross-links IgE antibodies already bound to mast cells, triggering rapid degranulation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Large amounts of histamine are released, causing vasodilation, fluid leak, airway narrowing and increased mucus.}\\)
\\(\\text{These changes can cause a sudden drop in blood pressure and severe breathing difficulty, known as anaphylactic shock.}\\)

questions.question_text: A young adult is diagnosed with HIV. Over several years, their T helper cell count falls well below normal. They begin to suffer from rare lung infections and persistent thrush (a fungal infection) that most healthy people quickly clear.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how HIV infection leads to a fall in T helper cell numbers. (3 marks)
b) Explain why this T helper cell loss makes the patient more likely to develop ‚Äúopportunistic infections‚Äù. (3 marks)
c) Classify the immunodeficiency caused by HIV as primary or secondary and justify your answer. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{HIV infects T helper cells and some macrophages by binding to specific receptors on their surface.}\\) 
\\(\\text{The virus replicates inside these cells and can kill them directly or trigger apoptosis.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cytotoxic T cells may also destroy infected T helper cells, so the overall T helper cell population drops over time.}\\)

\\(\\text{T helper cells are needed to activate B cells and cytotoxic T cells through cytokine release.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer T helper cells, the patient makes fewer antibodies and has weaker cell-mediated responses to pathogens.}\\)
\\(\\text{Microbes that are usually controlled easily, such as some fungi and rare bacteria, can now grow and cause serious}\\)
\\(\\text{disease.}\\)

\\(\\text{HIV infection causes a secondary (acquired) immunodeficiency.}\\)
\\(\\text{The immune defect is due to an external pathogen destroying T helper cells, not a genetic fault inside the immune}\\)
\\(\\text{system itself.}\\)

questions.question_text: In type 1 diabetes, a person‚Äôs immune system slowly destroys the insulin-producing Œ≤ cells in their pancreas. No virus or bacterium is found in the pancreas at the time of destruction.

orders.text_content: a) Define ‚Äúself-antigen‚Äù and ‚Äúnon-self-antigen‚Äù in human cells. (2 marks)
b) Explain what goes wrong in the immune system during an autoimmune disease such as type 1 diabetes. (2 marks)
c) Using type 1 diabetes as an example, describe which cells are targeted and one consequence for the body. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A self-antigen is a molecule, such as an MHC marker, found on the body‚Äôs own cells and normally recognised as ‚Äúself‚Äù.}\\)
\\(\\text{A non-self-antigen is a foreign molecule from pathogens or other sources that is recognised as ‚Äúnot self‚Äù and can}\\)
\\(\\text{trigger an immune response.}\\)

\\(\\text{Immune cells lose tolerance to a particular self-antigen and wrongly recognise self-cells as foreign.}\\)
\\(\\text{They then attack and destroy these self-cells, causing tissue damage and loss of normal organ function.}\\)

\\(\\text{Cytotoxic T cells and other immune cells target the Œ≤ cells in the islets of the pancreas.}\\)
\\(\\text{These Œ≤ cells are gradually destroyed and can no longer produce insulin.}\\)
\\(\\text{Without enough insulin, blood glucose levels remain high, leading to long-term damage to organs such as eyes,}\\)
\\(\\text{kidneys and blood vessels.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Consider two patients:
- Patient A is a child born with a mutation that prevents neutrophils from making toxic chemicals needed for phagocytosis.
- Patient B is an adult who receives chemotherapy that kills many dividing cells, including immune cells. Both patients suffer frequent infections that healthy people rarely get.

orders.text_content: a) Define primary immunodeficiency and secondary immunodeficiency. (2 marks)
b) For each patient, state whether their immunodeficiency is primary or secondary and justify your choice. (3 marks)
c) Explain why both patients are at higher risk of ‚Äúopportunistic infections‚Äù. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Primary immunodeficiency arises from a problem within the immune system itself, often due to a genetic mutation}\\)
\\(\\text{present from birth.}\\)
\\(\\text{Secondary immunodeficiency is caused by an external factor, such as infection, drugs or malnutrition, that}\\)
\\(\\text{weakens a previously normal immune system.}\\)

\\(\\text{Patient A has a primary immunodeficiency, because their phagocytes are faulty due to an inherited mutation}\\)
\\(\\text{affecting chemicals used in phagocytosis.}\\)
\\(\\text{Patient B has a secondary immunodeficiency, because chemotherapy, an external treatment, has damaged their}\\)
\\(\\text{immune cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{In Patient B, the immune system was initially normal but became compromised after exposure to the treatment.}\\)

\\(\\text{Their weakened immune systems cannot control microbes that are usually harmless or easily cleared in healthy}\\)
\\(\\text{people.}\\)
\\(\\text{These microbes can now grow unchecked and become pathogenic, causing frequent or unusual infections.}\\)

questions.question_text: A person gets a deep skin infection on their leg. Macrophages in the tissue engulf bacteria and become antigen-presenting cells. Swollen, tender lymph nodes appear in the groin a few days later as the person mounts an adaptive immune response.

orders.text_content: a) Describe how the lymphatic system transports antigens from the infection site to a lymph node. (3 marks)
b) Explain what happens inside the lymph node to start the adaptive immune response. (3 marks)
c) Explain why both patients are at higher risk of ‚Äúopportunistic infections‚Äù. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Fluid leaking from blood capillaries around the infection carries pathogens and antigen-presenting cells into}\\)
\\(\\text{nearby lymphatic capillaries.}\\)
\\(\\text{This fluid is now called lymph and is moved through larger lymphatic vessels towards regional lymph nodes.}\\)
\\(\\text{Afferent lymphatic vessels deliver lymph into the lymph node, where it passes through clusters of immune cells.}\\)

\\(\\text{Antigen-presenting cells display processed bacterial antigens on MHC II and interact with T helper cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{Specific T helper cells and B cells whose receptors match the antigen undergo clonal selection and clonal expansion.}\\)
\\(\\text{B cells differentiate into plasma cells that secrete antibodies, and T cells differentiate into effector and memory cells,}\\)
\\(\\text{initiating humoral and cell- mediated responses.}\\)

\\(\\text{Lymph nodes filter lymph and trap pathogens and antigen-presenting cells, concentrating them in one place.}\\)
\\(\\text{They are major sites of clonal expansion, so large numbers of lymphocytes are produced there, increasing their size}\\)
\\(\\text{and causing swelling.}\\)

questions.question_text: A group of students investigate why minor scrapes on their hands do not always lead to infection. They learn that skin is more than just ‚Äúa covering‚Äù and that it forms part of the first line of defence. Their teacher explains that sweat, oil and harmless microbes all work together to keep pathogens out.

orders.text_content: a) Explain two ways intact skin helps prevent pathogen entry. (2 marks)
b) Explain one way that normal skin flora (harmless bacteria) help protect against new pathogens. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The outer layer of skin cells forms a tough physical barrier that is difficult for pathogens to cross.}\\)
\\(\\text{Sweat and oil on the skin surface can create conditions (such as low pH) that are less favourable for many pathogens.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for either of the following, to a maximum of one mark:}\\)
\\(\\text{Normal florae compete with incoming microbes for space on the skin surface, making it harder for pathogens to attach.}\\)
\\(\\text{They also compete for nutrients, which limits the ability of new pathogens to grow and multiply.}\\)

questions.question_text: A child has a bacterial throat infection and develops a fever of 38.5¬∞C. The parents are worried, but the doctor explains that moderate fever is a common part of the second line of defence. Blood tests show increased levels of cytokines released by phagocytes.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how cytokines can lead to fever during an infection. (2 marks)
b) Explain three ways a moderate fever can help the body fight infection. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Activated phagocytes release cytokines (pyrogens) into the bloodstream when they detect pathogens.}\\)
\\(\\text{These cytokines act on the hypothalamus in the brain, raising the body‚Äôs temperature set-point and producing fever.}\\)

\\(\\text{Higher body temperature can reduce the growth rate of some bacteria and viruses that prefer normal body temperature.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fever can speed up some immune reactions by increasing the activity of certain enzymes and immune cells, by}\\)
\\(\\text{increasing kinetic energy of associated enzymes and cells and therefor rate of successful collisions.}\\)
\\(\\text{The person may rest more due to feeling unwell, which allows energy to be diverted towards immune function and}\\)
\\(\\text{recovery.}\\)

questions.question_text: A new whooping cough vaccine is introduced to a small town. Within two years, over 95% of school children are fully vaccinated. Case reports show a sharp drop in whooping cough, even in babies who are too young to be fully vaccinated.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how vaccination protects an individual student who receives the whooping cough vaccine. (3 marks)
b) Explain why very high vaccination rates in the town also protect unvaccinated babies. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The vaccine contains antigens from the whooping cough bacterium, which stimulate an adaptive immune response}\\)
\\(\\text{without causing full disease.}\\)
\\(\\text{B cells produce specific antibodies and memory B and T cells are formed against these antigens.}\\)
\\(\\text{If the student later encounters the real bacterium, memory cells respond quickly, producing antibodies that clear}\\)
\\(\\text{the infection before severe symptoms develop.}\\)

\\(\\text{When most people are immune, there are fewer infected individuals to pass the pathogen on, so overall transmission}\\)
\\(\\text{in the community falls.}\\)
\\(\\text{This ‚Äúherd immunity‚Äù reduces the chance that vulnerable unvaccinated babies will meet someone carrying whooping}\\)
\\(\\text{cough.}\\)

questions.question_text: In a clinic, two patients arrive with different illnesses. One has bacterial pneumonia; the other has influenza caused by a virus. The doctor prescribes antibiotics for the pneumonia but not for the flu, even though both patients have a fever and cough.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why antibiotics can treat bacterial pneumonia but not influenza. (2 marks)
b) Explain one-way antiviral drugs can act differently from antibiotics when treating viral infections. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Antibiotics target features of bacteria, such as cell wall synthesis or bacterial ribosomes, that are not present in}\\)
\\(\\text{human cells.}\\) 
\\(\\text{Influenza is caused by a virus that uses the host‚Äôs own cell machinery, so most antibiotics have no specific target and}\\)
\\(\\text{cannot stop viral replication.}\\)

\\(\\text{Some antiviral drugs block viral enzymes (such as reverse transcriptase or neuraminidase) that are needed for viral}\\)
\\(\\text{replication or release from host cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{Others prevent viruses from entering or uncoating inside host cells, so they cannot start their replication cycle.}\\)

questions.question_text: A basketball player twists their ankle badly but does not break the skin. The ankle becomes red, hot and swollen. Later that week, they also get a small cut on their finger that becomes red, swollen and filled with pus after dirt enters the wound.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the twisted ankle becomes inflamed even though no pathogens entered the body at that site. (2 marks)
b) Explain two differences between inflammation in the sterile ankle injury and inflammation at the infected cut. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Damaged cells in the sprained ankle release chemicals that trigger the inflammatory response, such as histamine}\\)
\\(\\text{and cytokines.}\\)
\\(\\text{These signals cause vasodilation and increased capillary permeability, leading to redness, heat and swelling even}\\)
\\(\\text{without an infection.}\\)

\\(\\text{One mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{At the infected cut, neutrophils and other phagocytes are recruited to engulf bacteria, often forming pus, at}\\)
\\(\\text{the ankle, phagocytes mainly clear damaged cells and debris.}\\)
\\(\\text{The infected cut involves recognition of pathogen-associated antigens and may later trigger adaptive responses,}\\)
\\(\\text{while the sterile injury mostly involves innate responses to tissue damage.}\\)
\\(\\text{The infected site has a risk of pathogen spread and systemic symptoms (like fever), while the sterile ankle}\\)
\\(\\text{inflammation is local and not caused by microbes.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A baby is breastfed for the first six months of life. The mother‚Äôs antibodies move across the placenta before birth and are also present in breast milk. After birth, more antibodies (mainly IgA) are supplied through breast milk. The baby can fight off some infections even though its own immune system is still immature. The baby stays healthy despite having an immature immune system.

What type of immunity does the baby gain from the mother‚Äôs antibodies?

orders.text_content:
A. Natural active
B. Natural passive
C. Artificial active
D. Artificial passive

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The baby receives ready-made antibodies from the mother by placenta and breast milk, so this is natural passive}\\)
\\(\\text{immunity, which is short-term and does not create the baby‚Äôs own memory cells.}\\)

questions.question_text: In 1950, a city had a large measles outbreak. After a nationwide vaccine program in the 1970s, measles cases dropped close to zero. In the last decade, vaccination rates fell in some suburbs due to misinformation and fear of side effects. Measles cases are now rising again, mainly in areas with low vaccine uptake. Which term best describes the current pattern of measles in this country?

orders.text_content:
A. Emerging disease
B. Re-emerging disease
C. Endemic disease
D. Sporadic disease

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Measles was once a major health concern, then controlled by vaccination, but cases have now increased again due}\\)
\\(\\text{to a drop in herd immunity, so it is a re-emerging disease.}\\)

questions.question_text: A scientist wants to know if a new respiratory virus is spreading quietly through a city. Many infected people have only mild symptoms or none at all, so they might not go to hospital. The lab designs a screening program using nose and throat swabs and runs PCR with primers specific to the new virus. Even patients with a very low viral load can still be detected.

orders.text_content:
Why is PCR particularly useful in this situation?

A. It only detects antibodies, so it shows past infection
B. It can amplify tiny amounts of viral DNA or RNA to detect early infection
C. It stains cell walls to show Gram-positive bacteria
D. It always tells which drug will cure the virus

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. PCR amplifies a specific DNA (or cDNA from RNA) sequence many times, so even very small amounts of viral genetic}\\)
\\(\\text{material in a patient‚Äôs swab can be detected in early or mild infections.}\\)

questions.question_text:
An outbreak of a new flu-like disease begins in one city. Within a month, thousands of cases occur across the country. Within three months, the same strain is reported in North America, Europe and Asia. Genetic tests show the virus has undergone a major change in its surface antigens compared to older strains.

Which definition best fits this event?

orders.text_content:
A. An endemic caused by antigenic drift
B. An epidemic caused by antigenic drift
C. A pandemic caused by antigenic shift
D. A sporadic infection caused by vector resistance

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. The disease has spread across multiple, non-adjacent continents with a dramatic rise in cases, so it is a pandemic, and}\\)
\\(\\text{the large, sudden change in surface antigens is an antigenic shift.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student studies a graph showing antibody levels after a vaccine dose and a later booster. The first peak is smaller and slower. The second peak is higher and occurs more quickly after the booster.

orders.text_content:
What is the best explanation of the second peak?

A. Antibodies now last forever, so no more boosters are needed
B. Booster exposure activates memory B cells, leading to a faster and stronger response
C. Booster destroys memory cells so more antibodies are made
D. Booster prevents any antigen from entering the body

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The first dose creates memory B and T cells; the booster re-exposes them to the antigen, so they rapidly divide}\\)
\\(\\text{into plasma cells and produce more antibody, giving a stronger and faster response.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A scientist reviews records from the early years of European settlement in Australia. They notice that Aboriginal communities had very high death rates from smallpox, while many Europeans survived. Conditions in the camps were crowded and food was limited.

Which factor did not contribute to the high impact on Aboriginal communities?

orders.text_content:
A. Lack of previous exposure, so no immunological memory to smallpox
B. Crowded living conditions that increased transmission
C. Pre-existing memory B cells against smallpox in Aboriginal adults
D. Reduced access to traditional medicines and poor nutrition

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Aboriginal communities had no prior exposure or memory cells to smallpox; this increased severity, while crowding,}\\)
\\(\\text{poor nutrition and loss of traditional care also worsened outcomes.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A virologist tracks a seasonal influenza strain over ten years. Lab tests show small, gradual changes in its surface antigens every year. Vaccines need to be updated regularly, but existing immunity still gives some partial protection. 

Which term best describes this pattern of antigen change?

orders.text_content:
A. Antigenic shift, which often causes new pandemics
B. Antigenic drift, which causes slow, stepwise changes over time
C. Zoonosis, where disease jumps from animals to humans
D. Vector resistance, where mosquitoes evolve new traits

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Antigenic drift is a slow change in antigen shape over many years, causing gradual loss of fit with existing memory}\\)
\\(\\text{cells, while antigenic shift is a sudden large change that can drive pandemics.}\\)

questions.question_text: Health workers respond to an outbreak of a faecal‚Äìoral pathogen that spreads through dirty water. They install clean toilets, treat drinking water, and run lessons on handwashing with soap. Which strategy best explains how these actions reduce spread?

orders.text_content:
A. They reduce airborne transmission
B. They reduce droplet spread when coughing
C. They break the faecal‚Äìoral route by improving hygiene and water safety
D. They only reduce vector-borne transmission

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Cleaning toilets, treating water and washing hands remove or kill pathogens in faeces and prevent them from}\\)
\\(\\text{entering mouths, breaking the faecal‚Äìoral transmission route.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A hospital lab receives samples from several patients with fever and cough. The doctors want to know quickly whether they are dealing with a bacterial pneumonia outbreak or a viral outbreak. The lab has light microscopes, Gram stain reagents, PCR machines and ELISA kits. The scientist first grows samples on nutrient agar and stains them with Gram stain. Under the light microscope, they see purple, spherical cells in chains in some samples, while other samples show no visible cells even after staining.

Which combination would give the clearest evidence that the pathogen is a bacterium?

orders.text_content:
A. ELISA for patient antibodies and PCR for viral RNA
B. Gram staining and light microscopy to see cell walls and shape
C. Only PCR with viral primers
D. Only ELISA for viral antigens

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Gram staining and microscopy can show cell shape and peptidoglycan cell walls, which are features of bacteria and}\\)
\\(\\text{not viruses, so they help distinguish bacterial infections.}\\)

questions.question_text:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, many countries used a mix of tools: PCR testing, mask mandates, border controls, and mass vaccination. Some people confused the roles of these strategies, thinking that PCR alone could stop spread or that vaccines alone meant no other measures were needed.
Which option correctly pairs a strategy with its main role?

orders.text_content:
A. PCR testing ‚Äì directly kills the virus in infected people
B. Masks and distancing ‚Äì reduce person-to-person transmission by droplets and aerosols
C. Vaccination ‚Äì only reduces symptoms, never affects spread
D. Border closure ‚Äì changes the virus‚Äôs antigens to stop infection

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Masks and physical distancing reduce the chance that droplets and small particles carrying the virus move from one}\\)
\\(\\text{person to another, so they lower transmission, while PCR is for detection and vaccines build immunity.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A hiker in rural Australia is bitten by a highly venomous snake. At the hospital, doctors quickly inject the hiker with antivenom that contains purified antibodies raised in horses against that snake‚Äôs toxin. The hiker recovers well, but they are warned that this treatment will not protect them from future bites.

Which type of immunity is given by the antivenom?

orders.text_content:
A. Natural active
B. Natural passive
C. Artificial active
D. Artificial passive

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{D. The hiker receives ready-made antibodies from another species via medical injection, which is artificial passive immunity}\\)
\\(\\text{and does not form the hiker‚Äôs own memory cells.}\\)

questions.question_text: A company produces monoclonal antibodies against a cancer cell antigen. They immunise a mouse, isolate one plasma B cell that makes the desired antibody, and fuse it with a tumour cell to form a hybridoma. The hybridoma is grown in culture to produce large amounts of identical antibody.

orders.text_content:
A. Plasma B cells can already divide forever in culture
B. Tumour cells stop antibody production, which is safer
C. Hybridomas combine unlimited cell division with specific antibody production
D. Hybridomas make many different antibodies at once

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. The tumour cell part gives the hybridoma the ability to divide for a long time, while the plasma B cell part provides}\\)
\\(\\text{the genes to make one specific antibody, so the culture can produce large amounts of identical monoclonals.}\\)

questions.question_text: A nurse reads that a new monoclonal antibody for an autoimmune disease must usually be given only once, because later doses may not work as well. Why might repeated use of the same monoclonal antibody become less effective?

orders.text_content:
A. The monoclonal becomes more concentrated each time
B. The monoclonal mutates into a virus
C. The patient‚Äôs immune system recognises the monoclonal as non-self and makes memory cells against it
D. The monoclonal deletes all memory cells in the body

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Monoclonal antibodies come from another organism, so the patient can make an immune response and memory}\\)
\\(\\text{cells against them, which means later doses are cleared faster and work less well.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Doctors trial a new monoclonal antibody that binds to PD-1 receptors on T cells in cancer patients. By blocking this receptor, the drug prevents tumour cells from turning T cells ‚Äúoff‚Äù. Clinical trials show better tumour control but also more autoimmune side effects.
Which term best describes this type of treatment?

orders.text_content:
A. Activation immunotherapy, because it boosts immune attack on cancer
B. Suppression immunotherapy, because it reduces immune function
C. Artificial passive vaccination, because it causes memory cell formation
D. Traditional chemotherapy, because it targets all dividing cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Blocking PD-1 lets T cells stay active for longer against cancer cells, which is activation immunotherapy that}\\)
\\(\\text{boosts immune activity, but it can also increase attack on some normal tissues.}\\)

questions.question_text: A scientist wants to see if a patient has mounted an immune response to a virus after infection. They coat a plate with viral antigens and add the patient‚Äôs blood sample. Later, an enzyme-linked antibody is added, and a colour change is measured with a spectrophotometer.

orders.text_content:
Which test is being used?

A. Gram stain
B. PCR
C. ELISA
D. DNA sequencing

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. ELISA uses antigen-coated plates and enzyme-linked antibodies to detect specific antibodies or antigens in a patient‚Äôs}\\)
\\(\\text{sample, often measured as a colour change.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A patient receives a kidney transplant from an unrelated donor. The donor kidney works at first, but months later tests show growing damage as cytotoxic T cells attack the graft. Doctors prescribe immunosuppressant drugs to reduce immune activity.

What is the main reason the graft was attacked?

orders.text_content:
A. The kidney lacked any MHC I markers
B. Donor MHC I markers were different from the recipient‚Äôs self-markers
C. The kidney contained too many memory B cells
D. The kidney produced its own antibodies

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The donor kidney cells present different MHC I markers that the recipient‚Äôs immune system recognises as non-self,}\\)
\\(\\text{so cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells attack the graft, leading to rejection.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In a trial, volunteers are asked to join a study testing a new cancer immunotherapy. They are given clear information about risks and benefits and may withdraw at any time without penalty.

Which bioethical principle is most directly supported by this process?

orders.text_content:
A. Beneficence
B. Justice
C. Autonomy / respect
D. Integrity

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Autonomy or respect focuses on people‚Äôs right to make informed choices about their own bodies, which is}\\)
\\(\\text{supported by clear information and voluntary consent.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A government considers making COVID-19 vaccination mandatory for healthcare workers in aged-care homes. This could protect vulnerable residents, but some staff worry about side effects and losing freedom of choice. An ethics committee meets to discuss the policy.

Which option best applies the principle of justice to this decision?

orders.text_content:
A. Focus only on the workers‚Äô individual risk
B. Focus only on the economic cost of vaccines
C. Consider fairness for all stakeholders, including equal protection for vulnerable residents and fair treatment of staff
D. Ignore resident outcomes and only follow hospital rules

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Justice is about fairness and equity; it asks how benefits and burdens are shared across groups, so both residents‚Äô}\\)
\\(\\text{protection and staff rights must be weighed to reach a fair outcome.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A disease spreads mainly by mosquitoes that breed in still water. Over time, the mosquito population develops resistance to a commonly used insecticide. New cases of the disease start to rise again despite spraying.

Which factor best explains this change?

orders.text_content:
A. Pathogen‚Äôs antigenic drift
B. Human demographic change
C. Vector resistance increasing pathogen spread
D. Better access to vaccines

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. When vectors such as mosquitoes evolve resistance to insecticides, they survive control programs and can}\\)
\\(\\text{continue to spread the pathogen, increasing disease transmission.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A teacher shows a table of different immunity types and asks which scenario is artificial active immunity.

Which option is correct?

orders.text_content:
A. A person recovers from chickenpox after natural infection
B. A newborn receives IgG antibodies across the placenta
C. A person receives an injection of monoclonal antibodies against a toxin
D. A person receives an mRNA vaccine that triggers their own antibody production

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{D. Artificial active immunity occurs when a medical procedure such as vaccination exposes a person to antigen}\\)
\\(\\text{and triggers their own immune response, forming memory cells for long-term protection.}\\)

questions.question_text: A doctor shows a patient an antibody graph with three labelled peaks. Peak 1 follows a natural infection in childhood. Peak 2 follows a vaccine and later booster. Peak 3 follows an emergency dose of antivenom after a snake bite.

orders.text_content: a) For one peak that shows active immunity, name the type of active immunity and explain why it is classed as ‚Äúactive‚Äù. (3 marks)
b) For peak 3, identify the type of immunity and explain two features that show it is passive. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for either:}\\)
\\(\\text{‚Ä¢ Peak 1 as natural active immunity.}\\)
\\(\\text{‚Ä¢ Peak 2 as artificial active immunity.}\\)
\\(\\text{In active immunity, the person‚Äôs own B and T cells are activated by antigen, leading to clonal selection and}\\)
\\(\\text{antibody production.}\\)
\\(\\text{Active immunity forms memory cells, so later exposures produce faster and stronger responses.}\\)

\\(\\text{Artificial passive immunity.}\\)
\\(\\text{Ready-made antibodies were injected from an external source (antivenom), so the patient‚Äôs own adaptive immune}\\)
\\(\\text{response was not activated.}\\)
\\(\\text{Antibody levels drop quickly because no memory cells form, so protection is short term.}\\)

questions.question_text: A country has high vaccination rates against a seasonal influenza strain. For several years, case numbers are low and most infections are mild. A few years later, a new influenza strain appears with very different surface antigens. Many vaccinated people still become sick, and cases spread across several continents in a few months.

orders.text_content: a) Explain two reasons why this new strain can spread widely even in a highly vaccinated population. (2 marks)
b) Suggest two public health actions that could reduce spread of the new strain and briefly link each action to how it limits transmission. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 2 marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{The virus has undergone antigenic shift or a major antigen change, so existing memory B and T cells no longer recognise}\\)
\\(\\text{the new antigen shape.}\\)
\\(\\text{Antibodies from earlier vaccines are no longer complementary to the new surface antigens, so neutralisation is much}\\)
\\(\\text{less effective.}\\)
\\(\\text{Herd immunity drops because many people are effectively ‚Äúnaive‚Äù to the new strain, even if they were vaccinated against}\\)
\\(\\text{the old one.}\\)
\\(\\text{With low effective herd immunity and easy human-to-human spread, the disease can reach epidemic or pandemic}\\)
\\(\\text{levels.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 2 marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{Rapid development and rollout of an updated vaccine, to rebuild immunological memory and restore herd}\\)
\\(\\text{immunity against the new strain.}\\)
\\(\\text{Sscreening and case identification using PCR or similar tests, so infected people can be isolated or quarantined}\\)
\\(\\text{to break chains of transmission.}\\)
\\(\\text{Social strategies such as social distancing, mask use or limiting large gatherings, to reduce person-to-person}\\)
\\(\\text{contact and droplet or airborne spread.}\\)
\\(\\text{Improving hygiene and sterilisation procedures (for example, cleaning shared surfaces or hand hygiene campaigns)}\\)
\\(\\text{to remove viral particles from the environment.}\\)

questions.question_text: A town has 95% vaccination coverage for measles. Most adults and school children are fully vaccinated.
