However, some babies are too young for the full schedule and a few adults refuse vaccines. When a traveller brings measles into the town, only a small number of cases occur.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how high vaccination rates protect babies who are not yet fully vaccinated. (2 marks)
b) Explain what could happen to disease spread if coverage falls from 95% to 75%, even though most individuals are still vaccinated. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Vaccinated people are less likely to get sick and pass on the virus, so there are fewer infected hosts in the community.}\\)
\\(\\text{This creates herd immunity, which lowers the chance that unvaccinated babies will ever meet someone carrying measles.}\\)

\\(\\text{With fewer vaccinated people, the virus can move more easily from one person to another, so herd immunity may}\\)
\\(\\text{be lost.}\\)
\\(\\text{Outbreaks become more likely, because chains of transmission are no longer blocked by immune individuals.}\\)
\\(\\text{Babies, immune-suppressed people and others who cannot be vaccinated now face a much higher risk of exposure}\\)
\\(\\text{and serious disease.}\\)

questions.question_text: An infectious disease was once common in a small, isolated region. Over time, vaccination programs and improved sanitation reduced cases to very low levels. Decades later, declining vaccination rates and antigenic shift in the pathogen lead to large new outbreaks in several major cities.

orders.text_content: a) Classify this disease as emerging or re-emerging and explain two reasons for your choice. (3 marks)
b) The disease now spreads fastest in crowded, low-income neighbourhoods. Explain two host or environmental factors that make these communities more vulnerable. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{This is a re-emerging disease.}\\)
\\(\\text{It was once a major health concern, but case numbers were brought under control, for example through vaccines or}\\)
\\(\\text{effective drugs.}\\)
\\(\\text{Cases have increased again due to factors such as lost herd immunity or antigenic shift, which fits the definition of}\\)
\\(\\text{re-emergence.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{Higher population density in crowded housing increases person-to-person contact, making it easier for the}\\)
\\(\\text{pathogen to spread.}\\)
\\(\\text{Poor sanitation or lack of clean water may support faecal‚Äìoral or contact transmission if the disease spreads that}\\)
\\(\\text{way.}\\)
\\(\\text{Limited access to vaccines or health services may lead to lower vaccination coverage and slower treatment,}\\)
\\(\\text{allowing more spread.}\\)
\\(\\text{Lack of clear education about infection control can reduce uptake of hygiene, PPE or isolation measures.}\\)

questions.question_text: During a respiratory virus outbreak, a school uses two different tests. Students with symptoms take a rapid antigen test at home. Positive results are then confirmed at a clinic using PCR on a nose swab.

orders.text_content: a) Explain one key difference between PCR and a rapid antigen test in how they detect the virus. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the school might use both types of tests instead of relying on just one. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{PCR detects and amplifies viral genetic material (DNA or cDNA from RNA), so it can find very small amounts of virus.}\\)
\\(\\text{A rapid antigen test detects viral proteins directly on the swab, without amplification, so it usually needs more virus}\\)
\\(\\text{present to show a positive result.}\\)

\\(\\text{Rapid antigen tests give quick results at home, so students can decide to stay away from school if they are likely}\\)
\\(\\text{to be infectious.}\\)
\\(\\text{PCR provides more sensitive and reliable confirmation, which is important for official case counts and contact tracing.}\\)
\\(\\text{Using both together balances speed and accuracy, helping to control spread while avoiding too many false results.}\\)

questions.question_text: A hospital investigates a cluster of fever cases. Doctors suspect infection with a known virus but want to confirm quickly. The lab has access to ELISA kits for antibodies, PCR machines and full DNA sequencing services.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how an ELISA could be used as a screening test in this situation and give one strength and one limitation of ELISA for early diagnosis. (4 marks)
b) Explain why DNA sequencing or other molecular tests are preferred when a new or unexpected pathogen is suspected. Refer to one scientific benefit and one public health benefit. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Plates are coated with viral antigen, then patient serum is added; if specific antibodies are present, they bind}\\)
\\(\\text{to the antigen.}\\)
\\(\\text{Enzyme-linked secondary antibodies and a colour change reveal whether the patient has antibodies to that virus.}\\)
\\(\\text{Strength: ELISA can test many samples quickly and is useful to screen a population for exposure or immune response.}\\)
\\(\\text{Limitation: in early infection, the adaptive response may not yet be active, so ELISA can give a false negative when}\\)
\\(\\text{antibodies are not yet present.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of one mark:}\\)
\\(\\text{Scientific benefit: DNA or RNA sequencing can identify the exact pathogen species or strain by its genetic code, even if}\\)
\\(\\text{its antigens are not well known.}\\)
\\(\\text{Scientific benefit: sequencing can track mutations over time, helping scientists follow antigenic drift or shift and}\\)
\\(\\text{understand how the pathogen is changing.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of one mark:}\\)
\\(\\text{Public health benefit: knowing the precise pathogen helps choose effective treatments or design targeted vaccines}\\)
\\(\\text{more quickly.}\\)
\\(\\text{Public health benefit: sequencing data from many patients helps track sources and transmission pathways,}\\)
\\(\\text{which can guide quarantine or travel restrictions.}\\)

questions.question_text: A public health team reviews vaccination data. Infants under six months have low vaccination coverage because many vaccines are scheduled later in the first year. However, most of these babies are breastfed and live in a community with high herd immunity.

orders.text_content: a) Explain two ways that young babies can be protected from severe disease before they complete their own vaccinations. (2 marks)
b) Explain why booster vaccines are needed later in life, even if a person completed their childhood schedule. Refer to memory cells and herd immunity in your answer. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 2 marks}\\)
\\(\\text{IgG antibodies can cross the placenta before birth, giving babies natural passive immunity for a short time after}\\)
\\(\\text{birth.}\\)
\\(\\text{Breast milk supplies IgA and other antibodies, which can protect mucosal surfaces in the baby, again as natural}\\)
\\(\\text{passive immunity.}\\) 
\\(\\text{High herd immunity in the community reduces the number of infectious carriers, lowering the chance that an}\\)
\\(\\text{unvaccinated baby meets the pathogen.}\\)
\\(\\text{Together, passive antibodies and herd immunity reduce severe infections during the period of immunological weakness.}\\)

\\(\\text{Memory B and T cells can decline in number over time if they are not restimulated, so immunological memory}\\)
\\(\\text{weakens.}\\)
\\(\\text{Booster doses re-expose the immune system to antigen, increasing memory cell numbers and restoring fast, strong}\\)
\\(\\text{responses.}\\)
\\(\\text{Maintaining strong individual memory helps sustain herd immunity, reducing spread and protecting vulnerable}\\)
\\(\\text{people.}\\)

questions.question_text: A tropical city uses insecticide sprays to reduce mosquito numbers and control dengue fever. At first, dengue cases fall sharply. Ten years later, mosquito counts rise again and dengue cases return, even though the same insecticide program is still in place.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the insecticide spray worked well in the early years. (2 marks)
b) Explain how insecticide resistance can develop in the mosquito population over time, and why this causes dengue cases to rise again. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Most mosquitoes were sensitive to the insecticide, so large numbers died when exposed.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer mosquitoes to bite people, there were fewer opportunities for the dengue virus to spread between hosts.}\\)

\\(\\text{Some mosquitoes carry mutations that help them survive the insecticide; these resistant mosquitoes are}\\)
\\(\\text{more likely to live and breed.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over many generations, the resistant genes become more common, so a larger share of the mosquito population}\\)
\\(\\text{can survive spraying.}\\)
\\(\\text{As resistant mosquitoes increase, more biting and virus transmission occur again, so dengue cases in humans}\\)
\\(\\text{start to rise.}\\)

questions.question_text: A new respiratory virus spreads by droplets and contaminated surfaces. A government considers different strategies: mask mandates, improving hand hygiene, better ventilation in public buildings, PCR screening in schools, and vaccine development.

orders.text_content: a) Describe two scientific strategies and two social strategies that could be used together to reduce spread of this virus. (2 marks)
b) Explain why relying on only one of these strategies is risky when dealing with a highly contagious pathogen. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of one mark}\\)
\\(\\text{Scientific strategy: vaccination programs to create artificial active immunity and herd immunity in the population.}\\)
\\(\\text{Scientific strategy: PCR testing to identify infected individuals so they can isolate and break chains of transmission.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of one mark}\\)
\\(\\text{Social strategy: social distancing and mask use in crowded indoor spaces to reduce droplet and airborne transmission.}\\)
\\(\\text{Social strategy: hand-washing and surface cleaning campaigns to remove virus from hands and fomites, limiting indirect}\\)
\\(\\text{contact.}\\)

\\(\\text{No single strategy is perfect; for example, vaccines may not cover all variants, and some people cannot be vaccinated.}\\) 
\\(\\text{Diagnostic testing alone does not prevent transmission if people are not isolated or if contacts still occur without}\\)
\\(\\text{ protection.}\\)
\\(\\text{Combining tools (for example, vaccines, testing, masks and hygiene) builds multiple barriers to spread, which is more}\\)
\\(\\text{effective for a highly contagious pathogen.}\\)

questions.question_text: Doctors are trialling two monoclonal antibody drugs. Drug A binds to a cytokine that drives inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis. Drug B binds to a growth factor receptor on certain cancer cells, flagging them for destruction by immune cells.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how Drug A works as suppression immunotherapy in an autoimmune disease. Include two effects on the immune response. (4 marks)
b) Explain how Drug B acts as activation immunotherapy against cancer and suggest one potential risk of this approach. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Drug A is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to a pro- inflammatory cytokine.}\\)
\\(\\text{By binding the cytokine, it reduces signalling between immune cells, lowering clonal expansion or activation of}\\)
\\(\\text{autoreactive lymphocytes.}\\)
\\(\\text{This decreases the destruction of self-tissues in joints, reducing symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.}\\)
\\(\\text{Overall immune function is also reduced, which may increase susceptibility to other infections.}\\)

\\(\\text{Drug B is a monoclonal antibody that binds to a cancer cell antigen or growth factor receptor, marking the cell for}\\)
\\(\\text{attack by natural killer cells or cytotoxic T cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{This increases immune activity against tumour cells, helping the body clear them more effectively.}\\)
\\(\\text{An increased immune response may also damage some normal cells with similar antigens or increase the chance}\\)
\\(\\text{of autoimmune-like side effects.}\\)

questions.question_text: Researchers are developing a vaccine for a new viral disease with a high death rate. One team suggests using a live, fully virulent virus at low dose to create strong immunity. Another team suggests an attenuated or antigen-only vaccine. An ethics committee reviews both proposals.

orders.text_content: a) Using bioethical principles, explain two reasons why a live, fully virulent virus vaccine would raise serious concerns. (2 marks)
b) Explain why an attenuated or antigen-only vaccine is usually preferred, referring to both immunological effectiveness and ethics. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks}\\)
\\(\\text{A live, virulent virus has a high chance of causing severe disease in some recipients, which conflicts with the}\\)
\\(\\text{principle of non-maleficence (do no harm).}\\)
\\(\\text{Even if consent is obtained, the risk of severe harm or death may be viewed as unacceptable compared to safer}\\)
\\(\\text{alternatives.}\\)
\\(\\text{Such a vaccine could also spread to vulnerable people who did not consent, which conflicts with respect for autonomy}\\)
\\(\\text{and justice.}\\) 
\\(\\text{If safer options exist, using a very risky design may also violate beneficence, which requires balancing benefits}\\)
\\(\\text{against harms.}\\)

\\(\\text{Attenuated or antigen-only vaccines still present viral antigens to the immune system, allowing development of}\\)
\\(\\text{memory B and T cells and long-term artificial active immunity.}\\)
\\(\\text{These vaccines have a much lower chance of causing full-blown disease, so they better meet non-maleficence while}\\)
\\(\\text{still providing strong protection.}\\)
\\(\\text{Safer vaccines improve public trust and uptake, helping to build herd immunity and protect vulnerable groups,}\\)
\\(\\text{which supports justice and beneficence.}\\)

questions.question_text: A patient with a high-risk exposure to a virus is given both a vaccine and a monoclonal antibody infusion. The vaccine contains viral antigens. The monoclonal infusion contains ready-made antibodies that bind strongly to the virus.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how the vaccine helps protect the patient in the medium to long term. (3 marks)
b) Explain how the monoclonal antibody infusion helps in the short term and give one reason it does not give long-lasting immunity. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The vaccine‚Äôs viral antigens are taken up by antigen-presenting cells and shown to T helper cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{Matching B cells are activated, undergo clonal expansion and differentiate into plasma cells and memory B cells.}\\)
\\(\\text{Memory B cells stay in the body and can produce antibodies quickly if the patient meets the live virus later.}\\)

\\(\\text{The monoclonal antibodies can bind and neutralise the virus immediately, without waiting for the patient‚Äôs own immune}\\)
\\(\\text{response.}\\)
\\(\\text{The antibodies are not produced by the patient‚Äôs own cells and will be broken down over time, so no memory cells are}\\)
\\(\\text{made and protection is short-lived.}\\)

questions.question_text: Researchers plan a trial for a new vaccine. Volunteers are randomly placed in two groups. One group receives the vaccine; the other receives a placebo injection with no active ingredient. Volunteers do not know which group they are in, but all are told about possible risks and can leave the study at any time.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why randomising volunteers into vaccine and placebo groups is important for good science. (2 marks)
b) Name two bioethical principles that are being supported in this trial design and briefly link each one to a feature of the study. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Randomisation makes it more likely that both groups are similar in age, health and other factors at the start of the}\\)
\\(\\text{trial.}\\)
\\(\\text{This means differences in infection rates at the end are more likely due to the vaccine, not other hidden variables.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks.}\\)
\\(\\text{Autonomy / respect: volunteers receive clear information and can withdraw at any time, so they control their own}\\)
\\(\\text{participation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Justice: random assignment and equal treatment of groups help ensure that risks and benefits are shared fairly.}\\)
\\(\\text{Beneficence / non-maleficence: careful monitoring and safety checks aim to maximise possible benefits while}\\)
\\(\\text{reducing harm to participants.}\\)

questions.question_text: A teacher shows students this four-panel diagram of different ways to gain immunity.

orders.text_content: a) For each panel, name the type of immunity (natural/ artificial, active/ passive). (4 marks)
b) Explain one key difference between ‚Äúactive‚Äù and ‚Äúpassive‚Äù immunity shown in this diagram. (2 marks)
c) Which panels show immunity that is likely to last longer, and why? Refer to memory cells in your answer. (3 marks)
d) A community wants to reduce measles outbreaks. Which panel best represents the main strategy they should use, and why? (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Panel 1: Natural active immunity, because infection happens naturally and the person‚Äôs own immune system}\\)
\\(\\text{responds.}\\)
\\(\\text{Panel 2: Natural passive immunity, because antibodies cross the placenta from parent to baby without the baby}\\)
\\(\\text{making them.}\\)
\\(\\text{Panel 3: Artificial active immunity, because a vaccine (medical procedure) gives antigen and stimulates the}\\)
\\(\\text{person‚Äôs own immune response.}\\)
\\(\\text{Panel 4: Artificial passive immunity, because antivenom antibodies are given by injection from an external source.}\\)

\\(\\text{In active immunity (Panels 1 and 3), the person‚Äôs own B and T cells are activated by antigen and produce antibodies.}\\)
\\(\\text{In passive immunity (Panels 2 and 4), ready-made antibodies are received from another individual or species, so the}\\)
\\(\\text{recipient‚Äôs adaptive response is not activated.}\\)

\\(\\text{Panels 1 and 3 (natural active and artificial active) usually give longer-lasting protection.}\\)
\\(\\text{Active responses create memory B and T cells, which can respond quickly on later exposure to the same antigen.}\\)
\\(\\text{Passive immunity (Panels 2 and 4) does not make memory cells, so protection fades as the donated antibodies}\\)
\\(\\text{are broken down.}\\)

\\(\\text{Panel 3 (artificial active immunity from vaccination) is the main strategy.}\\)
\\(\\text{Mass vaccination builds herd immunity, reducing spread of measles and protecting those who cannot be vaccinated,}\\)
\\(\\text{such as some babies.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A public health team models a respiratory disease outbreak under three scenarios: no controls, early masks and distancing only, and early masks plus a strong vaccine rollout.

The graph shows number of cases over time for each scenario:
‚Ä¢ Curve A represents no controls.
‚Ä¢ Curve B represents masks and distancing introduced early.
‚Ä¢ Curve C represents masks and distancing plus an early vaccine rollout.

On the x-axis:
‚Ä¢ Point X marks when the first cases are detected.
‚Ä¢ Point Y marks when public health measures (masks and distancing) are introduced.
‚Ä¢ Point Z marks when the vaccine rollout begins.

orders.text_content: a) Describe how Curve A and Curve B differ and explain what this difference shows about masks and distancing. (3 marks)
b) Explain why Curve C has the lowest peak, even though masks and distancing are also used in Curve B. (3 marks)
c) At which event (X, Y or Z) would you expect the effective reproduction number (R) to start falling below 1 in Curve C, and why? (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Curve A has a sharper rise and higher peak than Curve B.}\\)
\\(\\text{Curve B‚Äôs peak is lower and spread over a longer time than Curve A.}\\)
\\(\\text{This shows that masks and distancing reduce the rate of transmission, so cases grow more slowly and at any one-}\\)
\\(\\text{time fewer people are infected.}\\)

\\(\\text{Curve C includes both public health measures and a vaccine rollout, so more people become immune over time.}\\)
\\(\\text{Vaccination reduces the number of susceptible hosts, making it harder for the pathogen to find new people to infect.}\\)
\\(\\text{Together, vaccines plus masks and distancing push the effective reproduction number (R) below 1 more quickly, so the}\\)
\\(\\text{outbreak is smaller overall.}\\)

\\(\\text{R may begin to fall towards or just below 1 soon after Y and more clearly after Z in Curve C.}\\)
\\(\\text{Y marks the start of masks and distancing (fewer contacts), and Z adds vaccination (fewer susceptible people), so}\\)
\\(\\text{combined they cut spread enough that each case infects fewer than one new person on average.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A small population of lizard‚Äôs lives on a single rocky outcrop in the desert. Researchers record that this population has very low genetic diversity when they sample its DNA. A nearby mainland population of the same species has many more alleles at most gene loci.

Which statement best explains why the mainland population has greater adaptive potential?

orders.text_content:
A. It has fewer alleles, so mutations are rarer
B. It has a larger, more diverse gene pool with more alleles
C. It has no mutations, so its genome is stable
D. It has no selection pressures acting on it

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. A larger, more diverse gene pool means more alleles are present, giving greater genetic diversity and}\\)
\\(\\text{adaptive potential when new selection pressures arise.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A bird species lives both on a large mainland and on a small offshore island. Climate change causes a long heatwave and drought over several years. On the mainland, most birds survive. On the island, many die and the population becomes very small, with only a few breeders left. Decades later, both populations have recovered in size, but the island birds show much lower genetic diversity.

Which process best explains the genetic pattern in the island population?

orders.text_content:
A. Gene flow from many different mainland populations
B. Genetic drift following a population bottleneck
C. Natural selection with no change in allele frequencies
D. Increased mutation rate restoring original diversity

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. A severe, random reduction in population size due to drought is a population bottleneck. The small surviving group}\\)
\\(\\text{has an unrepresentative gene pool, so genetic drift reduces genetic diversity even after numbers recover.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which pair of processes both tend to increase genetic diversity in a population‚Äôs gene pool?

orders.text_content:
A. Genetic drift and founder effect
B. Mutations and gene flow
C. Selective breeding and bottleneck events
D. Natural selection and inbreeding

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Mutations create new alleles, and gene flow introduces alleles from another population, so both increase}\\)
\\(\\text{genetic diversity.}\\)

questions.question_text:
In a frog population, a dominant allele A gives darker skin, while a recessive allele a gives lighter skin. Initially, both colours are common. After a volcanic eruption covers the area with dark ash, predators easily see light frogs. Over several generations, dark frogs become far more common, and the frequency of A rises.

Which statement best explains this change?

orders.text_content:
A. Light frogs mutate into dark frogs when ash is present
B. Dark frogs are better camouflaged, so survive and reproduce more
C. Ash directly converts allele a into allele A
D. Frogs choose to develop darker skin during their lifetime

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The ash acts as an environmental selection pressure. Dark frogs with allele A are less visible, so they are more likely}\\)
\\(\\text{to survive to reproduce and pass on A, increasing its frequency via natural selection.}\\)

questions.question_text: A population of insects is exposed to a new pesticide. At first, only a few individuals carry a resistance allele. After several seasons of spraying, the frequency of the resistance allele matches the pattern shown in the graph below.

orders.text_content:
Which option best explains this pattern?

A. The pesticide creates new resistance alleles in every generation
B. Pre-existing resistant insects survive spraying and pass on their alleles
C. The pesticide eliminates all mutations from the gene pool
D. Resistance alleles appear only after spraying stops

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. There is pre-existing genetic variation. Spraying acts as a selection pressure that kills susceptible insects,}\\)
\\(\\text{while resistant ones survive and reproduce, so the resistance allele increases in frequency over time via natural selection.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A hospital uses the same antibiotic widely for many years. At first, almost all bacterial infections respond well. Over time, doctors notice that higher doses are needed, and some infections no longer clear with this drug, even when patients take it correctly.

Which description best explains how resistant bacteria became common?

orders.text_content:
A. Bacteria learned to avoid the drug by changing behaviour
B. The antibiotic directly taught bacteria to make new genes
C. Bacteria with resistance alleles survived treatment and passed these alleles on
D. Patients‚Äô immune systems became weaker and stopped killing bacteria

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Pre-existing resistant bacteria survive antibiotic treatment, while non-resistant ones die. The survivors reproduce}\\)
\\(\\text{and pass on resistance alleles, so resistant strains become more common in the population over time.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which situation best illustrates the founder effect?

orders.text_content:
A. A large population is reduced by a flood, then recovers
B. A few individuals colonise a new island and start a new population
C. Many migrants move between two nearby cities and interbreed
D. A population experiences strong stabilising selection around a mean

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The founder effect occurs when a small, unrepresentative group leaves an existing population and starts a new}\\)
\\(\\text{population, often with reduced genetic diversity and shifted allele frequencies.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A fish species once had a large, genetically diverse population in a lake. Heavy pollution kills most fish, leaving only a few survivors. These survivors are then selectively bred in captivity for fast growth and bright colour before being released back into the lake.

Which combination best describes the main genetic consequences of these events?

orders.text_content:
A. Population bottleneck followed by gene flow
B. Gene flow followed by natural selection
C. Population bottleneck followed by human-induced bottleneck from selective breeding
D. Founder effect followed by mutations restoring diversity

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. The pollution causes a population bottleneck that sharply reduces genetic diversity. Intensive selective breeding}\\)
\\(\\text{then favours a narrow set of traits, further reducing diversity and acting as a human-induced bottleneck.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which statement correctly contrasts gene flow and genetic drift?

orders.text_content:
A. Both always increase genetic diversity
B. Gene flow moves alleles between populations; drift changes allele frequencies by chance within a population
C. Gene flow is random; drift always follows selection
D. Gene flow only occurs after natural disasters; drift only during migration

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Gene flow is the movement of alleles between populations through interbreeding, usually increasing diversity.}\\)
\\(\\text{Genetic drift is a random change in allele frequencies within a population, often reducing diversity, especially in}\\)
\\(\\text{small populations.}\\)

questions.question_text: A mammal population is split into two groups when a large river changes course and permanently divides their habitat. No individuals cross the river. Over thousands of years, each group experiences different climates and predators.

orders.text_content:
Which outcome best describes what may eventually happen?

A. The two groups remain identical forever because they are the same species
B. Gene flow increases, so allele frequencies become more similar
C. The two groups accumulate genetic differences and may become separate species
D. The two groups become sterile, and both go extinct immediately

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. A geographic barrier blocking gene flow means each population faces different selection pressures, mutations}\\)
\\(\\text{and drift. Over time, allele frequencies diverge, and the groups may become different species that cannot interbreed to}\\)
\\(\\text{produce viable, fertile offspring.}\\)

questions.question_text:
On an island, two palm tree populations share the same forest but grow in different soil types. One population grows in very acidic soil and flowers earlier in the year. The other grows in neutral soil and flowers later. Pollen from one group rarely reaches receptive flowers in the other group.

Which type of barrier is most important in this example?

orders.text_content:
A. Geographic barrier causing allopatric speciation
B. Temporal barrier contributing to sympatric speciation
C. Mechanical barrier caused by different flower structure
D. post-zygotic barrier caused by hybrid infertility

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Different flowering times act as a temporal pre-zygotic barrier within the same area, reducing gene flow between}\\)
\\(\\text{the palm groups and contributing to sympatric speciation.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which option best defines an environmental selection pressure?

orders.text_content:
A. Any random event that changes allele frequency
B. A factor in the environment that affects survival and reproduction of phenotypes
C. Any mutation that appears in the gene pool
D. Any human preference for a trait in selective breeding

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. An environmental selection pressure is a factor such as climate, food availability or predators that affects which}\\)
\\(\\text{phenotypes survive and reproduce, influencing allele frequencies over time.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Influenza viruses slowly change their surface antigens over many years. People who had the flu or were vaccinated five years ago may still have partial protection, but new vaccines are recommended each season to better match circulating strains.

Which term best describes this long-term pattern of change?

orders.text_content:
A. Antigenic shift
B. Antigenic drift
C. Genetic drift in humans
D. Founder effect in viruses

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Antigenic drift is the gradual accumulation of small changes in viral surface antigens over time, reducing the match}\\)
\\(\\text{with existing immune memory and requiring updated vaccines.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which statement best describes a key difference between natural selection and selective breeding?

orders.text_content:
A. Natural selection reduces genetic diversity; selective breeding increases it
B. Natural selection is driven by environmental pressures; selective breeding is driven by human choice
C. Natural selection requires small populations; selective breeding needs large populations
D. Natural selection only affects plants; selective breeding only affects animals

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In natural selection, the environment decides which phenotypes are most fit, while in selective breeding, humans}\\)
\\(\\text{choose which traits to favour and breed, acting as the selection pressure.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A dog breed has been intensively inbred over many generations to fix a desired coat colour. The breed now has a high rate of inherited heart defects caused by a recessive allele.

Which process best explains the rise of this harmful allele?

orders.text_content:
A. Gene flow from wild dog populations
B. Natural selection favouring heart defects
C. Inbreeding increasing the chance that two carriers‚Äô mate
D. Mutations only in somatic cells

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Inbreeding means related individuals, who are more likely to share the same recessive allele, mate with each}\\)
\\(\\text{other. This increases the chance of offspring inheriting two copies of a harmful recessive allele and expressing the}\\)
\\(\\text{condition.}\\)

questions.question_text: A virus infects many people worldwide. Years later, a ‚Äúnew‚Äù strain appears with slightly altered surface proteins. People who had the original infection sometimes still get sick, but often with milder symptoms. A new vaccine is developed that matches the new strain‚Äôs antigens more closely.

orders.text_content:
Which statement best explains why the new vaccine is needed?

A. The virus has undergone antigenic drift, weakening the fit of existing antibodies
B. Human memory cells have completely disappeared after a few years
C. The virus has become a bacterium, so old vaccines no longer work
D. The virus can no longer infect human cells at all

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Gradual antigenic drift changes viral surface antigens so that older antibodies and memory cells bind less}\\)
\\(\\text{effectively, reducing protection and making updated vaccines useful.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which mutation is most likely to be passed on to the next generation?

orders.text_content:
A. A point mutation in a skin cell caused by sunlight
B. A block mutation in a liver cell during adulthood
C. A frameshift mutation in a sperm or egg cell
D. A missense mutation in a neuron after birth

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Only mutations in gametes (germline cells) can be inherited by offspring; mutations in somatic cells are not}\\)
\\(\\text{passed to the next generation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A gene normally has the codons:

AUG‚ÄìGAA‚ÄìCCU‚ÄìGGU‚ÄìUGA

In one individual, a single base substitution changes GAA to GUA. In another individual, a single base deletion occurs at the second base of GAA.

Which statement best compares these two mutations?

orders.text_content:
A. Both are silent mutations with no effect on the protein
B. The substitution is a missense mutation; the deletion is a frameshift mutation with larger impact
C. Both are nonsense mutations that create early stop codons
D. The substitution is a frameshift; the deletion is silent

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. A substitution that changes one codon‚Äôs amino acid is a missense mutation. A single-base deletion shifts the}\\)
\\(\\text{reading frame, changing all downstream codons and often causing a major disruption to the protein, which is a}\\)
\\(\\text{frameshift mutation.}\\)

\\(\\text{B. A substitution that changes one codon‚Äôs amino acid is a missense mutation. A single-base deletion shifts the}\\)
\\(\\text{reading frame, changing all downstream codons and often causing a major disruption to the protein, which is a}\\)
\\(\\text{frameshift mutation.}\\)

questions.question_text: Two bird populations live on separate islands. Some birds from Island 2 migrate to Island 1 and successfully breed with locals. After several generations, the frequency of allele A has increased on Island 1 and slightly decreased on Island 2.

orders.text_content:
Which process best explains this pattern?

A. Genetic drift due to random disasters
B. Natural selection with no migration
C. Gene flow introducing and removing alleles between populations
D. Founder effect starting a new population

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Migration and interbreeding between populations cause gene flow, which introduces allele A into Island 1 and}\\)
\\(\\text{removes it from Island 2, changing allele frequencies in both populations.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which combination correctly groups processes that decrease genetic diversity in a population?

orders.text_content:
A. Immigration, mutations, gene flow
B. Genetic drift, founder effect, population bottleneck
C. Gene flow, selective breeding, mutations
D. Natural selection, gene flow, polyploidy

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Genetic drift, founder effect and population bottlenecks all involve random or sampling effects that can remove}\\)
\\(\\text{alleles from a population and reduce genetic diversity.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A small island population of lizards has lived in the same stable climate for thousands of years. DNA tests show very low genetic diversity and only a few alleles at most gene loci. A mainland population of the same species shows many more alleles, including different colour and heat-tolerance variants. 

Climate records suggest that heatwaves and droughts will become more common across both habitats over the next 50 years.

orders.text_content: a) Explain what is meant by the ‚Äúgene pool‚Äù of a population, using this example. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the mainland population is likely to have greater adaptive potential under future heatwaves than the island population. (3 marks)
c) Describe one way that new alleles could enter the island population‚Äôs gene pool, and briefly explain how this would affect genetic diversity. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The gene pool is the complete set of all alleles present in the lizard population at a given time.}\\)
\\(\\text{In this example, the island population has a small, less diverse gene pool, while the mainland population has}\\)
\\(\\text{many different alleles in its gene pool.}\\)

\\(\\text{The mainland population has greater genetic diversity, because it has more alleles at many gene loci.}\\)
\\(\\text{This increases the chance that some lizards already carry alleles for traits like heat tolerance that give an advantage}\\)
\\(\\text{under new selection pressures.}\\)
\\(\\text{As the climate changes, these advantageous alleles can be favoured by natural selection, increasing in}\\)
\\(\\text{frequency and helping the population survive.}\\)

\\(\\text{One mark for either of the following, to a maximum of one mark:}\\)
\\(\\text{New alleles could enter the island population through gene flow, for example if a few mainland lizards migrate to}\\)
\\(\\text{the island and successfully interbreed.}\\)
\\(\\text{This would increase the genetic diversity of the island gene pool, giving it more alleles and potentially more}\\)
\\(\\text{adaptive potential.}\\)

questions.question_text: A fish species in a large lake has a big, genetically diverse population. A toxic spill kills almost all the fish, leaving only 50 survivors. Over the next decade, these survivors breed and the population returns to its original size, but genetic tests show much lower diversity and several alleles have been lost.

orders.text_content: a) Name the process that occurred when the toxic spill reduced the population and explain how it affected allele frequencies. (3 marks)
b) Explain why this fish population may now be more at risk of extinction if a new disease or temperature change occurs in the lake. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The process is a population bottleneck, a type of genetic drift.}\\)
\\(\\text{The small group of 50 survivors had an unrepresentative sample of the original alleles by random chance.}\\)
\\(\\text{As these survivors bred, allele frequencies in the rebuilt population reflected only their alleles, so some original alleles}\\)
\\(\\text{were lost and overall diversity fell.}\\)

\\(\\text{The population now has lower genetic diversity, because some alleles were removed during the bottleneck.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer different alleles, it is less likely that any individuals carry a favourable allele that gives resistance to the}\\)
\\(\\text{new disease or tolerance to the new temperature}\\)
\\(\\text{This reduced adaptive potential means the whole population is more likely to decline or go extinct when new}\\)
\\(\\text{selection pressures appear.}\\)

questions.question_text: A small island bird population has low genetic diversity and some signs of inbreeding, such as deformities in chicks. Conservation workers move a group of unrelated birds from the large mainland population to the island. Ten years later, genetic tests show more alleles at several loci and fewer deformities in chicks.

orders.text_content: a) Name the process that occurred when mainland birds joined the island population and explain how it changed the island gene pool. (3 marks)
b) Explain how this increase in genetic diversity can reduce the risk of harmful recessive conditions in the island population. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The process is gene flow between the mainland and island populations.}\\)
\\(\\text{Migrant birds interbred with island birds, bringing in alleles that were not present or were rare on the island.}\\)
\\(\\text{This increased the genetic diversity of the island gene pool by adding new alleles.}\\)

\\(\\text{With more alleles, island birds are less likely to be closely related, so two carriers of the same harmful recessive}\\)
\\(\\text{allele are less likely to mate.}\\)
\\(\\text{This lowers the chance that offspring inherit two copies of a harmful recessive allele, reducing the frequency of those}\\)
\\(\\text{conditions.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A bird species lives on a continent and several nearby islands.

- Every year, some birds fly between Island X and the mainland, mate, and raise young in both places.
- Once in the past, a hurricane blew a tiny group of five birds to a new, very distant island. They started a new population there, and no birds have arrived since.

orders.text_content: a) For the regular movement between Island X and the mainland, name the process and explain its effect on genetic diversity in Island X. (3 marks)

b) For the new, distant island, name the specific form of genetic drift that occurred and explain why this new population may have a very different allele frequency pattern from the mainland. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The process is gene flow between Island X and the mainland.}\\)
\\(\\text{Migrating birds bring alleles from the mainland and mix them into the Island Xgene pool through interbreeding.}\\)
\\(\\text{This tends to increase genetic diversity on Island X, because new alleles are added to its gene pool.}\\)

\\(\\text{The event is a founder effect, a type of genetic drift.}\\)
\\(\\text{Only five birds founded the new population, so their alleles were a random, unrepresentative sample of the}\\)
\\(\\text{mainland gene pool.}\\)
\\(\\text{As these few founders bred in isolation, their alleles set the baseline frequencies, often leading to lower diversity and}\\)
\\(\\text{different allele frequencies compared with the mainland.}\\)

questions.question_text: A large mammal population once occupied a continuous forest. A deep river forms and permanently divides the forest into two halves. No individuals cross the river. Over many thousands of years, one side becomes cooler and wetter with dense undergrowth, while the other side becomes warmer and drier grassland. Different predators and food sources exist on each side.

orders.text_content: a) Name the type of speciation most likely to occur here and identify the barrier involved. (2 marks)
b) Using correct speciation terminology, explain how two different species could evolve from this original population over a long time. (4 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The type of speciation is allopatric speciation.}\\)
\\(\\text{The key barrier is a geographic barrier, in this case the deep river.}\\)

\\(\\text{The river prevents gene flow and interbreeding between the two groups, so they remain reproductively isolated.}\\)
\\(\\text{Each group experiences different selection pressures, such as different climates, predators and food sources, as}\\)
\\(\\text{well as different random mutations and genetic drift.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over many generations, these factors cause allele frequencies to diverge, leading to the accumulation of}\\)
\\(\\text{genetic differences.}\\)
\\(\\text{Eventually, the two populations become so different that they can no longer interbreed to produce viable,}\\)
\\(\\text{fertile offspring, so they are now different species.}\\)

questions.question_text: Two plant populations of the same species live on the same island. One group grows on very acidic volcanic soil and flowers in early spring. The other grows on neutral soil and flowers in late spring. Pollinators usually visit only plants that are flowering at that time. Mixed-soil transplant experiments show that plants moved to the ‚Äúwrong‚Äù soil change their flowering time over generations.

orders.text_content: a) Name the type of speciation that may be occurring and identify the main pre-zygotic barrier in this example. (3 marks)
b) Explain how soil type and flowering time together can promote speciation over many generations, even without a geographic barrier. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The likely type of speciation is sympatric speciation, because both groups live in the same general area.}\\)
\\(\\text{The main barrier is a temporal pre-zygotic barrier, because the two groups flower at different times.}\\)
\\(\\text{This timing difference means that pollen from one group rarely reaches receptive flowers in the other, reducing}\\)
\\(\\text{gene flow.}\\)

\\(\\text{Different soil types of act as selection pressures, favouring different traits in each habitat, such as root or flowering-}\\)
\\(\\text{ime genes.}\\)
\\(\\text{Because flowering times differ, interbreeding between the two groups is reduced, so gene flow is limited.}\\)
\\(\\text{With limited gene flow, different selection pressures and mutations cause the two groups to accumulate genetic}\\)
\\(\\text{differences, which can eventually lead to separate species that cannot interbreed.}\\)

questions.question_text: A dog breed is selectively bred for a flat face and large eyes because many people find this look appealing. Breeders choose only the flattest-faced dogs to mate. After many generations, the breed is very uniform in appearance but has high rates of breathing problems and eye injuries. Genetic tests show very low genetic diversity compared with ancestral dog populations.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how selective breeding caused a reduction in genetic diversity in this dog breed. (3 marks)
b) Suggest two reasons why this loss of genetic diversity can be harmful for the long-term health and survival of the breed. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Humans acted as the selection pressure, repeatedly choosing only dogs with extreme flat faces to breed.}\\)
\\(\\text{This strong artificial selection favoured one set of alleles while many other alleles were not passed on, reducing the}\\)
\\(\\text{range of phenotypes.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over time, this created a human-induced bottleneck, where the breed‚Äôs gene pool became dominated by a}\\)
\\(\\text{narrow set of alleles and lost much of its original diversity.}\\)

\\(\\text{One mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{Inbreeding within a small gene pool increases the chance that harmful recessive alleles pair up, raising the frequency}\\)
\\(\\text{of inherited health problems.}\\)
\\(\\text{With few alleles, the breed has lower adaptive potential, so it may struggle to
cope with new}\\)
\\(\\text{diseases or environmental changes that affect dogs.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some of the selected traits (for example, extreme flat face) may not be beneficial for survival or welfare, leading to}\\)
\\(\\text{chronic health issues even in normal conditions.}\\)

questions.question_text: A hospital uses the same antibiotic to treat a common bacterial infection for many years. At first, almost all infections clear with a standard dose. Later, some patients fail treatment even when they take the drug correctly. Lab tests show that a small number of bacteria already carried a resistance allele before the antibiotic was introduced.

orders.text_content: a) Using correct natural selection language, explain how the resistant bacterial strain became more common over time. (4 marks)
b) Explain why misuse of antibiotics, such as using them for viral infections or stopping early, can speed up the evolution of resistance. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{There was pre-existing genetic variation in the bacterial population; some cells were resistant, others were}\\)
\\(\\text{not.}\\)
\\(\\text{The antibiotic acted as an environmental selection pressure, killing most non-resistant bacteria and giving}\\)
\\(\\text{resistant ones a survival advantage.}\\)
\\(\\text{Resistant bacteria were more likely to survive and reproduce, passing their advantageous resistance alleles}\\)
\\(\\text{to offspring.}\\) 
\\(\\text{Over many generations, the frequency of resistance alleles increased in the bacterial gene pool, so resistant}\\)
\\(\\text{strains became more common.}\\)

\\(\\text{Misuse exposes bacteria to frequent or incomplete courses of antibiotics, creating a strong and repeated selection}\\)
\\(\\text{pressure.}\\)
\\(\\text{Each exposure kills many non-resistant bacteria, but any resistant ones survive and multiply, spreading resistance}\\)
\\(\\text{alleles faster.}\\)
\\(\\text{Using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the number of selection events, giving more chances for}\\)
\\(\\text{resistant strains to dominate.}\\)

questions.question_text: A cattle breed is selectively bred for very high milk yield. Farmers keep only the highest-producing cows and bulls to breed. After many generations, the herd has very uniform milk yield but also high rates of joint problems and low fertility. Genetic tests show that many alleles present in the original herd are now missing.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how selective breeding created a human-induced bottleneck in this herd. (3 marks)
b) Give two reasons why this reduced genetic diversity can cause long-term problems for the herd. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Farmers acted as the selection pressure, repeatedly choosing only a small group of high-yield animals to breed.}\\)
\\(\\text{This meant that only their alleles were passed on, while alleles in the rest of the herd were lost from the gene pool.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over generations, this strong focus on one trait caused a large reduction in genetic diversity, like a bottleneck.}\\)

\\(\\text{One mark for each of the following, to a maximum of two marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{Inbreeding within a narrow gene pool increases the chance of harmful recessive alleles pairing, leading to more}\\)
\\(\\text{inherited health issues.}\\)
\\(\\text{With fewer alleles, the herd has lower adaptive potential, so it may cope poorly with new diseases, climate changes}\\)
\\(\\text{or feed shortages.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some selected traits, like extreme high yield, may be linked to reduced fertility or joint problems, which harm}\\)
\\(\\text{welfare and productivity.}\\)

questions.question_text: Every year, health agencies track influenza viruses around the world. For many seasons, they observe slow changes in surface antigens. Vaccines are updated each year to match the most common strains. Then, a new flu strain appears with a completely different combination of surface antigens. It spreads quickly and causes a worldwide pandemic.

orders.text_content: a) Name and distinguish the two processes that explain (i) the slow yearly changes and (ii) the sudden major change in surface antigens. (4 marks)
b) Explain why regular vaccine updates are needed to manage antigenic drift, but why even well-vaccinated populations can struggle when an antigenic shift occurs. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The slow yearly changes are due to antigenic drift, where many small mutations accumulate over time in viral}\\)
\\(\\text{surface antigen genes.}\\)
\\(\\text{These small changes gradually reduce how well old antibodies and memory cells bind, but some partial immunity}\\)
\\(\\text{often remains.}\\)
\\(\\text{The sudden major change is due to antigenic shift, where two or more different viral strains recombine to}\\)
\\(\\text{produce a virus with a new set of surface antigens.}\\)
\\(\\text{Because the new antigen pattern is very different, existing immune memory in the population is poor or absent,}\\)
\\(\\text{making pandemics more likely.}\\)

\\(\\text{With antigenic drift, updating vaccines each year to match the latest antigens keeps antibodies and memory cells}\\)
\\(\\text{well-matched to circulating strains.}\\)
\\(\\text{When antigenic shift happens, the new virus may be so different that existing vaccines and immune memory}\\)
\\(\\text{offer little protection at first.}\\)
\\(\\text{Populations may then face high infection rates until a new vaccine is developed and widely distributed, and herd}\\)
\\(\\text{immunity builds again.}\\)

questions.question_text: A moth species lives in a forest. Before a major fire, most tree trunks are pale, and pale moths are harder for birds to see. After repeated fires, many trunks are blackened by soot and charcoal. Over several decades, dark moths become more common while pale moths become rare.

orders.text_content: a) Using correct natural selection language, explain why dark moths became more common after the fires. (3 marks)
b) Explain why this example shows natural selection rather than selective breeding. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{There was pre-existing genetic variation in the moth population, with both pale and dark colour phenotypes.}\\)
\\(\\text{After the fires, darker trunks acted as a new selection pressure that made dark moths harder for predators to see, so}\\)
\\(\\text{dark moths had a survival and reproductive advantage.}\\)
\\(\\text{Dark moths were more likely to survive and reproduce, so the alleles for dark colour increased in frequency in the}\\)
\\(\\text{gene pool over generations.}\\)

\\(\\text{The environment (burnt forest and bird predation) is the selection pressure, not human choice.}\\)
\\(\\text{No humans are choosing which moths breed, so this is natural selection, not selective breeding.}\\)

questions.question_text: Early scientists like Lamarck suggested that giraffes developed long necks because they stretched to reach leaves during their lifetime and then passed this stretched trait to their offspring. Darwin later argued that variation in neck length already existed, and natural selection favoured longer necks where food was high in trees.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why Lamarck‚Äôs idea about giraffe necks does not match modern genetics. (2 marks)
b) Using natural selection language, describe how long necks could evolve in a giraffe population over many generations. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Lamarck suggested that traits gained during life, like a stretched neck, are acquired characteristics that can be}\\)
\\(\\text{directly passed to offspring.}\\)
\\(\\text{Modern genetics shows that only heritable genetic changes in gametes, not body changes from use, are passed}\\)
\\(\\text{to offspring, so Lamarck‚Äôs idea is not supported.}\\)

\\(\\text{There was pre-existing variation in neck length in the population due to different alleles.}\\)
\\(\\text{In environments where leaves were high, giraffes with longer necks had a feeding and survival advantage, so}\\)
\\(\\text{they were more likely to live long enough to reproduce.}\\)
\\(\\text{These individuals passed on their long-neck alleles, so the frequency of those alleles increased over generations,}\\)
\\(\\text{and the average neck length increased.}\\)

questions.question_text: A bacterial population in a hospital ward is exposed to a new antibiotic. Before use, only 5% of bacteria carry an allele that gives resistance. After years of frequent antibiotic use, the resistance allele rises to around 80%, then the graph levels off.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the resistance allele increased in frequency after the antibiotic was introduced. (3 marks)
b) Suggest one reason why the resistance allele frequency might level off at around 80% instead of reaching 100%. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{There was pre-existing genetic variation; a small percentage of bacteria were already resistant due to their alleles.}\\)
\\(\\text{The antibiotic acted as a selection pressure, killing most non-resistant bacteria while resistant ones survived}\\)
\\(\\text{treatment.}\\)
\\(\\text{Surviving resistant bacteria reproduced and passed their resistance alleles to offspring, so the allele frequency}\\)
\\(\\text{increased over time.}\\)

\\(\\text{One mark for either of the following:}\\)
\\(\\text{Some non-resistant bacteria may still survive in places where antibiotic levels are low or not used, so their alleles}\\)
\\(\\text{stay in the population.}\\)
\\(\\text{Resistance can sometimes carry a small fitness cost when antibiotics are absent, so a mix of resistant and}\\)
\\(\\text{non-resistant alleles can be maintained.}\\)

questions.question_text: A small island population of mice has only 60 individuals. No new mice arrive and none leave. Over many generations, scientists measure the frequency of allele A. They see the frequency move up and down in a random pattern, even though the environment and predators stay similar.

orders.text_content: a) Name the process that is changing allele frequencies in this small population and explain why it is more powerful here than in a large population. (3 marks)
b) Explain why low genetic diversity caused by drift can increase extinction risk, even if the environment does not change much. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The process is genetic drift.}\\)
\\(\\text{In a small population, random events like which individuals happen to breed have a large effect on allele}\\)
\\(\\text{frequencies.}\\) 
\\(\\text{In a large population, random changes balance out more easily, so drift has less impact on allele frequencies.}\\)

\\(\\text{Drift can remove alleles over time, reducing genetic diversity and leaving the population with few options if}\\)
\\(\\text{conditions change slightly or disease appears.}\\)
\\(\\text{Small, low-diversity populations are also more vulnerable to random disasters, where a single event can wipe}\\)
\\(\\text{out many individuals who share similar alleles.}\\)

questions.question_text: A virus spreads through humans worldwide. People infected in the first wave develop memory B cells and T cells. Over several years, small copying errors occur in the viral genes that code for surface proteins. A new strain appears with slightly changed antigens. Many people become infected again, but their illness is often milder than the first time.

orders.text_content: a) Name the evolutionary process that led to the new strain and explain how it occurs at the genetic level. (3 marks)
b) Explain why many people still get sick, but often with milder disease, when exposed to this new strain. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{The process is antigenic drift.}\\)
\\(\\text{Small point mutations and other minor changes accumulate in the viral genes that code for surface antigens.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over time, these small changes add up, producing a strain whose antigens differ enough from the original strain.}\\)

\\(\\text{Existing memory B and T cells recognise parts of the antigens that are still similar, so the immune response starts}\\)
\\(\\text{faster than during the first infection.}\\)
\\(\\text{Because the fit between antibodies and antigens is weaker than before, people can still be infected, but the}\\)
\\(\\text{faster, partially effective response often reduces symptom severity.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A palaeontologist compares two sedimentary rock layers in a cliff.

- Layer X (lower layer) contains only soft-bodied impressions and some trace fossils (burrows and tracks).
- Layer Y (higher layer) contains many permineralized skeletons and a wider variety of animal groups.

Which conclusion is MOST consistent with the fossil record?

orders.text_content:
A. Layer X is younger than Layer Y because soft-bodied organisms evolved after hard-bodied ones
B. Layer X is older than Layer Y and likely formed before many animals evolved hard parts
C. Layer X and Layer Y must be the same age because they are in the same cliff face
D. Layer Y must be older than Layer X because permineralized fossils are always from earlier eras

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In undisturbed sedimentary rock, lower layers are older than higher layers. Earlier in Earth‚Äôs history, many}\\)
\\(\\text{organisms were soft-bodied and less likely to fossilise. Later, more animals evolved hard parts that fossilise more}\\)
\\(\\text{easily, so the higher layer with more skeleton fossils is younger.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A geologist finds a fossilised amphibian in a sedimentary rock layer. In the same layer, she discovers an index fossil species that is known from many sites to have existed only between 210‚Äì205 million years ago. A nearby volcanic ash layer has been radiometrically dated (using uranium-235) to 208 million years ago. 

Which statement best describes the age of the amphibian fossil and the reasoning used?

orders.text_content:
A. Its age can only be estimated by radiocarbon dating of the amphibian bones
B. It must be older than 500 000 years but younger than 50 000 years because carbon-14 is present
C. It is approximately 208 million years old, inferred using both the ash layer and the index fossil as relative and absolute references
D. It cannot be dated because fossils never contain radioactive isotopes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. The amphibian fossil is the same age as the sedimentary layer. The ash layer provides an absolute date}\\)
\\(\\text{(~208 mya), and the index fossil narrows the time range (210‚Äì205 mya). Together, they support an age of roughly}\\)
\\(\\text{208 mya. Radiocarbon dating is only useful up to about 50 000 years and is not appropriate for fossils this old.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A museum receives two human skeletons for analysis:

- Skeleton A still contains measurable amounts of carbon-14.
- Skeleton B has no detectable carbon-14, so the researcher tries to date the surrounding volcanic rock with potassium-40.

Which interpretation best explains the choice of dating methods and their limitations?

orders.text_content:
A. Carbon-14 is used for very old fossils (hundreds of millions of years), so Skeleton A must be extremely ancient
B. After about 9 half-lives (~50 000 years), so little carbon-14 remains that radiocarbon dating becomes unreliable for Skeleton B
C. Potassium-40 is present in all bones, so it gives an accurate age of the organism itself
D. Radiocarbon dating directly measures the age of the sedimentary rock instead of the fossil

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Carbon-14 has a relatively short half-life (~5730 years). After around 9 half-lives (‚âà50 000 years), there is too}\\)
\\(\\text{little C-14 left to date reliably. Radiocarbon dating suits younger organic material (like Skeleton A). Very old}\\)
\\(\\text{material (Skeleton B and surrounding rock) is better constrained using long-lived isotopes such as potassium-40}\\)
\\(\\text{in volcanic rock, not in the fossil itself.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student describes fossilisation conditions as:

‚ÄúThe best fossils form when an animal dies on land, in hot, windy conditions with lots of oxygen and scavengers. The body dries out quickly and leaves a perfect skeleton that turns into a fossil.‚Äù

Which key correction should the teacher make?

orders.text_content:
A. Fossilisation is most likely in water or wet sediment, with rapid burial and low oxygen
B. Fossilisation needs very high oxygen levels so decomposers can work faster
C. Fossilisation only happens to soft-bodied organisms on land
D. Fossilisation is common and happens to most organisms that die

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Fossilisation is rare and favoured when an organism dies in water or is rapidly buried by sediment. Low}\\)
\\(\\text{oxygen, cooler temperatures and minimal scavenging slow decomposition, allowing minerals to seep in and}\\)
\\(\\text{form permineralized fossils or preserve moulds and casts.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Scientists studying a lineage of fossil horses notice a pattern:

- For long periods, horse fossils in successive layers show very little change in size or limb structure.
- In a few, relatively thin layers, they see sudden appearances of new forms with noticeably different limb proportions and tooth shape.
- Transitional fossils between old and new forms are rare.

Which explanation best fits both the fossil evidence and current ideas about evolutionary tempo?

orders.text_content:
A. Gradualism: changes occurred slowly and evenly through time, but the fossil record is perfectly complete
B. Punctuated equilibrium: long periods of little change were interrupted by short bursts of rapid evolution, making transitional fossils rare
C. Evolution does not occur; the new forms appeared spontaneously without ancestors
D. The new forms cannot be related, because transitional fossils must always be abundant if evolution occurred

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Punctuated equilibrium proposes that species remain relatively unchanged for long periods, with rapid changes}\\)
\\(\\text{occurring in short bursts associated with speciation. This leads to few transitional fossils and sudden jumps in}\\)
\\(\\text{morphology in the rock record.}\\)

\\(\\text{B. Punctuated equilibrium proposes that species remain relatively unchanged for long periods, with rapid changes}\\)
\\(\\text{occurring in short bursts associated with speciation. This leads to few transitional fossils and sudden jumps in}\\)
\\(\\text{morphology in the rock record.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A biologist compares the forelimbs of a whale, a bat and a cat. Each limb has the same basic set of bones (humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals, phalanges) arranged in a similar pattern, but used for swimming, flying and walking.

What do these limbs best demonstrate?

orders.text_content:
A. Analogous structures produced by convergent evolution
B. Vestigial structures produced by loss of function
C. Homologous structures produced by divergent evolution from a common ancestor
D. Structural changes that do not provide any information about relatedness

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. The limbs share the same underlying bone pattern but have different functions. This indicates homologous structures,}\\)
\\(\\text{which are evidence of divergent evolution from a shared common ancestor that had a similar limb.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Two bird species, Hawk A and Hawk B, have:
- Very similar wing shape, eye position and hunting behaviour
- Almost identical amino acid sequence for cytochrome c
- Small but consistent differences in DNA sequence in several nuclear genes

A third bird, Crane C, looks quite different and does not hunt, but:
- Has a cytochrome c sequence that only differs slightly from Hawk A and Hawk B
- Shows fewer DNA differences overall from the hawks than from other birds

Which conclusion about evidence of relatedness is MOST reasonable?

orders.text_content:
A. Structural appearance alone is enough to group Crane C separately from both hawks
B. Amino acid sequences are always less useful than DNA sequences and should be ignored
C. Molecular evidence (DNA and amino acids) suggests Crane C is relatively closely related to the hawks despite different morphology
D. Because Hawk A and Hawk B look similar, molecular data must be wrong

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Molecular evidence (DNA and amino acid sequences) can reveal close relationships even when body shape and}\\)
\\(\\text{lifestyle differ. Cytochrome c and DNA similarities suggest Crane C shares a relatively recent common ancestor}\\)
\\(\\text{with the hawks, and structural differences may reflect divergent selection pressures.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Researchers want to build a molecular clock for several closely related mammal species that diverged in the last 2 million years. They are choosing between nuclear DNA and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).

Which combination of reasons best explains why mtDNA is often preferred for tracking recent evolutionary changes?

orders.text_content:
A. mtDNA is inherited from both parents, recombines frequently and is copied very accurately
B. mtDNA has only one copy per cell, mutates slowly and is hard to detect in old samples
C. mtDNA is maternally inherited with minimal recombination, has no proofreading polymerase and exists in many copies per cell
D. mtDNA never mutates, so any sequence difference must be due to sequencing error

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. mtDNA is passed down the maternal line with limited recombination, so changes reflect a single lineage. It}\\)
\\(\\text{lacks proofreading polymerase and has high copy number, so mutations accumulate and are easy to detect, making}\\)
\\(\\text{mtDNA very useful for studying recent divergence.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student makes these claims:
1. ‚ÄúY and Z are the most closely related.‚Äù
2. ‚ÄúW is the outgroup.‚Äù

orders.text_content:
How should a teacher respond?

A. Only claim 1 is correct; W cannot be an outgroup
B. Only claim 2 is correct; Y and Z are least related
C. Both claims 1 and 2 are correct
D. Both claims 1 and 2 are incorrect

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. On a cladogram, the pair that shares the most recent common ancestor (Y and Z) is most closely related. The}\\)
\\(\\text{outgroup is the lineage that diverged first from the rest (W), so both student statements are correct.}\\)

questions.question_text: Timothee, an expert researcher, has constructed the following diagram after decades of evolutionary research. However, he is still unsure of the organisms‚Äô identity so has dubbed them organism A, B, C and D.

orders.text_content:
The researcher also knows that:

- B and D live in similar habitats and have independently evolved webbed feet for swimming.
- C lives in a forest and has non-webbed feet.

Which conclusion is most consistent with the phylogram and the idea of convergent evolution?

A. B and D must be the most closely related because they share webbed feet
B. B and C are most closely related because they share the most recent common ancestor, and webbed feet in B and D likely evolved independently
C. C and D are most closely related because neither has adapted to aquatic life
D. A and D are most closely related because D branched off second

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In the phylogram, B and C share the most recent common ancestor, so they are most closely related. The similar}\\)
\\(\\text{webbed feet of B and D are best explained by convergent evolution under similar selection pressures, not by}\\)
\\(\\text{close ancestry.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A museum is analysing two specimens:
- Specimen A is a wooden spear shaft from an archaeological site. Compared with fresh wood, it contains about one-sixteenth (1/16) of the original amount of carbon-14.
- Specimen B is a fossilised dinosaur femur found in sedimentary rock. No detectable carbon-14 is present.
Which interpretation best explains the choice and limits of dating methods for these specimens?

orders.text_content:
A. Both specimens can be reliably dated using carbon-14, because all fossils contain this isotope
B. Specimen A is roughly four half-lives of carbon-14 old, while Specimen B is too old for carbon-14 and must be dated using long-lived isotopes in nearby igneous rock
C. Specimen A must be millions of years old because it still has some carbon-14, and Specimen B must be younger because it has none
D. Neither specimen can be dated because only living organisms can contain radioactive isotopes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. If one-sixteenth of the original carbon-14 remains, the sample has passed through four half-lives (1 ‚Üí ¬Ω ‚Üí}\\)
\\(\\text{¬º ‚Üí ‚Öõ ‚Üí 1/16). For carbon-14 (half-life ‚âà 5730 years), this is around 23 000 years, so radiocarbon dating}\\)
\\(\\text{is suitable for the wooden spear (Specimen A). Dinosaur fossils (Specimen B) are far older than ~50000 years, so all}\\)
\\(\\text{carbon-14 has decayed; instead, long-lived isotopes (e.g. uranium or potassium) in surrounding igneous rock are}\\)
\\(\\text{used to estimate absolute age.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A palaeontologist describes two fossils of the same shell species:

- Fossil 1: A hollow cavity in the rock with the exact shape of the shell.
- Fossil 2: A solid copy of the shell shape that has filled that cavity with minerals over time.

Which terms correctly match Fossil 1 and Fossil 2?

orders.text_content:
A. Fossil 1 is a cast; Fossil 2 is a mould
B. Fossil 1 is a permineralised fossil; Fossil 2 is a trace fossil
C. Fossil 1 is a mould; Fossil 2 is a cast
D. Fossil 1 is an impression fossil; Fossil 2 is a trace fossil

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. When an organism decomposes and leaves a cavity with its shape, that cavity is a mould fossil. When sediment or}\\)
\\(\\text{minerals later fill that mould and harden into rock in the same shape, the solid copy is a cast fossil.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A marine mammal species has:

- A large, functional tail fluke used for swimming
- A tiny, internal pelvic bone that does not attach to any limb and does not help with movement

Scientists think its ancestor was a four-legged land mammal with fully functional hind limbs.
Which explanation best describes the evolution of this pelvic bone?

orders.text_content:
A. The pelvic bone is analogous, not vestigial, because it has no current function
B. The pelvic bone is vestigial; fully formed hind limbs became disadvantageous in water, so individuals with reduced hind limbs were favoured, and the remaining small pelvis now has little or no selective effect
C. The pelvic bone is homologous but not vestigial, because it still performs the original function exactly as in the ancestor
D. The pelvic bone evolved independently in the marine mammal and its ancestor, so it provides no information about relatedness

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The tiny internal pelvis is a vestigial structure‚Äîa reduced form of a structure that was functional in an}\\)
\\(\\text{ancestor. In a fully aquatic environment, large hind limbs likely became disadvantageous for streamlined}\\)
\\(\\text{swimming, so whales with smaller hind limbs were favoured by natural selection. Over time, limb bones were}\\)
\\(\\text{reduced, leaving a small pelvis that now provides little advantage or disadvantage but remains as evidence of}\\)
\\(\\text{evolutionary history.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher performs DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation on three species (X, Y and Z). She records the melting temperature (T‚Çò) at which hybrid double strands separate:

- Hybrid X‚ÄìY: separates at 94¬∞C
- Hybrid X‚ÄìZ: separates at 89¬∞C
- Hybrid Y‚ÄìZ: separates at 92¬∞C

Which conclusion best uses the principles of DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation?

orders.text_content:
A. X and Z are most closely related because they have the lowest melting temperature
B. X and Y are most closely related because their hybrid DNA has the highest melting temperature
C. Y and Z are least related because their hybrid DNA separates at an intermediate temperature
D. All three pairs are equally related because they form double-stranded DNA at all

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation, more complementary base-pairing (more similar sequences) produces more}\\)
\\(\\text{hydrogen bonds and a higher melting temperature. The X‚ÄìY hybrid requires the most heat (94¬∞C) to separate,}\\)
\\(\\text{indicating the highest similarity and therefore the closest evolutionary relationship.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student compares DNA sequencing and amino acid sequencing as molecular evidence for evolution.
Which statement best explains why DNA sequencing is often more sensitive than amino acid sequencing?

orders.text_content:
A. DNA sequencing can detect silent mutations that change amino acids but not DNA
B. DNA sequencing can detect silent mutations that change DNA sequence without changing the amino acid sequence
C. Amino acid sequencing can detect more changes because it ignores silent mutations
D. DNA sequencing is less useful because it cannot show small changes in nucleotide order

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. DNA sequencing identifies changes in the nucleotide sequence, including silent mutations that alter the codon}\\)
\\(\\text{but still code for the same amino acid. Amino acid sequencing cannot detect these silent changes, so DNA}\\)
\\(\\text{sequencing provides finer detail about evolutionary differences between species.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A molecular clock is built using a mitochondrial gene. The number of nucleotide differences between species pairs is:

- Species A vs B: 3 differences
- Species A vs C: 10 differences
- Species B vs C: 9 differences

Assume mutations accumulate at a roughly constant rate in all lineages. Which statement about the relative divergence times is most accurate?

orders.text_content:
A. A and B diverged most recently; C diverged earlier from their common ancestor
B. A and C diverged most recently because they have the most differences
C. B and C diverged at the same time as A and B because all three are alive today
D. All three species diverged at exactly the same time because they share a common ancestor

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Under a molecular clock, fewer differences in DNA generally mean a shorter time since divergence. A and}\\)
\\(\\text{B differ by only 3 nucleotides, so they diverged most recently. B and C (9 differences) and A and C (10 differences)}\\)
\\(\\text{diverged earlier from each other, indicating C split from the A‚ÄìB lineage before A and B diverged from each other.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A scientist wants to study evolutionary relationships between different species. Some are very closely related, while others are distantly related.
Which combination of methods best matches the flashcard recommendations?

orders.text_content:
