A. Closely related: amino acid sequencing; distantly related: DNA sequencing
B. Closely related: DNA sequencing; distantly related: amino acid sequencing of a conserved protein (e.g. cytochrome
C. Use amino acid sequencing for all species because it is always more precise
D. Use DNA sequencing for all species because amino acid sequences never change

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. For closely related species, DNA sequencing detects even tiny nucleotide differences. For distantly related}\\)
\\(\\text{species, amino acid sequencing of a conserved protein (such as cytochrome c) is useful, because DNA sequences}\\)
\\(\\text{may have diverged so much that only the protein sequence still shows meaningful similarities.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student makes several claims:

1. ‚ÄúY and Z are the most closely related because they share the most recent common ancestor.‚Äù
2. ‚ÄúBecause all branches are equal length, this diagram does not show how much time passed between divergences.‚Äù
3. ‚ÄúX must be older than W because its branch is drawn higher up.‚Äù

orders.text_content:
Which combination of claims is correct?

A. Only claim 1
B. Claims 1 and 2 only
C. Claims 2 and 3 only
D. All three claims

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. In a cladogram, all branches are unscaled; their length does not represent time. The pair with the most recent}\\)
\\(\\text{common ancestor (Y and Z) is the most closely related, so claim 1 is correct. Claim 2 is also correct: the equal}\\)
\\(\\text{branch lengths mean we cannot read time from the diagram. Claim 3 is incorrect: position in the image does not}\\)
\\(\\text{indicate ‚Äúoldness‚Äù; W is the outgroup because it diverges first from the root, not because of vertical height.}\\)

questions.question_text: Using the principle of parsimony - (fewest evolutionary changes), where did traits T and U most likely first evolve?

orders.text_content:
A. T evolved independently three times (in X, Y, Z); U evolved independently in Y and Z
B. T evolved once on the branch after W split off; U evolved once on the branch leading to the common ancestor of Y and Z
C. T evolved in W but was lost in all other lineages; U evolved in X and was lost in Y and Z
D. T and U both evolved in the common ancestor of all four species and were lost in W only

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Parsimony favours the explanation with fewest trait gains and losses. The simplest scenario is that trait T arose}\\)
\\(\\text{once after W branched off, so it is shared by X, Y and Z. Trait U is present only in Y and Z, so it most likely evolved}\\)
\\(\\text{once in their shared ancestor after the split from X. Multiple independent gains and losses (options a, c, d) are}\\)
\\(\\text{less parsimonious.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A geologist finds a distinctive index fossil in a rock layer in South America. The same index fossil species is well known from many sites and has been dated (using absolute methods) to around 150 million years ago. In a different country, another rock layer contains the same index fossil plus a new unknown fossil.

Which statement best describes how the geologist can use this information?

orders.text_content:
A. Use the unknown fossil to absolutely date the index fossil in all other locations
B. Use the index fossil to infer a relative age for the unknown fossil and its rock layer, close to 150 million years ago
C. Conclude that the unknown fossil must be exactly 150.0 million years old everywhere it is found
D. Ignore the index fossil, because only radiocarbon dating can give useful ages

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. An index fossil is a distinctive, widespread species of known age that lived for a relatively short time. Finding the}\\)
\\(\\text{same index fossil in another rock layer allows the geologist to give that layer and its fossils a relative age similar}\\)
\\(\\text{to the known time range (around 150 million years), even though it doesn‚Äôt provide an exact absolute date by itself.}\\)

questions.question_text: Early Earth‚Äôs atmosphere had almost no free oxygen, so most life was anaerobic and microbial. When some single-celled prokaryotes evolved oxygenic photosynthesis (cyanobacteria-like microbes), they began releasing O‚ÇÇ into oceans and eventually the air‚Äîevidence for this shift is seen in features like stromatolites and later banded iron formations. Rising oxygen was toxic to many anaerobes but enabled aerobic respiration, which produces much more ATP than fermentation. This energy boost helped support the later emergence and diversification of aerobic eukaryotes.

orders.text_content: a) Explain two major biological consequences of photosynthetic prokaryotes becoming common on early Earth. (2 marks)
b) Suggest one-way scientists can use the fossil record or rock evidence to infer when photosynthetic organisms first became widespread. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Photosynthesis releases oxygen, causing the atmosphere to become oxygenated.}\\)
\\(\\text{This allows aerobic respiration/aerobic organisms to evolve (e.g. evolution of more complex, energy-demanding}\\)
\\(\\text{eukaryotic life).}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for either of the following, to a maximum of 1 mark.}\\)
\\(\\text{Evidence of banded iron formations / oxidised iron-rich rocks or particular microfossils (e.g. stromatolites).}\\)
\\(\\text{These indicate large amounts of free oxygen being produced by photosynthetic organisms at that time.}\\)

questions.question_text: A textbook compares what happens after death in two environments: a small animal dies in shallow, muddy water and is rapidly covered by fine silt, while a similar animal dies on dry open land and remains exposed.

orders.text_content: a) Using the diagram, describe two conditions in the aquatic environment that increase the chance Animal 1 will form a fossil. (2 marks)
b) Explain why most organisms (including Animal 2) still do not become fossils, even if some conditions are favourable. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Rapid burial by sediment (e.g. silt/mud), which protects the body from physical damage.}\\)
\\(\\text{Low oxygen / cooler water / fewer scavengers, slowing decomposition and allowing mineralisation.}\\)

\\(\\text{Decomposition, scavenging or physical breakdown usually destroys remains before they can be buried and}\\)
\\(\\text{preserved.}\\)
\\(\\text{Fossilisation is a rare event requiring a specific combination of conditions, so only a tiny fraction of organisms}\\)
\\(\\text{are fossilised.}\\)

questions.question_text: A bone from an archaeological site contains one-eighth (1/8) of the carbon-14 found in a living person‚Äôs bone. Carbon-14 has a half-life of about 5730 years.

orders.text_content: a) How many half-lives have passed and estimate the age of the bone. Show your reasoning in words. (2 marks)
b) A dinosaur bone has no detectable carbon-14. Explain why radiocarbon dating is not suitable for this fossil and how scientists instead determine its age. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{3 half lives}\\)
\\(\\text{3 √ó 1570 is roughly 17000- 18000 years.}\\)

\\(\\text{Dinosaurs are much older than ~50 000 years, so almost all carbon-14 has decayed, making radiocarbon dating}\\)
\\(\\text{unreliable.}\\)
\\(\\text{Scientists date the fossil indirectly, using radiometric dating of long-lived isotopes (e.g. uranium / potassium) in}\\)
\\(\\text{surrounding igneous rock to estimate an absolute age.}\\)

questions.question_text: A field team logs a sedimentary cliff where the same rock layers can‚Äôt be traced sideways, so they use index fossils to correlate the sequence. In the column, index fossil A is known from many other sites to occur only between 90‚Äì85 million years ago, while index fossil B is restricted to 80‚Äì75 million years ago.

orders.text_content: a) Using the diagram and the idea of fossil succession, which layer is oldest and which is youngest? Justify briefly. (2 marks)
b) Explain how the principle of correlation and the known age ranges of index fossils A and B can be used to estimate the age of Layer 2. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Finding the same index fossils (A and B) in different locations allows those rock layers to be correlated in age.}\\)
\\(\\text{Layer 2 contains both A (90‚Äì85 mya) and B (80‚Äì75 mya), so it must fall within the overlap of these ranges.}\\)
\\(\\text{Layer 2 likely formed between about 80‚Äì85 million years ago, where the time ranges of A and B overlap.}\\)

\\(\\text{Layer 3 is oldest and Layer 1 is youngest (assuming normal, undisturbed strata with oldest at the bottom).}\\)
\\(\\text{In an undisturbed sequence, deeper layers are older and higher layers are younger (law of superposition / fossil}\\)
\\(\\text{succession).}\\)

questions.question_text: A worksheet shows the forelimbs of a bat, human, whale and the fin of a shark, with bones labelled.

orders.text_content: a) Choose two structures from the diagram that are homologous. Name the pair and explain why they are considered homologous. (2 marks)
b) Identify a pair of structures in the diagram that are analogous. Name the pair and explain why they are considered analogous. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Bat wing and human arm OR bat wing and whale flipper OR human arm and whale flipper.}\\)
\\(\\text{They share a similar underlying bone pattern/structure (e.g. humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals, phalanges)}\\)
\\(\\text{because they descended from a common ancestor, even though the functions differ.}\\)

\\(\\text{Bat wing and shark fin (or whale flipper and shark fin) that perform similar roles.}\\)
\\(\\text{They have similar function (movement through water/air)but different underlying structure and different ancestors,}\\)
\\(\\text{so they are analogous and evidence of convergent evolution.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher performs DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation on three species A, B and C and records the temperatures at which hybrid DNA strands separate.

- A‚ÄìB: 96 ¬∞C
- A‚ÄìC: 89 ¬∞C
- B‚ÄìC: 93 ¬∞C

orders.text_content: a) Rank the three pairs (A‚ÄìB, A‚ÄìC, B‚ÄìC) from most closely related to least closely related, based on the data above. (2 marks)
b) Explain why DNA‚ÄìDNA hybridisation or DNA sequencing is considered stronger evidence for evolutionary relationships than simply comparing external appearance. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A‚ÄìB (most closely related), B‚ÄìC, A‚ÄìC (least closely related).}\\)
\\(\\text{A higher melting temperature means more complementary base pairs, more hydrogen bonds, and therefore}\\)
\\(\\text{greater similarity / closer relatedness.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 2 marks.}\\)
\\(\\text{Molecular evidence directly reflects DNA changes, which accumulate over time.}\\)
\\(\\text{Similar-looking species can be distantly related due to convergent evolution, so appearance can be misleading.}\\)
\\(\\text{Tiny sequence differences in DNA can be detected and compared, giving a more precise measure of relatedness}\\)
\\(\\text{than structural features alone.}\\)

questions.question_text: A biologist is dating when several mammal species split by building a molecular clock using two datasets: mtDNA (small circular genome in mitochondria, inherited down maternal lines) and nuclear DNA (many genes in the nucleus, inherited from both parents). They notice mtDNA trees often show clearer separation between closely related species, while nuclear genes sometimes disagree.

orders.text_content: a) State two reasons why mtDNA is especially useful for tracking recent evolutionary changes between closely related species. (2 marks)
b) A student claims that ‚ÄúmtDNA is better in every situation than nuclear DNA for evolutionary studies.‚Äù Explain why this claim is too simple, giving two points. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{mtDNA is maternally inherited with minimal recombination, so any changes are easy to trace along a single}\\)
\\(\\text{lineage.}\\)
\\(\\text{mtDNA has no polymerase proofreading and high copy number, so it accumulates mutations more easily and}\\)
\\(\\text{is more likely to be recovered and analysed.}\\)

\\(\\text{mtDNA only reflects the maternal line, so it ignores paternal and recombined nuclear information that may be}\\)
\\(\\text{important.}\\)
\\(\\text{For very distant relationships, mtDNA may become too diverged or saturated, and nuclear genes or amino acid}\\)
\\(\\text{sequences of conserved proteins may be more informative.}\\)

questions.question_text: A teacher shows students a cladogram and a phylogram for the same four species W, X, Y and Z.

orders.text_content: a) Describe one key difference between what a cladogram and a phylogram show. (1 mark)

b) On the phylogram, Y and Z share a very recent common ancestor, and their branches are short and close to the present. Explain what this suggests about the relatedness of Y and Z and the amount of genetic difference between them. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A cladogram has unscaled branches (all equal length) and shows patterns of relatedness only, whereas a}\\)
\\(\\text{phylogram has branch lengths scaled to time or amount of change, showing both relatedness and evolutionary}\\)
\\(\\text{timing/amount of change.}\\)

\\(\\text{Y and Z share the most recent common ancestor and are therefore the most closely related species.}\\)
\\(\\text{Their short branch lengths indicate little time / few genetic changes since divergence, so they have very similar}\\)
\\(\\text{DNA sequences.}\\)

questions.question_text: A palaeontologist is explaining different fossil types and why the fossil record is incomplete.

orders.text_content: a) Using the diagram, distinguish between a permineralised fossil and a mould-and-cast fossil. (2 marks)
b) Give two reasons why the fossil record is considered incomplete and biased. (2 marks)
c) Explain why soft-bodied organisms are especially under-represented in the fossil record. Refer to their structure and fossilisation conditions. (2 marks)
d) Describe one method scientists use to study evolution of groups that have poor fossil records and explain why it helps. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Permineralised fossil ‚Äì minerals infiltrate and harden inside the pores/spaces of the original hard parts (e.g. bone or}\\)
\\(\\text{wood), preserving internal structure.}\\)
\\(\\text{Mould and cast ‚Äì the organism leaves a cavity (mould) in the sediment after it decays; later, sediment/minerals}\\)
\\(\\text{fill the mould and harden into a solid copy (cast) of the external shape.}\\)

\\(\\text{Fossilisation requires very specific conditions (e.g. rapid burial, low oxygen), so most organisms decay or are}\\)
\\(\\text{scavenged before they canfossilise.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some environments and body types are more likely to fossilise (e.g. aquatic, hard parts), so soft-bodied organisms}\\)
\\(\\text{and habitats like forests or mountains are under-represented.}\\)

\\(\\text{Soft-bodied organisms lack hard parts (bones, shells) that resist decay, so they break down quickly.}\\)
\\(\\text{They need exceptional conditions (e.g. very rapid burial in fine sediment, anoxic conditions) to leave impressions,}\\)
\\(\\text{which occur rarely, so they seldom fossilise.}\\)

\\(\\text{Method ‚Äì e.g. use molecular evidence (DNA, amino acid sequences) from living species, or comparative}\\)
\\(\\text{anatomy of homologous structures.}\\)
\\(\\text{Explanation ‚Äì these data show patterns of similarity and divergence that allow scientists to infer relationships and }\\)
\\(\\text{evolutionary history even where fossils are missing.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Geologists use a particular shell species as an index fossil. This species is:
- Very common in marine sediments
- Found in many different regions
- Only present in rocks from a narrow time range.

orders.text_content: a) State two features that make a fossil species useful as an index fossil. (2 marks)
b) Explain how index fossils help geologists to correlate rock layers in different parts of the world. (2 marks)
c) A student says: ‚ÄúAny fossil that is very old is automatically a good index fossil.‚Äù Explain why this statement is incorrect. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{It must be widespread geographically and relatively common, so it is found in many locations.}\\)
\\(\\text{It must have lived for a short geological time range, making the associated rock layer narrowly dated.}\\)

\\(\\text{If the same index fossil species is found in rock layers in different regions, those layers were deposited at}\\)
\\(\\text{roughly the same time.}\\)
\\(\\text{This allows geologists to match (correlate) the ages of rock sequences across continents, even if the rock types}\\)
\\(\\text{differ.}\\)

\\(\\text{Age alone is not enough; an index fossil must have a short time range, not just be old.}\\)
\\(\\text{If a species existed for a very long time, finding it does not narrow down the age of the rock, so it is not useful as}\\)
\\(\\text{an index fossil.}\\)

questions.question_text: Modern whales still carry clues to a land-mammal past: their skeletons include tiny, disconnected pelvic bones and no external hind limbs. For example, transitional fossils show reduced hind limbs and more powerful tails as swimming became more important than walking.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why the tiny pelvic bones in modern whales are considered a vestigial structure. (2 marks)
b) Describe how natural selection could have led from a four-legged land mammal to a whale with reduced hind limbs. (3 marks)
c) Explain how the whale pelvic bones provide evidence for evolution, rather than being a completely new structure. (2 marks)
d) A student claims: ‚ÄúBecause the whale pelvis has no function, natural selection should have removed it completely.‚Äù Suggest two reasons why the pelvis may still be present. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{They are reduced remnants of fully functional hind limb structures in ancestral land mammals.}\\)
\\(\\text{They no longer perform their original locomotion function in whales and have little or no clear current role.}\\)

\\(\\text{In an aquatic environment, individuals with smaller or more streamlined hind limbs may have had a swimming}\\)
\\(\\text{advantage (less drag).}\\)
\\(\\text{These individuals were more likely to survive and reproduce, passing on alleles for reduced hind limbs.}\\)
\\(\\text{Over many generations, hind limbs became progressively smaller and internal, leaving only vestigial pelvic}\\)
\\(\\text{bones in modern whales.}\\)

\\(\\text{The pelvic bones are homologous to the pelvis of land mammals, sharing similar position and basic structure.}\\)
\\(\\text{This suggests whales share a common ancestor with land mammals, and the structure has changed over}\\)
\\(\\text{time, supporting the idea of descent with modification.}\\)

\\(\\text{The pelvis may still have minor functions (e.g. muscle attachment, reproductive structures), so it is not strongly}\\)
\\(\\text{selected against.}\\)
\\(\\text{If the pelvis is not very harmful, there is little selective pressure to remove it entirely, so it can persist as a}\\)
\\(\\text{neutral vestige.}\\)

questions.question_text:
- W‚ÄìX: 95%
- W‚ÄìY: 80%
- W‚ÄìZ: 78%
- X‚ÄìY: 82%
- X‚ÄìZ: 79%
- Y‚ÄìZ: 96%

orders.text_content: a) Which pair of species is most closely related according to these data? Explain your reasoning. (2 marks)
b) Using this information, describe which species is likely to be the outgroup (most distantly related to the others). Justify your choice. (2 marks)
c) Explain why using multiple genes or whole-genome data can give a more reliable phylogeny than using a single gene only. (3 marks)
d) A student says: ‚ÄúSpecies that look the most similar must always have the highest DNA similarity.‚Äù Give two reasons why this can be wrong. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Y and Z are the most closely related pair.}\\)
\\(\\text{They have the highest percentage similarity (96%), meaning fewest differences and a more recent common ancestor.}\\)

\\(\\text{W is likely the outgroup.}\\)
\\(\\text{W has lower similarity with Y (80%) and Z (78%) than X does, indicating W diverged earlier from the lineage}\\)
\\(\\text{leading to X, Y and Z.}\\)

\\(\\text{Different genes can evolve at different rates, so one gene may give a distorted view of relationships.}\\)
\\(\\text{Using many genes or whole genomes reduces the effect of anomalies (e.g. selection acting strongly on one gene).}\\)
\\(\\text{This provides a more robust average signal of relatedness, improving the reliability of the phylogenetic tree.}\\)

\\(\\text{Convergent evolution can produce similar structures in distantly related species living in similar environments, even}\\)
\\(\\text{if their DNA is quite different.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some closely related species may evolve very different appearances due to strong selection, even though their}\\)
\\(\\text{DNA sequences remain highly similar.}\\)

questions.question_text: A class is learning about mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and how it is passed from one generation to the next.

orders.text_content: a) Describe how mtDNA is usually inherited in humans. Be specific about which parent(s) contribute it. (1 mark)
b) Explain why mtDNA is useful for tracing maternal lineages over many generations. (2 marks)
c) Give one limitation of using mtDNA alone to infer the evolutionary history of a species. (1 mark)
d) A student confuses mtDNA with nuclear DNA and says: ‚ÄúmtDNA controls all traits in the body.‚Äù Correct this misconception using two points. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{mtDNA is almost always inherited from the mother only, because mitochondria in the zygote come from the}\\)
\\(\\text{egg, not the sperm.}\\)

\\(\\text{mtDNA experiences little or no recombination, so changes mainly come from mutations over time.}\\)
\\(\\text{This makes it easier to trace a straight maternal line, as mtDNA sequences change gradually and can be compared}\\)
\\(\\text{between individuals and populations.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for either of the following, to a maximum of 1 mark.}\\)
\\(\\text{It only reflects the maternal line, ignoring paternal and recombined nuclear DNA.}\\)
\\(\\text{As a result, mtDNA can give an incomplete or misleading picture if used alone, so it is best combined with}\\)
\\(\\text{nuclear DNA and other evidence.}\\)

\\(\\text{mtDNA carries genes mainly involved in mitochondrial function and energy production, not most body traits.}\\)
\\(\\text{Most traits are controlled by nuclear DNA, which has far more genes and is inherited from both parents.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Fossils of a snail species are collected from rock layers spanning 5 million years.

Two models are proposed:
- Model 1 (Gradualism): Snail shell size changes slowly and steadily over time.
- Model 2 (Punctuated equilibrium): Snail shell size stays similar for long periods, with sudden jumps where new forms appear and older forms disappear quickly.

orders.text_content: a) Describe how the fossil record would look different under gradualism compared with punctuated equilibrium. (3 marks)
b) Suggest two reasons why transitional fossils might be rare, even if evolution is gradual. (2 marks)
c) Explain how environmental change could trigger a period of rapid evolutionary change consistent with punctuated equilibrium. (2 marks)
d) A student says: ‚ÄúIf fossils show sudden changes, evolution must be wrong and species must appear instantly.‚Äù Explain why this is not necessarily true. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Gradualism ‚Äì successive layers show small, continuous changes in
shell size/shape}\\)
\\(\\text{over time.}\\)
\\(\\text{Punctuated equilibrium ‚Äì long intervals where fossils show little or no change, interrupted by layers with sudden}\\)
\\(\\text{appearance of new forms and disappearance of old ones.}\\)
\\(\\text{Transitional forms are more frequently found under gradualism, but rarer and more clustered under punctuated}\\)
\\(\\text{equilibrium.}\\)

\\(\\text{Fossilisation is rare and patchy, so only a small sample of all organisms and time points are preserved.}\\)
\\(\\text{Transitional populations may be small or localised, so fewer individuals are fossilised and later discovered.}\\)

\\(\\text{‚ÄúSudden‚Äù changes in the fossil record may still represent many thousands of years, just compressed into}\\)
\\(\\text{a thin rock layer.}\\)
\\(\\text{Missing transitional fossils can be due to gaps in the record, not absence of gradual change, so the fossil pattern}\\)
\\(\\text{is still consistent with evolution by natural selection.}\\)

\\(\\text{A rapid environmental change (e.g. new predator, climate shift, new habitat) can create strong new selection}\\)
\\(\\text{pressures.}\\)
\\(\\text{These pressures can lead to fast changes in allele frequencies and the quick appearance of new species or forms,}\\)
\\(\\text{which may appear suddenly in the fossil record.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher constructs a cladogram and a phylogram for four reptile species A, B, C and D using DNA sequence data.
- The cladogram shows A branching first (outgroup), then B, then a recent node joining C and D.
- The phylogram shows that C and D diverged from their common ancestor 1 million years ago, while B diverged from their lineage 8 million years ago.

orders.text_content: a) From the cladogram, identify which two species are most closely related and explain why. (2 marks)
b) Using the phylogram, explain what the short branch lengths between C and D suggest about the number of genetic differences between them. (2 marks)

c) A different pair, B and D, both live in desert environments and have independently evolved pale body colour. Explain why pale colour alone does not prove that B and D are most closely related. (2 marks)
d) Suggest two advantages of using a phylogram rather than a cladogram when studying rates of evolution. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Species C and D are most closely related.}\\)
\\(\\text{They share the most recent common ancestor (latest node) compared with any other pair.}\\)

\\(\\text{Short branches indicate that little time has passed since divergence.}\\)
\\(\\text{Therefore, C and D have few genetic differences, consistent with high DNA similarity.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for each of the following, to a maximum of 2 marks.}\\)
\\(\\text{Similar traits in similar environments can arise via convergent evolution, not just shared ancestry.}\\)
\\(\\text{The phylogram shows B diverged much earlier from the lineage leading to C and D, so it is less closely related}\\)
\\(\\text{to D than C is.}\\)
\\(\\text{Pale colour is likely an adaptation to the desert that evolved independently in B and D, while DNA evidence places}\\)
\\(\\text{C and D as the closest relatives.}\\)

\\(\\text{Phylograms have branch lengths scaled to time or amount of genetic change, allowing estimation of how fast}\\)
\\(\\text{mutations accumulate.}\\)
\\(\\text{They help identify lineages with faster or slower rates of evolution, which can be linked to selection pressures}\\)
\\(\\text{or life history differences.}\\)

questions.question_text: A science class is studying how the fossil record can show changes in biodiversity over time.

orders.text_content: a) Describe how the sequence of fossils in the column provides evidence that life has changed over time. (2 marks)
b) Explain why this pattern alone does not prove that one fossil type directly evolved into the next (e.g. invertebrates ‚Üí fish ‚Üí amphibians). (2 marks)
c) Suggest one other type of evidence that, together with fossils, helps scientists infer evolutionary relationships among these groups. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Lower layers contain only simpler organisms (e.g. invertebrates), while upper layers contain more complex groups}\\)
\\(\\text{(fish, amphibians).}\\)
\\(\\text{This sequence suggests that new groups appear later, showing that biodiversity and complexity increased over time.}\\)

\\(\\text{Fossil layers show which groups coexisted and when they appeared, but they may not include all transitional forms.}\\)
\\(\\text{Evolution involves many intermediate species and branching lineages that the fossil record may not fully capture,}\\)
\\(\\text{so we cannot say one fossil species is the direct ancestor of another.}\\)

\\(\\text{Other evidence ‚Äì e.g. comparative anatomy of homologous structures (limb bones), or molecular evidence (DNA or}\\)
\\(\\text{amino acid sequences).}\\)
\\(\\text{Explanation ‚Äì similarities in structure or molecular sequences can show shared ancestry and support patterns}\\)
\\(\\text{seen in the fossil record.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student writes the following partial classification for modern humans:

Kingdom: Animalia
Phylum: Chordata
Class: Mammalia
Order: Primate
Family: Hominidae
Genus: Homo
Species: sapiens

Which statement is correct?

orders.text_content:
A. ‚ÄúPrimate‚Äù is the family because it comes after class
B. ‚ÄúHomo‚Äù is the species because it is the most specific name
C. ‚ÄúHominidae‚Äù is the family and must come before genus
D. ‚ÄúChordata‚Äù is the order because it comes after kingdom

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Family sits above genus in taxonomy, so Hominidae correctly precedes Homo.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: ‚ÄúPrimate‚Äù is an order, not family, and ‚ÄúHomo‚Äù is a genus, not species.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A palaeontologist finds a mammal fossil with forward-facing eye sockets, evidence of stereoscopic vision, and a five-digit hand. However, the digits show limited ability to rotate toward each other.

Based on the most defensible conclusion, this fossil most likely belongs to:

orders.text_content:
A. A primate, because stereoscopic vision and a pentadactyl limb are key primate traits
B. A hominin, because all hominins are defined by stereoscopic vision
C. A prosimian, because all prosimians have precision grip
D. A hominoid, because all hominoids have a tail

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. A primate is supported by stereoscopic vision + pentadactyl limb (and typically opposable digits), even if}\\)
\\(\\text{manipulation is less advanced.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: precision grip is associated with hominins (not all primates), and hominoids are defined as apes and lack}\\)
\\(\\text{a tail in this content.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A zoo is choosing signage for five species. The curator wants the label ‚Äúhominid‚Äù to appear only for animals that match the definition ‚Äúfamily Hominidae (great apes), excluding gibbons.‚Äù

Which list correctly matches that rule?

orders.text_content:
A. Humans, chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans; exclude gibbons
B. Humans, chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, gibbons
C. Humans, chimpanzees, gorillas; exclude orangutans and gibbons
D. Humans only; exclude all other apes

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Under the given definitions, hominids include humans, chimps, gorillas, orangutans, and exclude gibbons.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B incorrectly includes gibbons; C incorrectly excludes orangutans; D confuses ‚Äúhominin‚Äù (tribe) with ‚Äúhominid‚Äù}\\)
\\(\\text{(family).}\\)

questions.question_text: A fossil hand shows: (i) clear power grip capability, (ii) fine pinch grip surfaces consistent with precision grip, and (iii) wear patterns consistent with repeated small- object manipulation.

orders.text_content:
Which inference is most consistent?

A. The fossil must be a non-primate because only primates have power grip
B. The fossil is likely a hominin because precision grip strongly suggests that grouping
C. The fossil is likely a prosimian because prosimians are the most advanced primates
D. The fossil is likely a hominoid but not a hominin because hominoids are defined by precision grip

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The key discriminator here is precision grip, which is used to distinguish hominins from other primates in this}\\)
\\(\\text{content.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: primates have power grip; prosimians are treated as an outgroup here; and hominoids (apes) are not}\\)
\\(\\text{defined by precision grip alone.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which anatomical change most directly improves shock absorption during bipedal walking?

orders.text_content:
A. A non-opposable big toe and an arched foot with a prominent heel bone
B. A larger ribcage and longer arms relative to legs
C. A rectangular jaw with large, irregular teeth
D. A prehensile tail used as a fifth limb

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. The foot changes are explicitly linked to shock absorption and stride recovery in bipedalism.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: the ribcage/arm ratio is not a shock-absorption adaptation; jaw shape relates to chewing; and a prehensile}\\)
\\(\\text{tail is associated with arboreal movement.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student claims: ‚ÄúIf a fossil has a more central foramen magnum, an S-shaped spine, and a bowl-shaped pelvis, it must also have longer arms than legs.‚Äù

Which response is most defensible?

orders.text_content:
A. Correct, because these traits only occur together as a fixed package
B. Incorrect, because the listed traits indicate bipedalism, which is associated with longer legs than arms
C. Correct, because longer arms are needed for efficient upright walking
D. Incorrect, because an S-shaped spine is a monkey-only trait

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The listed features are bipedal adaptations, and bipedalism is associated with longer legs than arms (not longer}\\)
\\(\\text{arms).}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A treats correlated traits as an absolute; C reverses the functional logic; D contradicts the bipedal}\\)
\\(\\text{adaptation list.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A partial skull is found with relatively large zygomatic arches and a pronounced sagittal crest. The associated site shows no evidence of controlled fire or advanced cooking.

Which explanation best links the anatomy to the likely diet and time-point in hominin evolution described here?

orders.text_content:
A. The individual likely ate softer cooked foods, reducing chewing demands
B. The individual likely relied more on fruits/leaves, requiring stronger chewing muscles
C. The individual likely ate a high-meat cooked diet, producing smaller teeth and weaker jaw muscles
D. The individual likely had a parabolic jaw with uniform small teeth because of a balanced diet

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. Larger zygomatic arches and sagittal crest are linked here to chewing tougher plant material (prior to major}\\)
\\(\\text{dietary shifts associated with cooking).}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A, C, and D describe trends associated with later cooking/softer foods and reduced chewing structures.}\\)

questions.question_text: A museum caption says: ‚ÄúLucy proved that toolmaking began before bipedalism evolved.‚Äù Based on the described significance of Lucy, which correction is best?

orders.text_content:
A. Lucy suggested bipedalism occurred long before cranial expansion and stone tools
B. Lucy suggested cranial expansion occurred before bipedalism but after stone tools
C. Lucy suggested bipedalism and stone tools appeared at the same time
D. Lucy suggested stone tools drove the evolution of a prehensile tail

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Lucy is used here as evidence that bipedalism predates cranial expansion and stone tools.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B reverses the timeline; C asserts simultaneity not supported; D introduces an unrelated trait.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Four fossil specimens are proposed to be Australopithecus species. A student wants to place them in the correct evolutionary order used in this course content.

Which sequence is correct?

orders.text_content:
A. africanus ‚Üí afarensis ‚Üí anamnesis ‚Üí sediba
B. anamnesis ‚Üí afarensis ‚Üí africanus ‚Üí sediba
C. sediba ‚Üí africanus ‚Üí afarensis ‚Üí anamnesis
D. afarensis ‚Üí anamnesis ‚Üí sediba ‚Üí africanus

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. That is the listed ordering.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: the other options permute the sequence and would misalign timeline-based reasoning questions.}\\)

questions.question_text: A site contains evidence of the earliest stone tools in this topic set, alongside cut-marked bones that suggest meat was consumed, but there is no evidence of controlled fire.

orders.text_content:
Which hominin is most consistent?

A. Homo habilis
B. Homo erectus
C. Homo sapiens
D. Homo neanderthalensis

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Homo habilis is linked here to the first stone tools (Oldowan) and the beginning of raw meat consumption.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: controlled fire is associated with Homo erectus in this content; the others are later.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher proposes: ‚ÄúThe shift to controlling fire would be expected to correlate with (i) increased braincase size over time and (ii) reduced chewing structures.‚Äù

Which option best matches the causal pathway described here?

orders.text_content:
A. Fire ‚Üí cooked meat ‚Üí increased protein intake ‚Üí larger braincase, plus less need for large jaw muscles
B. Fire ‚Üí reduced protein intake ‚Üí smaller braincase, plus greater need for large jaw muscles
C. Fire ‚Üí no dietary change ‚Üí no braincase change, but larger teeth due to harder food
D. Fire ‚Üí immediate loss of bipedalism due to a new selection pressure

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. The pathway links controlled fire to cooking, improved diet/protein intake, and a trend toward larger braincase;}\\)
\\(\\text{cooking also reduces chewing demands, supporting reduced jaw musculature over time.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B reverses direction; C denies the described trends; D is unrelated.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student writes: ‚ÄúCultural evolution is slower than biological evolution because it requires mutations.‚Äù

Which statement best corrects this?

orders.text_content:
A. Cultural evolution is faster because behaviours and ideas can be learned and transmitted socially
B. Cultural evolution is slower because it depends on inheritance of alleles only
C. Cultural evolution is the same speed as biological evolution because both require meiosis
D. Cultural evolution is impossible without a prehensile tail

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. Cultural evolution is defined as social transmission (not genetic inheritance), and is therefore described as}\\)
\\(\text{faster than biological evolution here.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B confuses cultural with genetic inheritance; C inserts irrelevant mechanisms; D is irrelevant.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A class compares two explanations for why hominin phylogenetic trees change over time:

Explanation 1: New fossils can force reconsideration of relationships.
Explanation 2: The fossil record is complete enough that new fossils rarely matter.

Which option is most consistent with the provided reasoning?

orders.text_content:
A. Explanation 1 only
B. Explanation 2 only
C. Both explanations
D. Neither explanation

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. The reasoning given explicitly links new evidence/new fossils to revisions of phylogenetic trees and highlights}\\)
\\(\\text{incompleteness.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B contradicts the premise; C includes a contradiction; D rejects both despite direct support for}\\)
\\(\\text{Explanation 1.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A fossil is dated using a method with substantial imprecision; later analysis suggests the fossil could be ‚Äúmuch younger or older‚Äù than originally proposed. A student argues: ‚ÄúThat would not affect any evolutionary conclusions.‚Äù

Which response is most defensible?

orders.text_content:
A. Correct, because dating only matters for geography, not evolutionary relationships
B. Incorrect, because uncertain ages can change where a fossil fits in a timeline and therefore alter inferred relationships
C. Correct, because radiometric methods (non-carbon-14) are always perfectly precise
D. Incorrect, because imprecision only happens with DNA sequencing, not fossils

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. If ages shift materially, the timeline used to infer relationships and branching order can change, so evolutionary}\\)
\\(\\text{conclusions can be revised.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A is too narrow; C overstates certainty; D misidentifies the source of the problem.}\\)

questions.question_text: A dataset shows that populations within Africa have the greatest genetic diversity, while many non-African populations show reduced diversity.

orders.text_content:
Which concept best explains this pattern under the accepted migration model described here?

A. Founder effect during migration waves out of Africa
B. Directional selection that always increases diversity during migration
C. Outgroup bias: prosimians artificially inflate diversity estimates
D. The multiregional hypothesis, because it predicts Africa should have the least diversity

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. The pattern is explained by a founder effect: migrating groups carry a gene pool that is not fully representative}\\)
\\(\\text{of the source population.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B is not the described mechanism; C is irrelevant; D does not align with the stated evidence used to}\\)
\\(\\text{support out-of-Africa.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which set of evidence most directly supports the accepted model that Homo sapiens originated in Africa and later migrated outward?

orders.text_content:
A. Oldest Homo sapiens fossils in Africa + greatest African genetic diversity + mtDNA tracing to a common African ancestor
B. Largest skull size in Homo neanderthalensis + presence of Y5 molar cusps
C. Presence of a prehensile tail in prosimians + absence of a tail in hominoids
D. Morphological clades unique to regions across a wide timespan

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. All three items are listed as support for the out-of-Africa model here.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B and C are not migration-line evidence; D is presented as support for multiregional logic, not out-of-Africa.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A geneticist defines ‚ÄúGroup X‚Äù as: ‚Äúa set of alleles on the same chromosome that tend to be inherited together.‚Äù They then notes that different human populations can be grouped based on related versions of Group X that reflect migration history.

Which pairing best matches the definitions used here?

orders.text_content:
A. Group X = haplotype; population groupings = haplogroups
B. Group X = haplogroup; population groupings = haplotypes
C. Group X = clade; population groupings = taxa
D. Group X = species; population groupings = genus

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A. A haplotype is the set of linked alleles/DNA on a chromosome; haplogroups are population-level groupings}\\)
\\(\\text{used to describe migration-linked diversity here.}\\) 
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: B swaps levels; C uses different concepts; D confuses genetic groupings with taxonomic ranks.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A student argues: ‚ÄúIf a wave of Homo sapiens reached Sahul and later became geographically isolated, you would expect their gene pool to remain fully representative of all African Homo sapiens.‚Äù

Which response best evaluates the claim?

orders.text_content:
A. Correct, because isolation always increases representativeness
B. Incorrect, because isolation following a migration wave can preserve a subset of variation rather than the full source diversity
C. Correct, because mtDNA guarantees identical diversity in all populations
D. Incorrect, because Sahul isolation would only change fossils, not genetics

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. A migration wave can involve a subset of the original gene pool; subsequent geographic/genetic}\\)
\\(\\text{isolation can maintain distinct patterns rather than ‚Äúfull representativeness.‚Äù}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A is backwards; C overclaims mtDNA; D ignores genetic consequences of isolation.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A class compares modern human genomes and finds that some non-African populations share approximately 1‚Äì4% of their DNA with Homo neanderthalensis, while many African populations do not.

Which inference best matches the explanation provided here?

orders.text_content:
A. Neanderthals were present in Africa in large numbers, causing African populations to gain Neanderthal DNA
B. Interbreeding most likely occurred outside Africa after some Homo sapiens migrated out and encountered Neanderthals
C. Neanderthals evolved from Homo sapiens, so non-Africans are more ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù
D. African populations lost Neanderthal DNA because cooked meat removes alleles

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{B. The explanation provided is that Neanderthals left Africa earlier; later, non-African Homo sapiens encountered}\\)
\\(\\text{them outside Africa and interbred, while African populations did not because Neanderthals were not present there}\\)
\\(\\text{at that time.}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A contradicts the stated reason; C is not supported; D is biologically incoherent in this context.}\\)

questions.question_text:
A researcher is evaluating two models of global human origins:

Model A: A single origin with later dispersal.
Model B: Regional evolution from geographically separated populations with interbreeding.

Which fossil pattern is presented here as supporting Model B?

orders.text_content:
A. The oldest Homo sapiens fossils are found in Africa
B. African populations show the greatest genetic diversity
C. Distinct combinations of morphological traits (morphological clades) persist in specific regions across a wide timespan
D. mtDNA traces all humans to a common African ancestor

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{C. Morphological clades unique to particular geographic regions across a wide time span are used here as evidence}\\)
\\(\\text{consistent with localised evolution plus interbreeding (multiregional framing).}\\)
\\( \\)
\\(\\text{Traps: A, B, and D are listed supports for the out-of-Africa model in this content.}\\)

questions.question_text: A museum is revising primate signage after updated classification guidance. Staff have labelled gibbons as ‚Äúhominids‚Äù because they are apes, and visitors keep confusing ‚Äúhominid‚Äù with ‚Äúhominin.‚Äù The curator wants the labels corrected to avoid inaccurate relationship claims.

orders.text_content: a) Correct the student by stating the most accurate classification term for gibbons and the reason the term ‚Äúhominid‚Äù does not apply here. (2 marks)
b) State what ‚Äúhominin‚Äù means in one sentence. (1 mark)
c) Using a simple relationship statement, compare how closely related gibbons are to humans versus chimpanzees and gorillas. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Gibbons are hominoids (apes; superfamily Hominoidea).}\\)
\\(\\text{Hominids (family Hominidae / great apes) exclude gibbons in this classification.}\\)
\\(\\text{A hominin is any species (living or extinct) classified within the tribe Hominini.}\\)

\\(\\text{Humans, chimpanzees and gorillas are all hominids (family Hominidae), so they share a more recent common}\\)
\\(\\text{ancestor with each other than with gibbons.}\\)
\\(\\text{Gibbons are hominoids but not hominids, meaning they diverged earlier and are less closely related to humans}\\)
\\(\\text{than humans are to chimpanzees (and gorillas).}\\)

questions.question_text: A lab compares two skull bases from a mixed deposit. One has a more central foramen magnum, the other more posterior. The team must infer locomotion, but prior cases show single-trait classification can be misleading when fossils are incomplete.

orders.text_content: a) Identify the most likely locomotion style suggested by this feature and justify why. (2 marks)
b) Explain why this feature alone is not enough to confidently classify the fossil as a specific hominin species. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Bipedal locomotion.}\\)
\\(\\text{A central foramen magnum supports upright posture by aligning the head on top of the spine for efficient walking.}\\)

\\(\\text{A single trait can occur in multiple taxa or vary in degree, so additional skeletal evidence (e.g., pelvis, femur, foot)}\\)
\\(\\text{is needed to avoid misclassification.}\\)

questions.question_text: A partial fossil hand shows strong power-grip features, but no clear surfaces for precision pinch. The site also contains stone fragments that may be tools or natural breaks. The team wants to infer whether the specimen is likely a hominin without overinterpreting the evidence.

orders.text_content: a) State the most defensible conclusion about whether this fossil is likely to be a hominin, and why. (2 marks)
b) Name two primate features (other than grip type) that could be used to support that the fossil is at least a primate. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{It is likely not a hominin.}\\)
\\(\\text{All primates have power grip, but precision grip is the key discriminator expected in hominins.}\\)

\\(\\text{1 mark for any of the following, to maximum of two marks.}\\)
\\(\\text{Forward-facing eyes / stereoscopic (3D) vision.}\\)
\\(\\text{Pentadactyl hand (five digits).}\\)
\\(\\text{Opposable thumb.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student models bipedal walking and claims an S-shaped spine explains most efficiency. Reviewers point out pelvis shape, femur angle, and foot structure each change stability and energy cost. They cite gait studies showing small alignment differences can matter over long distances.

orders.text_content: a) Explain how a bowl-shaped pelvis contributes to efficient bipedal walking. (1 mark)
b) Explain how an inward-angled femur reduces energy cost during walking. (1 mark)
c) Explain how foot adaptations and features (arched foot + prominent heel bone + non-opposable big toe) improve bipedal locomotion. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{A shorter, bowl-shaped pelvis supports body weight during upright movement (despite trade-offs such as more}\\)
\\(\\text{difficult childbirth).}\\)
\\(\\text{It reduces lateral leg swing, lowering energy expenditure while walking.}\\)

\\(\\text{Improves shock absorption and recovery after each stride.}\\)
\\(\\text{A non-opposable big toe and arch stabilise push-off for upright walking rather than grasping.}\\)

questions.question_text: A documentary script claims tool-making came before bipedalism ‚Äúto free the hands.‚Äù The science advisor warns Lucy is often used to challenge that oversimplified sequence. The producers want a defensible timeline linking bipedalism, cranial expansion, and technology.

orders.text_content: Correct the student‚Äôs claim using Lucy‚Äôs significance. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Lucy supports that bipedalism evolved long before major cranial expansion.}\\)
\\(\\text{Lucy supports that bipedalism existed before widespread stone tool-making (in this framing).}\\)

questions.question_text: A skull has large zygomatic arches and a sagittal crest, and nearby evidence suggests tough, fibrous foods. There is no strong evidence for controlled fire in the same layer. Researchers debate whether diet alone explains the anatomy or whether food processing must be considered.

orders.text_content: a) Infer the most likely dietary pressure suggested by these skull traits. (2 marks)
b) Explain why the absence of controlled fire evidence strengthens your inference. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Strong chewing demands consistent with tougher foods (e.g., fruits/leaves) requiring large jaw muscles.}\\)
\\(\\text{Larger chewing structures (zygoma/crest) are associated with greater reliance on hard-to-chew foods rather than}\\)
\\(\\text{softened/cooked foods.}\\)

\\(\\text{Without cooking, food would be less softened, increasing selection/need for strong chewing musculature and}\\)
\\(\\text{related skull features.}\\)

questions.question_text:
Students must order four Australopithecus species on a timeline before making evolutionary claims. The teacher warns that a wrong order can produce a convincing but incorrect story about when ‚Äúhuman-like‚Äù traits appeared. The correct sequence is needed for later interpretation questions.

Place the following in the correct order from oldest to most recent: A. anamensis, A. afarensis, A. africanus, A. sediba. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{anamensis ‚Üí afarensis ‚Üí africanus ‚Üí sediba.}\\)

questions.question_text: A summary of African climate shifts describes forests shrinking and more open habitats expanding over long periods. The article argues habitat change acts as a selection pressure, not just background. Students must link a habitat shift to specific traits likely to be favoured.

orders.text_content: a) State the environmental change linked here to Australopithecus evolution. (1 mark)
b) Explain how that change acts as a selection pressure (not just a background detail). (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Climate change (forests shifting toward grasslands).}\\)

\\(\\text{A new environment changes survival/reproductive success of different traits (selection pressure).}\\)
\\(\\text{Traits improving movement/efficiency in the new environment (e.g., bipedal adaptations) would be favoured over}\\)
\\(\\text{generations.}\\)

questions.question_text: An archaeological site has (i) Oldowan-style stone tools, and (ii) cut-marked bones suggesting meat consumption, but no evidence of controlled fire.

orders.text_content: a) Identify the most likely Homo species associated with this package of evidence. (1 mark)
b) Provide two linked reasons from the evidence that support your identification (not just a definition). (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Homo habilis.}\\)

\\(\\text{Associated with the first stone tools (Oldowan).}\\)
\\(\\text{Began eating raw meat; controlled fire/cooked meat is linked later (e.g., Homo erectus).}\\)

questions.question_text: A genetics study finds diversity is highest in Africa and often decreases with distance from Africa. The pattern appears across multiple genetic markers and fits migration models involving repeated founding events. Students must explain the mechanism and why it predicts reduced diversity.

orders.text_content: a) Name the population-genetics effect used to explain this pattern in the accepted migration model. (1 mark)
b) Explain why founder effect predicts reduced diversity outside Africa in this model. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{Founder effect.}\\)

\\(\\text{Migrating groups carry a gene pool that may be unrepresentative of the source population.}\\)
\\(\\text{Populations remaining in Africa had more time to accumulate genetic differences, increasing diversity relative to}\\)
\\(\\text{newly founded populations.}\\)

questions.question_text: A student argues mtDNA is ‚Äútoo small‚Äù to infer ancestry. The teacher notes mtDNA inheritance patterns can reveal population history when combined with fossil and geographic evidence. Students must explain how mtDNA supports a shared ancestry signal and why it matters for origin models.

orders.text_content: a) State the key conclusion drawn from mtDNA analysis in this content. (1 mark)
b) Explain why this supports the ‚Äúout of Africa‚Äù model rather than a fully regional-origin model. (2 marks)
c) Explain one reason mtDNA is useful for reconstructing human migration patterns and one limitation of using mtDNA alone. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{mtDNA analysis traces modern humans back to a common ancestor within Africa.}\\)

\\(\\text{A shared recent common ancestor located in Africa supports an African origin followed by dispersal.}\\)
\\(\\text{It is inconsistent with entirely separate, long-term regional origins producing modern humans independently without}\\)
\\(\\text{a common African origin signal.}\\)

\\(\\text{(useful): mtDNA is inherited maternally with little/no recombination, so mutations accumulate along maternal}\\)
\\(\\text{lineages and can be used to build a maternal "tree‚Äù and infer migration pathways/timings.}\\)
\\(\\text{(limitation): mtDNA represents only the maternal lineage (a single genetic locus) and may not reflect the full}\\)
\\(\\text{ancestry of populations; conclusions should be supported with nuclear DNA and other evidence (e.g., fossils/geography).}\\)

questions.question_text: A report groups populations using sets of DNA variants that tend to be inherited together. It shows distinct groupings can persist after long periods of limited gene flow without speciation. Students must explain how these patterns form and what they can indicate about migration.

orders.text_content: a) Define ‚Äúhaplotype‚Äù (1 mark)
b) Explain how different haplogroups can form as humans migrate. (2 marks)
c) Explain why distinct haplogroups can persist for long periods even if speciation does not occur. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text: \\(\\text{A haplotype is a group of alleles/DNA on the same chromosome that are likely to be inherited together.}\\)

\\(\\text{Populations migrating to different regions diverge genetically over time.}\\)
\\(\\text{This produces distinct population groupings (haplogroups) associated with different migration pathways/regions.}\\)

\\(\\text{If gene flow between groups is limited (e.g., geographic distance, cultural barriers), recombination and interbreeding}\\)
\\(\\text{occur less often between haplogroups, so the linked allele patterns remain common within each population.}\\)
\\(\\text{Even with some interbreeding, if the groups remain mostly reproductively compatible (no reproductive isolation),}\\)
\\(\\text{the populations can stay as one species while still retaining statistically distinct haplogroup frequencies due to}\\)
\\(\\text{shared ancestry, drift and/or founder effects.}\\)

questions.question_text: Evidence suggests humans reached Sahul long ago, and later sea-level rise split it into Australia, Tasmania, and Papua New Guinea. Researchers argue isolation can drive genetic divergence and cultural divergence over time. Students must connect reduced contact to both genetic and cultural change.

orders.text_content: a) State when Sahul was reached and what landmasses it later became. (2 marks)
b) Explain how the separation of Sahul could lead to both genetic and cultural divergence from other human populations. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Reached Sahul around 60,000 years ago (approx.).}\\)
\\(\\text{Sahul later became Australia, Tasmania, and Papua New Guinea.}\\)

\\(\\text{Geographic separation causes genetic isolation (limited gene flow), so allele frequencies/ haplotypes can}\\)
\\(\\text{diverge.}\\)
\\(\\text{Isolation also limits cultural exchange, allowing unique customs/skills to develop and persist in that population.}\\)

questions.question_text: Some non-African populations show a small Neanderthal DNA signal, and some Melanesian groups show Denisovan ancestry. A post misuses this to claim some groups are ‚Äúmore evolved.‚Äù Students must interpret the DNA patterns using interbreeding and migration and reject the value-judgment claim.

orders.text_content: a) Explain why many non-African populations have 1‚Äì4% Neanderthal DNA. (2 marks)
b) Explain why many African populations do not show this Neanderthal DNA signal in this framing. (1 mark)
c) A separate dataset suggests Denisovan ancestry is elevated in some Melanesian populations. State the most direct inference. (1 mark)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Homo sapiens and Neanderthals interbred, sharing DNA.}\\)
\\(\\text{Interbreeding occurred when non-African Homo sapiens encountered Neanderthals outside Africa.}\\)

\\(\\text{Neanderthals were not present in Africa during the relevant time, so African Homo sapiens did not interbreed}\\)
\\(\\text{with them.}\\)
\\(\\text{Homo denisova interbred with Melanesian humans.}\\)

questions.question_text: A display shows multiple hominin family trees updated over different years as new fossils and revised dates appear. A student says revisions mean the science is unreliable, while a researcher argues incomplete fossilisation and dating uncertainty make revisions expected. Students must explain why trees change legitimately.

orders.text_content: a) Give two reasons why the hominin fossil record is incomplete. (2 marks)
b) Explain how dating imprecision can force revisions of evolutionary relationships. (2 marks)
c) Explain how new fossil discoveries (even a single specimen) can legitimately change a hominin phylogenetic tree. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Many ancestors lived in environments that did not favour fossilisation.}\\)
\\(\\text{Some species existed for a short time and/or behaviours such as burial rituals reduce fossil availability.}\\)

\\(\\text{If fossils are dated as much younger/older than reality (especially with relative dating), the timeline becomes}\\)
\\(\\text{inaccurate.}\\)
\\(\\text{Changing timelines can change inferred branching order/relationships, so phylogenetic trees must be reconsidered}\\)
\\(\\text{when ages or new fossils change the evidence base.}\\)

\\(\\text{New fossils can add previously missing anatomical data (e.g., skull/teeth/pelvis traits) that changes which}\\)
\\(\\text{derived characteristics are shared, altering how species are grouped.}\\)
\\(\\text{A new fossil can reveal an intermediate form or extend the known time range/geographic range of a species,}\\)
\\(\\text{which can change inferred ancestry (e.g., which lineage is ancestral vs a side branch) and therefore the}\\)
\\(\\text{branching pattern of the tree.}\\)

questions.question_text: Which statement best describes the induced fit model?

orders.text_content:
A. The substrate permanently changes shape to match the enzyme‚Äôs active site.
B. The enzyme‚Äôs active site is rigid and perfectly complementary before the substrate arrives.
C. The enzyme‚Äôs active site changes shape slightly when the correct substrate approaches, improving complementarity and catalysis.
D. Enzymes speed up reactions by changing substrates into different reactants.

questions.question_text: A student heats an enzyme above its optimum temperature and then cools it back to the optimum. Explain why the enzyme may still have low activity after cooling.

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Extremely high temperature can disrupt bonds that maintain the enzyme‚Äôs tertiary structure (e.g., hydrogen bonds}\\)
\\(\\text{and disulphide bridges), causing a conformational change. The active site is altered and may no longer be}\\)
\\(\\text{complementary to the substrate, so activity can remain low even after temperature returns to optimum.}\\)

questions.question_text: For substrate concentration, what limits the reaction rate before and after the saturation point?

orders.text_content:
A. Before: enzyme concentration; After: substrate concentration
B. Before: substrate concentration; After: enzyme concentration
C. Before: temperature; After: pH
D. Before: pH; After: temperature

questions.question_text: A student adds more enzyme to a reaction mixture, but after a certain point the reaction rate stops increasing. Explain why and state the limiting factor at that point.

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{After the saturation point for enzyme concentration, substrate becomes the limiting factor. There are not enough}\\)
\\(\\text{substrate molecules to occupy the increasing number of enzyme active sites, so adding more enzymes does not}\\)
\\(\\text{increase enzyme‚Äìsubstrate complex formation per second and the rate plateaus.}\\)

questions.question_text: Describe the difference between a competitive inhibitor and a non-competitive inhibitor, including where each bind and what happens if you increase substrate concentration. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Competitive inhibitors bind to the active site and compete with the substrate; increasing substrate concentration can}\\)
\\(\\text{reduce inhibitor impact because the substrate is more likely to collide with and bind the active site. Non-competitive}\\)
\\(\\text{inhibitors bind to an allosteric site and change the enzyme‚Äôs shape/active site; increasing substrate concentration}\\)
\\(\\text{has minimal effect because the inhibitor is not competing for the active site.}\\)

questions.question_text: State two features that DNA and RNA have in common (2 marks)

questions.question_text: tRNA

questions.question_text: Cytokine is a protein that is released from human mast cells. Nucleic acids encode instructions for the synthesis of Cytokine in a mast cell. Outline the steps of transcription in the synthesis of tryptase. (3 marks)

\\(\\text{DNA strand by RNA polymerase.}\\)

questions.question_text: Cytokine is a protein that is released from human mast cells. Nucleic acids encode instructions for the synthesis of Cytokine in a mast cell.

orders.text_content: a) Identify the cellular location and the enzyme responsible for producing the mRNA that codes for Cytokine. (2 marks)
b) Outline the steps of translation in the synthesis of Cytokine. (3 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{Transcription occurs in the nucleus (nucleoplasm) of the mast cell.}\\)
\\(\\text{RNA polymerase binds the promoter of the Cytokine gene and synthesizes a complementary mRNA.}\\)

\\(\\text{Award one mark for each of the following, to a maximum of three marks.}\\)

\\(\\text{Elongation: tRNAs match anticodons to codons on Cytokine mRNA; ribosome catalyses peptide bond formation }\\)

\\(\\text{For secreted Cytokine, the ribosome associates with rough ER via a signal peptide; nascent Cytokine enters the}\\)
\\(\\text{ER lumen.}\\)

questions.question_text: A botanist compares three plants grown under the same hot, dry conditions: wheat (C3), maize (C4), and a cactus (CAM). Explain how each pathway differs in (i) where and/or when CO‚ÇÇ is fixed, and (ii) how this helps reduce photorespiration and/or water loss. (2 marks)

solutions.solution_text:
\\(\\text{1 mark for any of the following, to a maximum of two marks:}\\)
\\(\\text{C3 - CO‚ÇÇ fixed by Rubisco in mesophyll cells during the day; no separation mechanism, so more photorespiration}\\)
\\(\\text{in hot conditions.}\\)
\\(\\text{C4 - CO‚ÇÇ initially fixed by PEP carboxylase in mesophyll cells into 4C compounds, then CO‚ÇÇ released and}\\)
\\(\\text{re-fixed by Rubisco in bundle sheath cells (spatial separation), reducing photorespiration.}\\)
\\(\\text{CAM - stomata open at night; CO‚ÇÇ fixed by PEP carboxylase at night into organic acids, then CO‚ÇÇ released and}\\)
\\(\\text{fixed by Rubisco during the day (temporal separation), reducing water loss.}\\)
\\(\\text{Link to advantage - C4/CAM concentrate CO‚ÇÇ around Rubisco and/or keep stomata closed during the day,}\\)
\\(\\text{improving efficiency in hot/dry environments.}\\)

questions.question_text: The temperature outside reaches 40 degrees, and a wheat crop ‚Äì a C3 plant ‚Äì becomes withered, wilted and struggles to survive. Explain why this occurs (2 marks)

\\(\\text{Causes photorespiration where glucose is not produced and atp consumed and causes accumulation of}\\)
\\(\\text{toxic byproduct.}\\)

\\(\\text{that they can no longer bind to complementary substrate and therefor hindering photosynthetic reactions.}\\)

questions.question_text: A plant is exposed to increasing light intensity. The photosynthesis rate increases initially and then levels off. Which statement best explains why the rate levels off?
